PETITION.TITLE: Staging of American B52 Bombers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned in the Northern Territory respectfully showeth:
That the proposed use of Darwin Airport as a refuelling and Rest and Recreation base for American B52 bombers:

Jeopardizes the welfare of the citizens of Darwin and of all Australians, in that it establishes a stronger potential of Darwin being a nuclear target in any conflict between the USA and another power.
Impedes the sovereignty of the Australian nation in that Australian citizens would have neither control nor knowledge of whether B52's:
(a) Carried nuclear weapons
(b) Were engaged in bombing missions against another State.
Violates the Australian people's independence and links this nation irreconcilably with United States foreign policies thereby destroying the potential for independent Australian defence policy.

Violates democratic procedures in committing the Australian nation to participation in future wars without due consultation and informed assessment by Australian citizens and further increases the militarisation of the Indian Ocean thereby increasing the likelihood of super power conflict in this region.
Jeopardizes the welfare of the Citizens of Darwin, in that noise pollution and the threat of accidental radioactive fallout will increase substantially to the residents.
Negates the potential of the Australian nation to establish itself as a nation of Peace in the Pacific region and violates Australia's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

Your Petitioners' therefore pray that the Members of the House of Representatives will ensure that the Prime Minister withdraw the offer of Darwin, or any other location in Australia, as a base or depot for American B52 bombers. And that furthermore will ensure that any request of such usage by the U.S. Government be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Armitage,Mr Beazley,Mr Robert Brown,Mr Campbell,Dr Cass,Mr Charles,Mrs Child,Mr Duffy,Mr Free,Mr Holding,Mr Humphreys,Mr Jacobi,Mrs Kelly,Mr Kent,Mr Les McMahon,Mr Mildren,Mr Milton,Mr Mountford and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Commission: Melbourne Showband
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the Australian Parliament in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that:
As regular viewers and listeners of the ABC Melbourne Showband we were disappointed to learn of the dismissal of seventeen members of this outstanding orchestra.

We have had a great deal of pleasure over the past years viewing and listening to this band's fine music. It is the only full-time light orchestra in Australia and we are disgusted to think that such talented musicians should be dismissed in this manner.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to rescind this decision and make more money available for the continuance of the full Showband.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House condemns the Government for-

(1) its erratic and unstable behaviour, its preoccupation with its internal dissension and the paralysis of the proper functions of government and of this Parliament because of the Government's total distraction with these problems;
(2) the unfair and inequitable manner proposed for the elimination of or reduction in important community programs;
(3) the serious damage caused to the federal system by savage and unfair reductions in funding provided for the States;
(4) the deceitful way in which the States were deprived of $70m to which the Australian people were entitled; and
(5) the extraordinary behaviour of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer in seeking to publicly humiliate the Premiers through shoddy leaks to the media.
I would expect that, as a matter of self-respect, the Government would want to take this motion immediately.
Mr Malcolm Fraser-The motion will be taken immediately.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving his motion forthwith.
Motion of Condemnation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House condemns the Government for-

(1) its erratic and unstable behaviour, its preoccupation with its internal dissension and the paralysis of the proper functions of government and of this Parliament because of the Government's total distraction with these problems;
(2) the unfair and inequitable manner proposed for the elimination of or reduction in important community programs;
(3) the serious damage caused to the federal system by savage and unfair reductions in funding provided for the States;
(4) the deceitful way in which the States were deprived of $70m to which the Australian people were entitled; and
(5) the extraordinary behaviour of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer in seeking to publicly humiliate the Premiers through shoddy leaks to the media.

The Opposition does not take this action lightly. Formal moves to censure the government of the day are made only when the state of the nation's affairs demands them-when the government has patently failed to fulfil the trust given to it by the people. This describes precisely the condition of the Government today.

Over the past 10 days, and especially over the past 48 hours, various events have given the nation an extraordinary insight into the degraded state into which this Government has descended: The disarray, the turmoil, the confusion and the incompetence of the Government itself, and the consequent paralysis and corruption of the Parliament. Because of these events, the truth is now apparent. Behind that stony Easter Island image, nothing stirs but personal and malevolent ambition.

The forces that motivate this Government have nothing to do with the welfare of the nation; they have all to do with the survival in power of the Government. The new health program, the Lynch Committee proposals, and the results of the Premiers Conference, show that what this Government intends for the next decade is not the great leap forward that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser) promised during the election last October, but a timid scramble backwards. They show that all that this Government has in mind for the 1980s is nostalgia for the 1950s, when the haves were urged on to ever greater affluence and the have-nots were left to fend for themselves.

The nation is entitled to ask why the Government is in such a dishevelled state. The answer can be found in the Prime Minister's contemptuous treatment of the Premiers and the experience of his former Minister for Industrial Relations. The petty vindictiveness of the Prime Minister towards the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and his selective leaking of confidential Cabinet decisions in order to score cheap points off the Premiers, show that the Prime Minister will go to extreme lengths to protect his ascendancy over his colleagues.

The honourable member for Kooyong has now told us the reasons for this degradation of parliamentary and government affairs: The Prime Minister's manic determination to get his way, his suspicion of his colleagues, the subversion of government in factional interests, the bitter tensions that exist within the coalition. The honourable member for Kooyong has put it on the scoreboard. These are the reasons that, seven months after the election, the Government has achieved nothing, save a few favours for a few friends. These are the reasons that the nation's affairs are in such a disorganised, ineffective state. These are the reasons that the Prime Minister and his colleagues deserve the most severe censure of this Parliament and the nation.

The Prime Minister has nobody but himself to blame for the latest crisis in which he finds himself embroiled. He was not content with simply taking the States to the cleaners to the tune of $70m. He was determined to ensure that everyone should know how clever he was, and how tough he could be in a confrontation with the Premiers. He embarked on a strategy on Monday in which he set up the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to leak the details of their cleverness to selected journalists. When this did not produce the desired headlines, the necessary stage-managed publicity, the Prime Minister himself called a background briefing of journalists from the Herald and Weekly Times group of newspapers, among them Mr Trevor Hawkins from the Sun News-Pictorial, Mr Wallace Brown of the Courier Mail, and Mr Geof Kitney of the Perth Daily News. This briefing in the Prime Minister's office took place on Tuesday night, and produced the news stories yesterday morning which so incensed the Western Australian Premier, Sir Charles Court.

It was from these incidents that flowed the extraordinary sequence of events last night in which the Prime Minister and the Treasurer between them held four Press conferences to try to extricate the Prime Minister from the consequences of his smart-Alick behaviour. I emphasise that these were, of course, Press conferences. At no stage did the Prime Minister seek to come into this House and attempt to justify his deceit of the Premiers, or to explain why he thought it necessary to leak to the Press information that could only be seen as humiliating to all State governments and contemptuous of the Australian people. Nor has there yet been any explanation to the Parliament why this Prime Minister believes he has some special exemption from the normal Westminster conventions that preclude Ministers from breaching Cabinet confidentiality.

As past events have demonstrated, however, this Prime Minister obviously believes the usual rules and proper standards concerning a great range of attitudes, among them trust, loyalty and honesty, both in personal relationships and in his conduct of government, simply do not apply to him. The honourable member for Kooyong made this perfectly clear in his speech to the House last week explaining his resignation from the Fraser Ministry. What has happened this week serves only to substantiate the very strong criticisms of the Prime Minister that were contained in that speech. Let me remind the House that, like the Peacock resignation, the events of the past 48 hours sprang from that much abused political tactic, the background briefing. In the case of the honourable member for Kooyong, so-called senior government officials were the source of the story that appeared in the Australian on 14 April concerning allegations damaging to his political and personal integrity. As the honourable member said last week, it was this story, and the Prime Minister's gross disloyalty to him in not denying it in detail, that finally provoked his resignation.

The source of the Australian story has not been disclosed. Yet ironically we now have the same tactic of the background briefing being used, again in an issue concerning the Prime Minister, again with the same euphemistic source of senior government officials, and again causing political fall-out for the Government. The difference this time is that the Prime Minister has been caught out. He has been forced to admit his direct involvement, both in authorising the Treasurer to leak to the Press, and then by calling his own background briefing to reinforce his disclosure of information humiliating to the Premiers but of short term advantage to himself. I suggest that, if the honourable member for Kooyong ever had any doubts as to the identity of the source of the Australian story that shafted him, he would have few remaining doubts after the events of the past 48 hours. I suggest also that few other members of this Parliament would now have any real doubts either, irrespective of any denials to the contrary.

The Prime Minister's conduct in this matter, with all of his twisting and turning in the last 48 hours-first of all to exploit the circumstances and then to preserve his political hide-raises fundamental issues that go to the heart of this censure motion. First, there is the broad question of Commonwealth-State relations. Clearly the Prime Minister and the Treasurer believe that conferences with the Premiers are, as one Premier now describes them, no more than exercises in bluff in which the biggest cheat wins. There is no doubt the principle was upheld on this occasion. Equally clearly, this Government is utterly contemptuous of such conferences as forums for meaningful and responsible negotiations. Second, there is the matter of economic management.

On this occasion the Government had made up its mind on the maximum finance it would share among the States. It then set about seeing how far it could squeeze the Premiers to stay under that limit, irrespective of the merits of their individual arguments or of the needs of the States in terms of economic and welfare development. That is, this is not just a repudiation of the Premiers but it is a rejection of the rights of the people of this country. Having succeeded by shaving $70m off the funds that Cabinet had agreed the Commonwealth could afford, the Prime Minister could not resist boasting of his success or, when his cheap sneering backfired, pushing the Treasurer forward to take his place and to take the blame. This is not only an arrogant and irresponsible means of economic management, it is also wholly consistent with this Government's erratic and ad hoc administration of the last 5 1/2 years.

Finally, there are the ethics of the Prime Minister's behaviour. We on this side of the House have long held the view that this Government cannot be trusted and that this Prime Minister can be trusted least of all. We have said so, forcefully and with certainty, whenever the occasion warranted. I say so again today. I go further and say that the standards of the Prime Minister are the standards of the bully, the standards of the sneak and the standards of the snake oil salesman. They are standards that infect this Government from the top and they are standards that have been adopted by those who seek promotion and Prime Ministerial patronage above all else. They are standards that have been publicly paraded in the past 48 hours to the discomfort, I am sure, of many honourable members opposite whose sense of honesty and decency is as outraged as is that of any other member of this Parliament or the community by the Prime Minister's behaviour in the past fortnight.

The Prime Minister has prevaricated, he has evaded, he has sneered, he has threatened, he has boasted and he has used his staff to hector in an attempt to intimidate the Australian Broadcasting Commission into scrapping video film of a stumbling and shifty interview he gave last night. After that appalling performance on being confronted by questions he did not want to answer on events his own foolish actions had precipitated, he tried to censor the news. His Press secretary, Mr Barnett, who gracelessly is accommodated in the officials enclosure opposite, thundered around the Press Gallery corridors last night like a half-pay reject from Cop Shop trying to bully and badger the ABC journalists into censoring the news, and when that did not work, levelling threats against them. Is that the standard that this parliamentary institution has sunk to? Are they the ingredients, the qualities, of the ethical standards that the Prime Minister clings to?

All that the Prime Minister has not done is the only thing he should have done when this issue burst about him; that is, he has not come into this Parliament, admitted his mistake and his guilt-instead of hiding behind the Treasurer-and he has not reconvened the Premiers Conference to offer explanations and apologies as well as the short-changed $70m. What that demonstrates, of course, is that Parliament continues to be as much of an irrelevance to this Prime Minister as it has always been to his Government. Question Time is a farce; the Standing Orders are misused as an obstruction to proper scrutiny and accountability; the Notice Paper is no more than a stock-list of deferred debates and questions on notice, some of which have been waiting for six months for an answer. The Government's legislative program is a joke.

We are now in the tenth week of sitting, yet nothing of real substance has gone through this Parliament since the election, apart from an apology of a Bill to establish a restricted Human Rights Commission and a piece of pay-off legislation to Mr Rupert Murdoch to guarantee his new airline's purchase of 21 new aircraft. If the Prime Minister does forget old friends within his own ranks at least he remembers to pay off old debts to people outside the Parliament. Freedom of information legislation which frees no information at all is jammed in the Senate, and we are all still waiting for the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) to bring before the Parliament his foreshadowed amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act, a Bill which has all the earmarks of another sell-out of the public interest to this Government's great and powerful friends.

What we can make of this is that Parliament has done nothing because this Government has nothing for it to do. It reacts; it does not initiate. It has no perceived objective except to stay in office by gimmickry and deceit, and no vision beyond the political problems of the immediate 24 hours. All these aspects of this Government's conduct are crystallised in the events of the last 48 hours.

No single issue better characterises this Government's lack of integrity, or better illustrates its fundamental dishonesty, than does the issue of health care. Of all the broken promises, the dishonoured commitments, the smart, mealy-mouthed slogans, the double dealing and the double standards, and the deliberate and calculated lies of the last 5 1/2 years it is the Fraser Government's policies and actions on health care which epitomise its basic character, its subservience to wealth and privilege and its mean and grubby behaviour towards the rest of the Australian people.

We on this side of the House see the question of health care quite differently from our opponents. We believe health care is a right, not a privilege. That is why we introduced the Medibank scheme in 1974. It is why we remain committed to the reintroduction of a universal health insurance scheme at the first opportunity after the next election. If the new health program is an example of the Government's duplicity, the Lynch committee's proposals-coupled with the results of the Premiers Conference-demonstrate equally well the Government's timidity. Three and a half years ago the Prime Minister announced that we were ready, as he put it, 'to stride into a new era of prosperity and development'. Over the past fortnight we have been given a glimpse of this Government's vision of what this era contains. What a miserable, dispirited vision it is!

In the Lynch committee program, and throughout the results of the Premiers Conference, the Government is demonstrating that it has decided to run away from its responsibilities. It somehow sees virtues in this-virtue that is given the name of small government. In the real world, of course, small government is meaningless. In the real world, pressures and expectations exist that demand government that is aware, government that is realistic, government in contact with the people and not, as the Lynch committee would have it, government cut off from them. In this real world, there are more than two million people trying to survive in poverty. For with all its potential, this society somehow manages to have one of the most inequitable distributions of wealth in the industrialised world. Social and economic injustices abound in welfare programs, in housing, in health, education, in the law, in the distribution of wealth, income and opportunity. Discrimination plagues such minority groups as migrants and Aboriginal Australians, who suffer under one of the highest incidences of disease in the world. The drive for equal rights for women has all but been abandoned. The need for rational urban planning, housing and regional development programs has been denied.

Individual citizens-no match on their own for ever-growing corporations and their ever-widening power-deserve more influence in their jobs and in the market place and greater protection for their environment. This is the reality and the Government has run away from it. The only vision that stirs its leader is that of power and how to maintain it, no matter how malevolent, damaging and divisive the measures that have to be adopted to achieve that end. Yesterday's events show that he will abuse his relationship with the Press, ignore the Parliament and even subvert national economic policy-making to maintain his ascendancy over those he imagines to be a threat to him and his position.

Everywhere in the nation's administration is confusion, contradiction and incompetence. The Fraser Government and its ways have become a farce. Long after the people have swept it out of office the joke will be going round the pubs that the Fraser Government was the government that decided to sell a cement works in the city where it had just closed down all the building industry. Any normal Prime Minister who presided over such chaos would resign, even if only out of self-respect. But this Prime Minister is not normal. He gained power with whatever unsavory weapons were to hand. He is obviously determined to hang on to it, no matter what the cost to the nation or what damage it does to his own party.

By this motion the House seeks to recall the Prime Minister and his colleagues to their senses. It seeks to remind them that Australians expect more from their Government than they have received from this Administration-confusion and incompetence concerning everything but the maintenance of power and the concentrated pursuit of vendettas against assumed rivals. This Prime Minister almost single handedly has managed to infect and corrupt the body politic in this country to an unbelievable degree. There is no longer respect or confidence within the community for the way in which political government of this nation is conducted by the Fraser Government and there is only one man who can accept the responsibility for that very black honour-the Prime Minister of this country. He is a disgrace to this nation. He ought to be scourged from office. I thoroughly recommend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. I ask for leave of the House to amend the motion to make it a censure rather than a condemnation. It affects the time factor.
—Leave is refused.
—Leave is refused.

—It does not make any difference whether this motion is called a condemnation or a censure; everybody in the nation knows it is one of censure on the Government. Last evening we came into this Parliament asking the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to make a statement in the House. He declined to do it. Why? Because he was afraid of the debate that would then have taken place. The only reason there were any Press conferences or television appearances yesterday was that Sir Charles Court said: 'Unless you, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, go in front of the Australian public to say you deliberately deceived us I will bring you down as leader and as Treasurer. I will move for your sacking, and as I have a fair bit of control in Western Australia I will guarantee there will be a replacement both for the Prime Minister and for the Treasurer'. That is the only reason the two distinguished gentlemen decided to go to air last night. But, they did not have enough courage to come into this House and debate the matter that was before the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: What is before the nation? How is it that the Prime Minister can say to the nation: 'I have taken all the money out of the taxpayers' pockets but I will not give as much as the States need; I will withhold it and I will do it by deceit and deception'. He says: 'When I have fooled the Premiers and made them look complete idiots, I will then give a background briefing to the Press as to how stupid and foolish they were'. What sort of federalism is that? What sort of national leadership is it when those two distinguished gentlemen, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, take delight in making fools of the leaders of all the States?

In what way were the Premiers made fools of? It was on the basis that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer would withhold from the States not a mere $70m but $280m of Australian taxpayers' money-not the Prime Minister's money, not the Treasurer's money and not the Commonwealth's money, but Australians' money. Why do the States need that money? Honourable members ought to know the problems of the States. Is it any wonder that Sir Charles Court is on record in regard to this matter. He is Government parties' leader in Western Australia. Honourable members opposite might not like him but at least he has enough courage to stand up and make them look weak and cowardly-and that is why they are here today. The only reason they have come into this Parliament to listen to the debate is that they have been instructed to do so, otherwise they will not retain their title. Why was Sir Charles Court so upset, as every Premier was upset? Not one of them accepted the offer made. They negotiated furiously. They argued, in the interests of the Australian people, that the Government should give them what they needed. The Government denied them their rights, which means it has denied the rights of every Australian. Sir Charles Court said:
I have been misled by the Prime Minister. In February 1976 I was promised a new deal on federalism. It guaranteed me increased allocation from the Federal coffers, but I have been deceived.

In other words, Sir Charles Court has said: 'You, Mr Prime Minister, have gone back on your word. You broke your undertaking. You said in 1976 that we would not be worse off as States. We are substantially worse off and you have deceived me.' How did the Prime Minister do it? The arrangement was that the States were to get 39.87 per cent of the personal income tax receipts. Under this formula they get a mere 38 per cent. Does the Prime Minister expect them to accept it-no! It would mean a drop overall of about $280m. The Prime Minister informed the Press that the States received 10 per cent. They did not get 10 per cent because the Government guaranteed that included in their allocation this time was the provision for urban transport and soil conservation, for which previously specific purpose grants were made. They received 9 per cent. The Prime Minister has even misled the nation on that. They needed 13 per cent. If one adds on the other 4 per cent one will arrive at the amount of $280m. Does the Prime Minister believe the States were just going to put that money in the bank and not use it?

Let us look at what else the Government has done to the taxpayers of Australia. Let us look at the health program. The Government has demanded that when a person goes to hospital as an outpatient he or she must pay $15 a time. Can one imagine the situation of a person who is dependent upon a dialysis machine and who has to go to hospital at least four times a month and the situation of those suffering from skin diseases who have to attend the outpatients' department perhaps once a week? The Government has demanded that the States extract extra money from these poor, unfortunate taxpayers who suffer ill health. What sort of a health scheme is it that is run only on a Treasury basis? How can a government run a health scheme on the basis of monetary allocation and not on the needs of the sick, the poor and the underprivileged? The Government has demanded that the States extract millions of dollars from the Australian people in their efforts to keep their health. What sort of a nation is it that cannot afford a health program?

The Government guaranteed in its previous election campaign that it would maintain Medibank. What a joke that is. That is one example of the many promises the Government made. The Government promised that it would maintain wage indexation and tax indexation. It intended to maintain all the rights and privileges of the Australian nation. The Prime Minister has broken promise after promise. The chickens have come home to roost now because the Government's own kith and kin, the wool growers and others, are sending urgent telegrams saying: 'Look what you have done in relation to wool testing. It will affect 100,000 wool growers and the test will not even be accepted internationally'.

Even the Prime Minister's own supporters cannot tolerate him any more. When the Premiers as a group say that he is not to be trusted, why should he remain in office? If the Prime Minister were to go to the nation now on the basis of this so-called arrangement with the States, every Premier, irrespective of his politics, would vote against him. They would oppose him and ask for him to be removed from office because he is of no value to the nation. The reason is this: Unless a person has integrity and political honesty he or she is not entitled to hold office. The behaviour of the Prime Minister right across the spectrum of this nation, whether it be in relation to national affairs or international affairs, is of deceit and deception. It does not matter what the Prime Minister tells us in this Parliament, he is prone to deceive us. He is prone to have arrangements made with the United States of America that do not mean what they say and arrangements made with the States that do not mean what they say. He has given indications in this Parliament of his intentions but he never carries them out. Promises made at election time are never carried out. These are the problems in relation to what is said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, phooey.

—'Oh, phooey', says the interjector at the back of the chamber. He holds a marginal seat that we will take next time there is an election. Let us look at the record of the Government. Let us take one issue that affects the States. I refer to the area of pre-schools. I was the Minister who went around to every Premier and who at the time had responsibilty for looking after children under the age of five years. I said to them: I will put it in writing that we promise to provide 75 per cent of the recurrent costs of looking after pre-school children. This we did. If we look at New South Wales, for example-this situation applies right across the board-we find now that the Commonwealth's contribution to recurrent costs for pre-school children is a mere 30 per cent. If we look at it from the point of view of children under five being cared for in New South Wales, that State now has to pay $8.2m for this care. The figure in 1976-77 was a mere $1.7m. Is this not symptomatic of all the things this Government has done? If people go to Queanbeyan Hospital they will pay more; if they send children to the pre-school at Queanbeyan they will pay more.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at what has happened from the point of view of housing grants. In 1975 $127m was allocated for housing grants. In 1980-81, $90m was allocated. This represents a reduction in monetary terms and a 50 per cent reduction in real terms. Let us look at dwelling construction. In 1977 New South Wales was able to construct 3,000 houses for low income earners. But with the money which has been allocated by this Government it will be able to construct 1,200 houses. Is it any wonder that the States are asking: 'What are you going to do for us?' Australian taxpayers are involved. I turn now to the question of looking after children in institutions. Again the Government says that this is another State responsibility. In 1976 the Government gave a measly $5 for each child in an institution. That allocation has not been increased since 1976. So the States-I use New South Wales as an example-now have to provide $27.50 for each child. This Government gives nothing. That applies right across the board. The States have now been given a signal that this Government will not provide any unemployment benefit to 16 and 17 year olds. The States will have to pay for their institutional or other care. This Government gives them nothing. And this is a national government interested in welfare!

Let us look now at the meals on wheels situation. In the three years that we were in government we increased the subsidy for meals on wheels on three occasions. This Government has increased it once. That service is not able to keep going as it cannot keep up with the costs. The States are having to provide meals for the pensioners and the poor as this Government is not prepared to do it. The States have to do this using taxpayers' money in the States. The meals on wheels operation requires vehicles to operate and this Government has not increased the subsidy for these vehicles but has escalated petrol tax by 400 per cent. In social welfare programs-whether we are talking about pre-schools, housing, juvenile problems or the care of young or old people-this Government has failed at every turn. The States could use $280m. They would use it for Australians who are paying taxes now. What right has this Government as trustee to say that it will appropriate that money to itself because it has a mandate so to do? Where is this Government's mandate to do any of these things? Where is its mandate to deny care to children? Where is its mandate to whittle down the States' housing finances? Where is its mandate to deny help to the underprivileged, whether they be in institutions or anything of that nature?

TALK.START.PARA: —Your mandate would increase taxes.

—That is just it. This Government's mandate is: Do not increase the taxes federally but sock the people really hard through the States. The honourable member for Dundas should try to tell the people in his electorate that their taxes have been reduced. They will say to him: 'Ruddock, you are out of your mind. We are paying a fortune for the care of our children. We cannot get housing loans at reasonable interest rates. We are paying enormous costs which the States have to impose for transport, health care, and every other charge'. What a thimble and pea trick it is for this Government to say: 'We will reduce the taxes to you but you will pay through the nose'. The whole idea of federalism was to give everybody in Australia a fair share of the wealth. This Government has approached it on the basis that the States should try to do the best they can. The Government knows better than anyone else that some States have more capacity to levy taxes than others. Is this Government running federalism on the basis that there has to be double taxation? Obviously it is.

SPEECH.PARA: There has to be a Federal tax. There has to be a State tax. That is the Government's policy. If we go to any of the people in Australia today they say 'What do we need a national government for? It opted out of everything'-except selling this country to overseas interests. The Government has opted out of everything. What is it going to do now as a national government? Why does it not talk about being involved in education? Why does it not talk about being involved in health? Why is it not involved in housing? Why is it not involved in urban transport where the Government has slashed programs to ribbons? The Government promised in every election campaign, for example, to assist the country lines program. After the election the Government deprived the program of the moneys that were promised. Everywhere that the Government has made promises it has failed to fulfil them.

What does it mean? The interjection referred to taxes. The Government says: 'Perhaps we will drop Federal income tax rates by $2 or $3 but the mugs outside won't know that. They will have to pay another $20 or $30 through State taxes but we will go away as being good economic managers'. I make the point-luckily this is the point-that the State Ministers for Health will be here tomorrow. I hope that those Ministers tear the Government to ribbons on the basis of how the Government misled them. The Premiers are coming back. They would love to come back tomorrow. They ought to be here tomorrow to tear the Government limb from limb on the basis of how the Government deceived them by saying that it could not afford any more money.

The Prime Minister went out and told the Press that it was beyond any possibility that the States could get another one per cent increase. In fact, as Sir Charles Court has said, under the arrangements, the promises made to him in February 1976, he was entitled to another 4 per cent from the point of view of keeping up with the costs of living. Inflation is spiralling. Who has to pay the costs of inflation? Interest rates now are 17 per cent or more. Who is paying that? The Australian taxpayer. Where is the Government's economic management at any level we want to look at? How dreadful is it to think that we had a parliament in session yesterday and not one of the Government's leaders could find time to come into this House to discuss the problems as to why the States were upset, as to why the Premiers of every State were concerned as to what was to happen to their programs! The Prime Minister could not have cared less. It was not until Sir Charles Court said: 'Listen, unless you go in and make a public confession and show how weak you are, I will bring you down, from Western Australia. I will guarantee that the Liberal machine there will move into action and we will have a new leader in the national Parliament very soon'. That is where the influence came from. Top marks to Sir Charles Court! Even though his politics are poor, his principles in this area are accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentlemen's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government in 1975 and in successive elections and with record majorities was given a mandate to govern this country well. We will discharge that duty through this Parliament and through future parliaments.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask honourable members on my left not to keep up the interjection level which means that the right honourable gentleman cannot be heard. I ask all honourable members to observe that.

—In 1975 this Government was first given a mandate to govern this country well. After that election and through successive elections and with record majorities this duty has been discharged, and it will continue to be through this Parliament and through successive parliaments. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) spoke of the state of the nation as though there was no hope and confidence in the wider community. How far apart can he be from the feelings, the sense of confidence and optimism, that and now shared in every corner of Australia? How far is he from the imaginative decisions that we have taken over the last few days in health, in the Review of Commonwealth Functions and, indeed, in the Premiers Conference itself? The Leader of the Opposition and the Australian Labor Party can only look to the past and the prescriptions of the past which show that they believe it is government, government decisions, government bureaucracies and large spending which must determine it all. A classic example is health where the Labor Party believes the Government through taxpayers' funds should provide everything, should spend everything and do everything. We happen to have a different belief. We believe that available funds should be concentrated on the disadvantaged and on those in need. We do not believe that taxpayers' money should be used to pay unnecessary subsidies to those who are better off in the community. We do not believe in undermining individual responsibility by centralised bureaucracy. We believe the user should pay and the user is entitled to the influence that comes from paying. We do not believe in dual control of the Federal and State governments over Australia's hospitals. We believe the States have responsibilities that they ought to discharge. Labor's arrogant assumption that Canberra knows best is false indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: The central part of this debate is whether the people of Australia, the taxpayers, should have dollars to spend on their own account or whether the Government should continue to absorb larger and larger funds, leaving less and less freedom to people throughout this country. A very essential principle consistent with political freedom is economic freedom, freedom to make decisions and to choose and determine one's own future. Labor's high taxes, big bureaucracy and interfering regulations undermined this economy in the past and they would do it again. We well know that the predictions of the Leader of the Opposition about the Australian economy time and again have proved to be so very wrong.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my left are interjecting at a very loud level. This is a motion moved by the Party leader, the Leader of the Opposition. He has made serious charges against the Government. In any sense of fairness, especially in the national Parliament where it is a major national issue that is being debated, the right honourable gentleman will be heard in silence.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Prime Minister is not answering the charge. This is Professor Kemp's 1975 policy speech.
—Order! The honourable member for Blaxland will resume his seat and remain silent.
—This is written but unrehearsed. Obviously he has no intention of answering the debate.

—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will give example to his followers either by his continual interjections or by his silence. This is the national Parliament and I ask the Leader of the Opposition to maintain proper decorum and remain silent.
—Mr Speaker, I accept that. I will set the standard for my supporters, which, unlike that of the Prime Minister, will be a decent one.

—The Leader of the Opposition has not shown it yet, but let us see whether he can for the rest of this debate. I was indicating that the Leader of the Opposition's economic predictions have proved very wrong on so many occasions and they are wrong for this decade. In June last year he said that we would have an inflation rate of 12 per cent for the year to December. How wrong he was. In 1978 he said that we would enter the 1980s with unemployment approaching a million. How wrong he was and how wrong he is. He said that the 1980s are looming as a decade of despair. The only despair will be in the hearts and minds of the members of the Australian Labor Party as they dig graves for themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth went into this particular Premiers Conference which has led to this debate with a negotiating position. It would have been vastly offensive to the Premiers if we had made a Cabinet decision which said: 'These are the dollars, these are the cents. We have no negotiating position; we have no capacity to listen to your arguments, no capacity to adjust as a consequence of the arguments that are put'. The Cabinet decision made it perfectly plain that at most the funds given to the Premiers would be no higher in real terms than the year before, but that the final decision would be determined at the time by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and myself in conjunction with other colleagues who were at that Conference. The decision was made on that day. The decision stands. The Commonwealth demonstrated that it was reasonable, that it was flexible and that it listened to the Premiers. The Premiers would expect us to go to that Conference with a negotiating position and with some capacity for movement. If we did anything else it would certainly be offensive to all Premiers.

Our fundamental concern in these matters is to protect the taxpayers of Australia. The Opposition, the Labor Party, and most of the Premiers say that they want to spend more and more funds. If we acceded to all the requests of the Premiers, if we acceded to the exhortations of the Australian Labor Party, the taxpayers of this country would have no funds at all left for themselves. Protection of the Australian taxpayer is essential to achieve the basic objectives which are important to this nation. Those objectives include higher rates of growth-high by world standards, high by the standards of the last decade-and lower rates of inflation than we had under Labor, lower rates of inflation than will be found in other countries. Over 300,000 jobs have been created under our policies over the last two years. What other industrialised country can show a performance equivalent to that in the circumstances we have? In addition, there has been greater help to those in need than on any other occasion, greater security for those in need through indexation of pensions, greater assistance to the disadvantaged than Labor ever dreamed of providing.

We need to understand that the money we spend, the money Labor would like to spend, the money Premiers ask for, cannot be taken out of the sky. It does not belong to the Commonwealth; it does not belong to the States; it belongs to the taxpayers, the individual men and women of this nation. It is not a question of cheating taxpayers; it is not a question of cheating the States; it is a question of making a proper judgment about what resources should be used by government and what resources should be left to the people, the taxpayers of Australia. There is no robbery in that, and there is nothing new in States complaining. There is nothing new in States asking for more funds, but if we have a Commonwealth government, as we did in Labor's term, which does not have the capacity to say no to greater and increased demands for expenditure, then quite plainly we destroy this economy and destroy the wellbeing of Australia's families.

We provided the maximum funds that were responsible on the arguments of the day and within the discretion provided by Cabinet. That was the appropriate thing to do to protect the wellbeing of this economy and the wellbeing of Australian families and taxpayers. It is quite plain that taxpayers are fed up with governments or political parties in opposition which just want to spend and spend and go on spending. They know that that way lies disaster for themselves, for their businesses, and for their children. Quite plainly, the States should show responsibility, as all governments should, and cut waste and bureaucracy and over-regulation. They should repeat the example of Sir Phillip Lynch and his committee which reviewed Commonwealth functions. I have no doubt that each State could pursue the same exercise with merit.

Somebody has tried to suggest that there is something wrong in a Cabinet decision being made public. I should have thought that overwhelmingly the purpose of Cabinet decisions is to make them public, and the Treasurer and I, in consultation, did just that. There is nothing wrong with Cabinet decisions being made public. That is why Cabinet decisions are made-for the purpose of government. To suggest that there is something wrong in that is a strange thing indeed.

The Labor Party once more shows itself as a party defending higher taxation and big spending. We need to understand that the Leader of the Labor Party has said that the challenge to socialism is the rapid spread of philosophies based on lower taxes and smaller government. He knows that as the Australian people come to understand better and better that their wellbeing is dependent upon those philosophies, the chance of socialism having its day in Australia will be abandoned for all time. What kind of political party is it that sees cuts in government spending as robbing governments? This Government is supporting taxpayers and giving them greater influence over the affairs of this nation. If the Opposition had been responsible, it would have been supporting the Government in what it did at the Premiers Conference. The Labor Party, as always, at the last election--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The right honourable gentleman will resume his seat. The honourable member for Burke has interjected constantly. I warn him to cease.

—The Labor Party has shown, as it did at the last election and the election before that and the one before that, that it is totally out of touch with the needs, aspirations, hopes and beliefs of the Australian people. As Mr Willis said: If Labor did not win in 1980 it faced a mammoth task in rebuilding the public sector and in convincing the electorate that it should pay a higher level of tax to enable it to do so'. Well, it will never persuade the Australian people that that would be a desirable objective. The benefits of our policies are now becoming plain. We are determined that Australia will not go the way of other countries, strangled by bureaucracies, strangled by higher and higher taxes and strangled by governments which seek to make all decisions for all the people, leaving them no freedom for themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition said that the future was miserable and dispirited. Well, it is only miserable and dispirited for him and the Labor Party, because under our policies Australia can and will have and is having economic growth unparalleled in the Western world today with higher real incomes, lower taxes than the people would have had under Labor, and with 300,000 more jobs over the last two years and lower rates of inflation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. The Prime Minister has brought in the wrong speech. I have heard this one before.
—The honourable member for Hunter will resume his seat.

—If the honourable gentleman does not like the truth, that is his business. The Government's policies provide the only way in which to achieve these objectives and to provide better care for those in need. The choice is very clear between the Government and the Opposition; the philosophies are clear between us: Labor's way of big government, socialism in the extreme, higher and higher taxes, higher and higher government spending leading to stagnation, unemployment and inflation or the Government's way, which is building a great future for Australia and for all the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to reply to the statement made by the senior spokesman for the Government, as he has come to be known. Before I deal with that in detail let me dispose of some of the canards with which he opened this horrible speech that he has inflicted upon this House today. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) referred to the fact that there is a sense of confidence in every corner of this country. I wonder how many corners of this country this Prime Minister has gone to.
—Time!
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. The clock showed that the honourable member's time had expired. It has now been adjusted.

—It is no wonder that honourable members are afraid; they will get all they want in 15 minutes. I wonder how many corners of this country this Prime Minister has gone to. Has he gone to those corners of the country in which the two million people living in poverty exist? Do those people have a sense of confidence in the future of this country which is now not one nation, as I said before, but two nations? What freedom do they have to determine their future?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us put aside these hopeless assertions by this man who has created a level of two million people living in poverty in this country and come to the facts of the situation which are now before this Parliament. What are the facts? They are simply that the Prime Minister has lied to the Premiers of Australia. With his Treasurer (Mr Howard) he went into the Premiers Conference and told the Premiers unequivocally that the situation with which they were confronted was that that was the limit of the capacity of the Commonwealth Government of Australia to transfer funds under this vaunted new federalism from the Federal Government to the States to enable the States to undertake the face to face obligations of government to people, to ensure that Australians have the greatest opportunity of living a decent life. He told them that that was the limit of the capacity of this Government. Having lied to them, what happened? The nature of this man is that he is not capable of living with what he perceives to be a victory. He then, by the nature of his makeup, has to twist the knife and rub people's noses into the ground.

So what did he do. First of all he went to his highly paid man, his hatchet man, Barnett, the man who has to spend so much of his time doing this job that last year he had an overtime bill of $29,000. This man said to these spokesmen: 'Look what our clever Prime Minister and our clever Treasurer did. The Prime Minister lied to the Premiers. They could have got another $70m'. What could they have done with the $70m in terms of looking after the people of this country? But no, we have such a clever Prime Minister that he lied to the Premiers! He told them that what they got was the maximum. Mr Barnett said that what was said by the Treasurer and what was said by the Prime Minister was not the case. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer lied and then when the lies became apparent Mr Barnett was sent out to try to stand over people to try to remedy the situation.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Sinclair

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. The honourable gentleman is constantly using the work 'lie'. It is an unparliamentary term. It is inappropriate, inaccurate and it is deliberately false. It is designed to distort the argument from the valid basis on which it should be put. I submit to you, Mr Speaker, that it is an unparliamentary expression and that it should therefore be withdrawn.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the House to come to order. This is a matter which has concerned me. No honourable member is entitled to cast reflections on another honourable member unless there is a specific motion which enables him to do so. The terms of this motion are not a censure on any member of the Parliament. It is in fact a motion which condemns the Government and because of the way in which the motion is put I cannot permit personal attacks upon individual members of the House. I therefore ask the honourable member for Wills to cease using the term.

—Mr Speaker, whether deceit has been practised by this Prime Minister and this Treasurer will not necessarily be judged by the manipulated numbers in this House. A judgment on whether deception has been practised will be made by the Premiers of Australia. The Premiers of Australia will have no doubt whether deception has been practised because they were there and they were told what the limits were. Subsequently the Prime Minister told another, different story that shows that $70m which could have been made available was not made available.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us come to the canards which are told by this Prime Minister and this Government in terms of what the philosophy is which justifies their position. In terms of their concepts, they say they are not a government of big government; they are the government of lesser government. Let us look at the facts as distinct from what they put out. Between 1972-73 and 1975-76 Commonwealth Budget receipts as a proportion of gross domestic product averaged 23.9 per cent. This was during the period of the Labor Government. The percentage has grown inexorably under this Government. Between 1976-77 and 1980-81 the amount taken by the Commonwealth Government as a proportion of gross domestic product has gone up from an average of 23.9 per cent during the period of the Labor Government to 25.8 per cent.

This Government is not a government of lesser government; it is a government of less equitable government. What is the evidence of this? The evidence is clear. One should look at the Government's approach in terms of the sort of regulatory mechanism it is going to impose on this community. The Government says it is wrong to have a mechanism imposed upon industry in terms of the Prices Justification Tribunal or, in terms of the Trade Practices Commission so it either abolishes these mechanisms or emasculates them. But at the same time the Government heaps upon heap the mechanisms which it imposes in the industrial relations field to the point where the Industrial Relations Bureau, this monstrosity, is maintained-against the advice of the employers, against the advice of the trade union movement, against the advice of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and against the advice of his own Minister who has just resigned because he could not stand the stench of this Government. This is the living proof that this is not a government committed to smaller or lesser government. As I said before, it is a government which can be properly described only as a government of the privileged, by the privileged and for the privileged.

What do we find in terms of this new federalism? We are told by the Prime Minister that it will create a new co-operative relationship with the States. In fact, what has happened under the Prime Minister is that we have reached a situation where he will not make all that is available from Commonwealth revenues to the States. He gives them misguided information. In fact, the situation has been reached where this morning the Premier of Queensland described the action of the Prime Minister as malicious and misleading. Why does the Premier of Queensland say this about the Prime Minister? The reason is that the Government says one thing and practises another. Has the Prime Minister in any way attempted to meet the charges made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen)? There is no way in which that has been done. Has the Prime Minister met the charge? This is the crucial and critical point.

The charge is that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have deliberately misled the Premiers of the States on basic issues regarding federalism on what moneys will be available to provide services to the people of this country. As a result of that misleading, the Premiers have departed from the presence of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer and returned to their States. They are currently undertaking an examination of what additional taxes and imposts they will have to place upon the people of Australia to continue to provide services which will enable people to lead decent lives. I ask: Can a more fundamental charge be made against the morality and integrity of a government? This is a government which on one hand says there must be honesty and truth in relations and then on the other hand enters into negotiations in which it is not prepared to tell the truth in regard to these fundamental matters which determine how the economy of this country will operate and how the welfare of its people will be determined.

Is it any wonder that what we are witnessing today is a disintegration of government? The sacrifices being made under this Government are not sacrifices by the Prime Minister but sacrifices which he has imposed on others. The back benchs of this Parliament and the chanceries of this world are littered with those people sacrificed by the Prime Minister. They have been sacrificed because, as has been said, he is possessed of a manic determination to get his own way.

TALK.START.PARA: —No Country Party members have been sacrificed.

—No Country Party members have been sacrificed. Of course it is one rule for poor subservient members of the Liberal Party. They must toe the line. If in any way they try to express an opinion they are for the high jump. If the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) pre-empts a Cabinet decision about Trans-Australia Airlines that, of course, is all right. If the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) wants to say something about what should happen there is no question of control applying to leading members of the National Country Party; they are immune. Why are they immune? They are immune because they represent to the Prime Minister a manifestation of his conception of what this country should be about.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, it is a concept, as I said, of two classes of people-the privileged who will have their privileges maintained and increased, and against that an increasing number of people whose opportunity for a decent life will be pressed further and further into the ground. Is it any accident that after five years of Fraserism and this sort of government there has been a doubling of the number of people living in poverty?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Is it in order for the honourable member for Hawker to be reading a newspaper while his future leader is speaking?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—We can see how worried they are when they try to consume time in that way. The fact that the number of people who are living in poverty in this country has doubled is not an accident. It is the result of the deliberate implementation of policies calculated by this Prime Minister to produce that result. It does not happen by accident. These things happen because governments do not provide services to people-they do not provide services to the poor, the unemployed, the underprivileged, the Aboriginals and the people who depend on legal aid. Those sorts of things come about only because governments provide them, but State governments can provide them only if they are provided with the maximum amount of money which will enable them to do these things and if the Federal Government has its priorities right.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the first element, we have seen this week-it stands unrefuted by the statement of the Prime Minister-the situation in which the Prime Minister has not told the truth, in which he has withheld the money from the States. That is money which, under the management of this Federal Government, will not be used to do the jobs which need to be done in order, as the Prime Minister said in opening his speech, to give a sense of confidence in every corner of this country. If we are to look after the people of this country, economic management has to be carried out in a way that produces that result.

Let us finally nail this misrepresentation that under the economic management of the Prime Minister and this Government we have produced marvellous results. Very simply, the fact is that in the period of this Government the economic performance of Australia vis-a-vis the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, has been significantly worse in terms of growth and in terms of inflation. The facts are on record. The average rate of growth in Australia in the period 1976 to 1979 was 2.8 per cent. That was the performance in this country. What was the OECD average? It was 4 per cent. The figure was significantly less in this country than in the OECD. What was the inflation performance? Inflation in Australia was 11 per cent and the OECD average was 8.5 per cent. So, in the period 1976 to 1979 the Government failed in terms of growth performance and it failed in terms of inflation performance. It has produced that result because of this concept that it will not deal honestly with the economics of this country. At this Government's level of control it does not deal honestly; but, it has reached the bottom of the barrel now when it lies and tells untruths and deceives its own kind. It deceived Liberal Premiers. It deceived Sir Charles Court and it deceived Bjelke-Petersen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like in the first part of my remarks to deal with what I believe to be the central issue in this debate and, most particularly, the central issue of the events of the past 48 hours. That is the proposition that in some way the Commonwealth Government has robbed the States of approximately $70m. It is a charge that I can understand. I can understand why it has been made in the circumstances of the past 48 hours but during this debate, because I regard that issue as being absolutely crucial to the credibility of what has been said by the Opposition and to the merits of this debate, I want to examine the approach of the Commonwealth to the Premiers Conference in its proper perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: All of us know-none better than people who sit on the Opposition front benches-that in any discussion or in negotiation the people negotiating on behalf of the parties have a certain capacity and a certain flexibility. They are not sent to the negotiating table with one, and one only, instruction. They are given guidance. They are told what is the ambit of their authority and are given guidance as to what they should do. The truth is that the Federal Cabinet gave to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and me, as the Cabinet has done on the occasion of earlier Premiers Conferences, authority to make a decision on the day of the Conference as to the final amount that should be given. That fact cannot be stressed too much. We were not told, when the Cabinet took its decision, that we had to give the States the same in real terms plus absorption. We were told that under no circumstances should we go beyond that figure, that we should make an assessment on the day in the light of economic circumstances and budgetary considerations as to the appropriate amount. For it to be suggested in those circumstances that we have in some way robbed the States and that we have in some way deceived them is totally to misrepresent and to misunderstand the nature of a conference such as this. It is a total misunderstanding of the nature of Cabinet giving to Ministers a general authority and a total misunderstanding of what happened on the day of that Conference.

As I have already indicated, at that Conference negotiations started on the basis of there being an offer by the Commonwealth of 8 per cent plus absorption. After very lengthy discussion that figure was increased by an amount of approximately $27m as a result of a decision on the part of the Commonwealth-a decision which was taken by the Prime Minister and me in consultation with the other five Ministers who were present at the Conference. That decision was to increase the amount by $27m by providing to the States of South Australia, Tasmania and Victoria a sufficient additional supplement so that their total increase would not be less than 8 per cent, thus increasing the overall amount to about 8 1/4 per cent.

After dinner and after lengthy discussion between the seven Commonwealth Ministers, it was decided to increase the amount. I repeat that that decision was taken only after that lengthy discussion. It was not a unanimous discussion. As everyone would expect, differing points of view were expressed in this discussion. It was decided to increase that amount to 9 per cent plus absorption. I regard that as an entirely proper, predictable and justifiable procedure for the Commonwealth to take at a conference such as this. To suggest that this is a procedure that in some way robs the States, deceives the States and is in some way dishonourable on the part of the Commonwealth is to misunderstand the nature of these types of negotiations.

We indicated very clearly throughout the entirety of the Conference just precisely what our position was. Therefore, I want to emphasise as powerfully as I can that the proposition that in some way the States have been robbed of $70m is a proposition without substance. We are not, as the Prime Minister and others have said during this debate, talking about whether it is the States' money or the Commonwealth's money. We are talking about it being the money of the taxpayers of Australia. We were given authority by our Cabinet colleagues. We were not given a direction. The central thing about the Cabinet authority that was given to the Prime Minister and me-it has to be repeated again and again-was that a decision as to the final amount to be offered to the States should be made at the Conference in the light of budgetary and economic circumstances that existed at the time. That was the decision that was taken by the seven Commonwealth Ministers who were present at the Conference, including the Prime Minister and me.

We have heard a great deal over recent years from many Premiers around Australia that the problem with Premiers Conferences is that the Commonwealth goes to them with a fixed position, that the Commonwealth is not prepared to move and is not prepared to listen to argument. They suggest that we might as well send the Premiers a letter or a telex with the result. It has been suggested that the Conferences at no stage evince any Cabinet flexibility or willingness to move. On this occasion we demonstrated a flexibility. We demonstrated a capacity to move. We demonstrated a willingness to listen to argument. In those circumstances, for it to be suggested around Australia now by Premiers on both sides of the fence that in some way we have not handled this thing properly is a complete misunderstanding of the situation. In reality, what we have done is to conduct a negotiation in the manner that has been urged upon us time and again by the Premiers all around Australia. I find that an odd circumstance. I find it an odd charge and I find it a complete misunderstanding of the nature of the Premiers Conferences. We negotiated within our mandate. We were not given--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth will never have a negotiating position again.
—I warn the honourable member for Corio. The House will come to order. I am not prepared to allow this continual noise. When an honourable member has the call he is entitled to be heard.

—We were not given an instruction to give that additional $70m. For it to be suggested that the States have been in any way robbed of that money is a complete distortion of the circumstance and a complete misunderstanding of the nature of Premiers Conferences. Throughout the course of this debate criticism has been made of the federalism policies of this Government. Let me remind the House and in particular the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) that when the tax sharing arrangements were first negotiated in 1976 it was always contemplated that there would be a review of those tax sharing arrangements after they had been in operation for a number of years. There was never any commitment that the arrangements made then would be continued in perpetuity to the letter. To suggest otherwise is to misread the nature of those arrangements and the proposition that was entered into at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I reject charges that the Commonwealth has abrogated the arrangement made in 1976. We have not abrogated the arrangement made in 1976. The States wanted a review of the tax sharing arrangements as much as the Commonwealth did. No Premier was more vocal than the Premier of New South Wales in wanting a review of the tax sharing arrangments. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition ought to know that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Sir Charles Court?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—Mr Speaker--

—The Treasurer will resume his seat. I remind the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that he spoke to the motion which is before the House. He seconded the motion. I ask him now to hear the speaker from the other side.

—During this debate the Opposition has talked a great deal about economic conditions in Australia. In my concluding moments I would like to say a few things about economic conditions in Australia. I remind the House that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden), the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Wills spent most of their speeches talking about economic conditions in Australia. I point out to the House how absurd it is for those gentlemen to talk in those terms in the face of the economic performance of this country at the present time. Let us talk about the growth rates of Australia compared with those of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. Let us talk about the fact that non-farm product in this country is rising by about 4 per cent this year against a Budget prediction of 3 1/2 per cent. Let us talk about the fact that fixed private sector capital investment will rise by about 20 per cent in real terms this financial year. Let us talk about the fact that this country is the envy of the industrialised world so far as overseas investment is concerned. Let us talk about the fact that the inflation rate of this country is significantly below the average of the industrialised world. Let us talk about the fact that businessmen all around Australia have renewed confidence and expectations about the economic future of Australia. Finally--
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. Let us talk about the leak.
—There is no point of order.

—Finally, as the hour approaches 12 o'clock and the time comes for me to conclude my remarks, let us talk about the unemployment figures that will become public in five minutes time. The figures will show the best performance in the area of unemployment for many years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—The right honourable gentleman claims to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, Mr Speaker.
—He may proceed.
—The Sydney Morning Herald of 4 May made the following comment:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Ian Sinclair is refusing to put on oath his denial that he knew Australia continued to breach an international trade agreement by selling cheap milk powder.

On 27 February 1981 I received a letter from Senator Peter Rae, Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, in which he set down particulars of some evidence received by that Committee and asked for my comments on it. I responded to that letter on 16 March and then on 22 April 1981. I further reponded in the following way:
Dear Senator Rae,
The letter under your hand as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations dated 25th March, 1981, has been received.
My response to your earlier correspondence of the 16th March, 1981, was written as a Minister in accordance with the several Oaths taken relating to that office.
My comments were based on my own recollection and supported by Departmental records and my Ministerial diaries.

In my letter of 16 March 1981 I set down in considerable detail my response to Senator Rae's letter which was dated 27 February 1981. As my letter stated, the detail was in accordance with my own recollection and was written as a Minister of the Crown. I have now received a further letter from Senator Rae dated 6 May 1981 in which he comments, inter alia:
Nevertheless, we are left with the dilemma that sworn evidence was given to the Committee which is contradicted only by an unsworn letter from you.

In your letter dated 22 April 1981 you stated the written evidence you gave to the Committee by letter dated 16 March 1981 was given as a 'Minister in accordance with the several Oaths taken relating to that office'.
From our examination of the oaths taken by Ministers we are unable to see any declaration that would place written evidence given by a Minister on the same basis as sworn evidence.

I do not believe it appropriate that a Minister of this House should appear and give sworn evidence before a committee of the other House. Therefore, I make this statement with respect to the evidence that I have tendered to that Committee in the Parliament and, of course, in accordance with my responsibilities to this Parliament. I believe that is the correct and proper form by which I can respond to the honourable senator. I assert to that honourable gentleman and to the members of the Senate Committee that I believe the evidence given to them is totally correct and has the substance of my being a Minister and giving it in this place. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence. I do not wish to cast any reflection upon the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair). Often it is very difficult for Senate committees to understand that they cannot get evidence from Ministers of the Crown. It would be in the interests of the Parliament and the Minister if he made a statement indicating where the evidence given is in conflict and why. Then everybody in both Houses would know the position.

—No doubt that proposal has been heard by the right honourable gentleman. I granted him indulgence to make a personal explanation. He stated why he did not make a statutory declaration. My ruling is that that ends that matter. I have no doubt that the points raised by the honourable gentleman would have been heard by the right honourable gentleman.
