SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MACPHEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I take this opportunity to report to the House on discussions with State and Northern Territory Ministers about the eligibility for the franchise of new settlers. This matter has been discussed among Ministers responsible for immigration and ethnic affairs matters regularly for the past two years or so. At our last meeting which was held on 14 and 15 April 1981 agreement was reached on the following:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Migrants, irrespective of their country of origin should be treated equally in relation to requirements to enrol, on their right to vote at elections for parliament and to nominate as a candidate for election to parliament;
(2) Australian citizenship is the appropriate basis for the franchise;
(3) No person currently enrolled as an elector should be disenfranchised;
(4) Uniform legislation to give effect to the foregoing should be enacted by the Commonwealth and all States.
In addition, all Ministers agreed that it would be appropriate to introduce the new arrangements from 1 January 1982 but this is subject to confirmation by respective governments.

Honourable members will be aware that under existing legislation British subjects may enrol and vote after six months residence in Australia whereas other migrants must attain Australian citizenship-involving a minimum residence period of three years-before they are entitled to enrol and vote. In the interests of clarity, it should be noted that the term 'British subject' includes citizens of most former British colonies. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list of 42 countries whose citizens are British subjects and entitled to vote under existing laws after six months residence in Australia. Honourable members will note that the list runs from the Bahamas and Bangladesh to Zambia and Zimbabwe. Of course, some former British colonies removed themselves from the Commonwealth and their people from British subject status but the majority remained and retained that status.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
List of countries to which the status of British subject is applied under the Australian Citizenship ACT:

Bahamas; Bangladesh; Barbados; Botswana; Canada; Cyprus; Dominica; Fiji; The Gambia; Ghana; Grenada; Guyana; India; Jamaica; Kenya; Kiribati; Lesotho; Malawi; Malaysia; Malta; Mauritius; Nauru; New Zealand; Nigeria; Papua New Guinea; Saint Lucia; Saint Vincent; Seychelles; Siera Leone; Singapore; Solomon Islands; Sri Lanka; Swaziland; Tanzania; Tonga; Trinidad and Tobago; Tuvalu; Uganda; United Kingdom and Colonies; Western Samoa; Zambia and Zimbabwe.

TALK.START.PARA: —The removal of the anomaly between British subjects and other migrants was recommended by the Report of the Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services for Migrants more widely known as the Galbally report. When this report was tabled in the Parliament in May 1978 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced the Government's acceptance of all of its recommendations. The report in this respect stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We observe that while migrants who are British subjects are eligible to vote after residence in Australia for six months, non-British migrants must become citizens by naturalisation before they are eligible to vote in Federal elections. We recommend that anomalies in voting rights be resolved and that all migrants be placed on an equal footing in their voting rights.

Following the Galbally report an interdepartmental committee examined and reported on voting rights. After examination of that report by Cabinet I discussed this question with my State and Territory counterparts at a conference of Ministers in Darwin in 1980. It was agreed at that conference that Ministers would seek the reactions of their respective Cabinets and report back at the next conference which was held in April 1981. At that conference last month, Ministers expressed strong support for the changes I have just foreshadowed. I emphasise that the changes will not, of themselves, confer a right to vote upon any further categories of people. The only group of migrants affected by the changes will be British subjects-that is people who are not Australian citizens-who have not enrolled before the end of 1981. In future, British subjects will not be entitled to enrol unless they become Australian citizens. I should also emphasise that the changes will not disenfranchise anyone.

After 1 January 1982 or such other date as the governments might decide all persons currently enrolled will be obliged by law to remain on the electoral rolls and to vote at elections. However, after that date, of those persons not enrolled, only Australian citizens will be entitled and required to enrol and vote. One of the options considered by Ministers was that British subjects already enrolled should be permitted to take themselves off the roll. Ministers decided that this option should not be adopted. As a consequence, compulsory enrolment and voting will continue for all those who are now on the roll and who will in future be eligible to be on the roll. The introduction of these changes will constitute a further milestone in the social and political development of Australia. The changes reflect the cultural diversity of modern Australia and its independent identity.

The term British subject is included in many Commonwealth and State Acts, apart from electoral legislation. I am informed that it is now used only by the United Kingdom and Australia and that the United Kingdom is moving to adopt other approaches. It is fitting, therefore, that Australian legislation be re-examined as well. In most countries, the primary condition for obtaining the franchise is citizenship. Comparison with other countries, however, should not be taken too far because Australian law obliges all eligible voters to enrol and to vote. This is not the situation in many countries.

Australia's franchise for British subjects without citizenship is associated with our origins as a series of British colonies. Indeed, before 26 January 1949 when Australian citizenship was introduced all Australians were British subjects. That term described a common or shared status of citizenship of the Commonwealth of Nations. In the 1940s, each of these nations introduced its own citizenship but retained strong links with other Commonwealth nations by granting each of its citizens the status of a British subject. In Australia citizenship itself was more readily available to British subjects than to other settlers until 1973. Since then, all settlers have had to satisfy the same residence requirement for citizenship. We are now taking the next step and placing the franchise on an equal footing.

The most fundamental reflection of commitment to the nation is citizenship. The most fundamental expression of citizenship is the right to elect those who govern the nation. Against that background it is of interest to consider some statistics. As at 30 June 1979 it was estimated that about 2.6 million overseas-born residents of Australia had periods of residence greater than the three years necessary to apply for citizenship. In fact only 1.4 million-about half-had become citizens. When we study the 1.2 million who had residentially qualified to apply but had not become citizens, we find the British subject group comprised almost 70 per cent of the residentially-qualified non-citizens. Analysis of the period of residence in Australia also reveals a noteworthy pattern. Of the migrants born in the United Kingdom, including the Republic of Ireland, who had not taken citizenship, about 60 per cent had lived in Australia for more than 4 years; about 36 per cent had lived in here for 10 or more years; and about 13 per cent had lived here for 22 years or more. It is for these sorts of reasons that a study has been made of the Citizenship Act and of policies, practices and procedures associated with citizenship. When the results of those studies have been fully evaluated, further anomalies will be removed.
In foreshadowing legislation to vary the entitlement of future migrants to enrol and to vote, I emphasise two things:

Firstly, all Australian residents who believe they qualify for Australian citizenship should enquire at the nearest office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs or lodge an application; and, secondly, British subjects who believe they are entitled to enrol on the Commonwealth Electoral Roll should enquire at or make application to the Australian Electoral Office before the end of 1981. I commend this decision to the House. I present the following paper:
Voting Rights for Migrants-Ministerial Statement, 7 May 1981.
Motion (by Mr Fife) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition, as is warranted, treats the announcement by the Government with the seriousness that it deserves. We see the ramifications of the change and it is to be hoped that the changes enunciated by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) do not in any way offend those people already living in Australia. I think everyone in this country would agree that all people coming to live in Australia should be treated in exactly the same way. Whilst the Galbally Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services to Migrants may have recommended along those lines I do not know that it went as far as to say that citizenship ought to be the basis for the franchise. Nonetheless, that is a stand which the Australian Labor Party takes at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out at the outset that the policy put forward at the election in October last year by the Labor Party, expressed by my colleagues the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Dr Cass) who was then the shadow Minister and by the leader of the Labor Party was that all migrants, irrespective of where they come from, should have citizenship for the purposes of the franchise but that the period after which they would become eligible to make application for citizenship should be reduced from three years to one year. I make it quite clear that in respect of the statement made by the Minister the Opposition has not changed its mind. The Opposition believes it is right that all migrants should be treated equally. In this case that means people coming from any one of the 42 British and so-called former British areas or from the United Kingdom itself should now have citizenship as the basis for the franchise. This is the same burden as that carried by migrants from other parts of the world.

We in the Opposition see no major substantive argument for leaving the set period at three years. Indeed, according to the figures given by the Minister it appears that the period stipulated does not seem to make much difference to the migrants themselves. Those people who do not wish to take out citizenship do not seem to have been affected by the reduction from five years to three years. It may be the case that they will not be affected by a reduction in the period from three years to one year. Whilst it is the overwhelming view of the Labor Party at the moment that citizenship ought to be the basis for the franchise-certainly, it is a view I hold very strongly at a personal level-it is not a view that goes unchallenged. As honourable members would be aware, views have been expressed by some members of the New South Wales Labor Party committee on ethnic affairs-although action has not been taken by the New South Wales Government-that a mere 12 months residency should be the basis for a person's being allowed to vote in this country. People from other parts of Australia hold similar views. It may be that there are people in the Government parties who hold such views.

At the moment the policy we put forward at the last election stands as far as the Labor Party is concerned. If the Government has a substantive reason for continuing with the three-year residency period then such a reason is certainly not to be found in the Minister's statement. We cannot find any argument why that three-year period remains. I think it is quite a change not only to say to people who might be described as British subjects that in the future 'You will have to take out citizenship' but also to say 'The period to which the change relates will increase from six months to three years'. Again it seems to me that it would have been better to compromise the time period with that citizenship commitment. Perhaps the residency period then could have been reduced quite substantially. Certainly, a Labor government would look very closely, as soon as it came to office, at reducing the period for all people, not just British subjects, in terms of applications for citizenship in this country. I make those points in relation to where we stand.

I think it is also important to say in relation to the measure that agreement with the States, of course, has been sought but that again there are varying views within the States as to what they want to do. It is not just the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that is affected; the electoral laws of the States and Commonwealth will have to be changed. It is to be hoped that the States will follow suit. As I said earlier, New South Wales-the largest of the States in terms of population-is looking closely at residency as the basis for the voting right. Again, we will have to be cognisant if the States after the change is implemented this year move to liberalise the opportunity for people to be placed on the electoral roll.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2.15 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to conclude my remarks because there is an arrangement-I am thankful to the Government for it-that if I reduce my period of speaking to the House then the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent), the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) and the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) can say a few words about their experiences in this field. Between them, they have had a great deal of experience. In support of this question of dealing with all migrants equally, I reiterate what the Labor Party had to say at its conferences in 1979 and 1980. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . 'there shall be no distinction between Australian citizens whether born in Australia or overseas in legal, social and political rights' . . . 'a Labor Government will amend all Federal Acts to specify ''Australian citizen'' wherever the term ''British subject'' appears . . .'
I will say a little bit more about that later. It continued:
'At the same time, the existing rights of British subjects already living in Australia would be preserved'.
The Labor Party policy states:

A Labor Government will grant citizenship to all permanent Australian residents of good character (who apply for it), after 12 months continuous residence in this country. These provisions will apply to all immigrants coming to Australia whether from the Commonwealth or not. British subjects already in Australia at the time of proclamation of the Act will preserve their existing privileges. However, they will be encouraged to become Australian citizens.
All immigrants arriving after the legislation relating to citizenship is introduced will be treated equally, without any prejudice to their country of birth, colour or religion.

It is quite clear to the House from that statement that the Labor Party is in accord with the equality of treatment which as a result of this statement of the Minister of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is to be given to all people who come to Australia to make it their home. I reiterate that it is important to encourage as many people as possible who are now eligible to go on the electoral roll to do so before January 1982, because after that time they will face a far more difficult hurdle. I would like also to reiterate that we see no substantive reason for the Government maintaining the three-year qualifying period, and on coming to office a Labor Government would immediately review that period with a determination to reduce it to 12 months.

Whilst in the Minister's statement some mention was made of the term 'British subject' appearing in Acts of Parliament, it ought to be made even clearer that the term 'British subject' appears in no fewer than 75 Acts of this Parliament. That situation ought to be looked at and dealt with quickly. It appears in Acts such as the Atomic Energy Act, the Australian Coastal Shipping Commission Act, the Australian Institute of Marine Science Act, the Australian National Airlines Act, the Broadcasting and Television Act, the Christmas Island Act, the Commonwealth Banks Act, the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, the Commonwealth Police Act 1957, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Act 1961 and the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act 1972. If the Minister is determined, as he says in his speech, to do something about it-as is the United Kingdom-then it ought to be done as soon as possible to clean up the discrimination which is now very much a part of the legislation in the way in which it has been framed by this Parliament.

The Opposition gives enthusiastic support to the treatment which in future will flow from this statement whereby all who come to make Australia their home will be treated equally, irrespective of where they come from. We do say that the qualifying period should have been looked at more closely by the Government. We think there is a case for shortening that period to closer to the six months which was previously necessary for all British subjects rather than extending it to three years, which was the period applicable to all other migrants. In that respect we say that upon becoming the Government we will be looking at reducing the period to 12 months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating a statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) on the subject of voting rights for migrants. The Minister, in his statement, outlined decisions which were being taken following consultations on 14 and 15 April between himself and State Ministers responsible for immigration and ethnic affairs. The Minister outlined that agreement was reached at that meeting on the following propositions:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Migrants, irrespective of their country of origin should be treated equally in relation to requirements to enrol, on their right to vote at elections for parliament and to nominate as a candidate for election to parliament;
(2) Australian citizenship is the appropriate basis for the franchise;

I note that the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) on behalf of the Opposition has expressed support for the changes which are to be introduced, although he has done so in a somewhat qualified way in that he has suggested that a Labor government would want to review the period of residence which qualified people for citizenship. It is of interest to note that he did not say a Labor government would reduce the period required for citizenship. He left it very open by saying that it would 'look very closely' at the period for citizenship. I suggest to the House that it is all very well for Labor spokesmen in Opposition to suggest that they would look at that period and lead people to believe that there is a strong prospect that they would reduce the residential period for citizenship. However, it is interesting and instructive to note that Labor parties in government have agreed with the present period. The communique from the conference of Ministers responsible for immigration and ethnic affairs held on 14 and 15 April stated:

The Conference expressed strong support for adopting a uniform Australia-wide qualification for voting rights based on Australian citizenship. Citizenship is available to all people after three years' residence. People already enrolled will have their existing rights preserved. Ministers agreed to work toward introducing this change by 1 January 1982 although some States face technical problems which will first need to be resolved.
So, State and Commonwealth governments of whatever political complexion agreed that these changes based on the present period of three years residence should be introduced.

I suppose it would be fair to say that any period of residence required for citizenship is to some extent an arbitrary one and it might be subject to some adjustment one way or another. I suggest to the House that something like the present period of three years is a logical and appropriate period rather than, say, a marked reduction to one year. There is a need to ensure that people who vote in our national and State elections have a commitment to Australia. The Minister said in his statement to the House:
The most fundamental reflection of commitment to the nation is citizenship. The most fundamental expression of citizenship is the right to elect those who govern the nation.

The pattern of immigration in the past indicates that a number of people came to this country under assisted migration programs from the United Kingdom and from other countries in the 1950s and 1960s and it was not uncommon for a number of those people to stay for, say, two years and then go back to their country of origin. Certainly they completed the requirements to qualify for their assisted passage but their attitude of mind was that it was something of a working holiday, or maybe in other cases people felt that they wanted to come to Australia but after arriving and living here for a while felt they had no long term commitment to the country. That became obvious only after a couple of years. Therefore, I suggest that any substantial reduction in the present period of residence required for the taking out of citizenship would not be in the best interests of this country and would not be in the best interests of the migrants who want to make Australia their home for the rest of their lives.

I commend the Minister's statement to the House. I look forward to some bipartisan support on this matter and I hope that the Labor Party in Opposition will not seek to use the opportunity to curry support with migrant groups on the basis of suggestions that the Labor Party in government has not been prepared to carry out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am honoured to follow my colleague on this side of the House, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young), into the debate on the statement of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee). May I say also that I have some practical experience in the matters the Minister mentioned as I was disenfranchised myself for more than five years after my arrival in Australia. I ask the honourable member for Casey (Mr Falconer), whose Government was practising the disenfranchising of migrants for five years until we came into office in 1972 and reduced that period to three years, how he would support that proposition? On the one hand, he talked about waiting for three years, but under his Government the franchise was given to many migrants six months after arrival in this country. I cannot reconcile one attitude with the other.

SPEECH.PARA: In our recent history we have pursued policies to attract migrants as settlers. Therefore, it is our responsibility to assist migrants in the difficult task of settlement and to make sure that they share equal rights, opportunities and duties, as do all Australians. I agree with the Minister when he stated:

Migrants, irrespective of their country of origin should be treated equally in relation to requirements to enrol, on their right to vote at elections for Parliament and to nominate as a candidate for election to Parliament.

The Minister's way of achieving equality differs somewhat from mine. The proposal that settlers from the British Commonwealth should take out Australian citizenship in itself is not opposed. However, the requirement of three years residence before one can apply for citizenship is the key to our opposition. By disenfranchising British settlers for three years we do not help anybody. It is not the way to go about introducing equality. This Government knows how to pervert facts to cover up its intentions. Let me mention only that it is toying with the idea of lifting the retiring age of women to 65 years, under the guise of equality, instead of reducing the male pensionable age to 60 for those who wish to retire early. Equality and equal treatment is not achieved by pulling everybody into the mud but by lifting up those who are not treated fairly. After all, equal pay for women does not mean lowering the male pay but improving the pay of women are discriminated against.

The proposal of my colleague the honourable member for Port Adelaide that all settlers be extended the privilege of becoming Australian citizens after 12 months residence, which is Labor's policy, is a much fairer approach to this question and a much more equitable solution. But even that in itself will not eliminate discrimination unless we accept the policy of the Australian Labor Party and remove the requirement that an applicant for citizenship has to demonstrate an adequate knowledge of the English language. Such a requirement, of which our racist bureaucrats in the Minister's Department are so fond, certainly discriminates against migrants from non-English speaking countries. I hope that the Minister will ask his Party to accept our policy on this matter.

The Minister also mentioned in his statement that 1.2 million migrants who qualified residentially have failed to take out Australian citizenship, and he said that 70 per cent of them are British subjects. I do not think that by disenfranchising them in the future the Government will force them to become citizens. After all, there are approximately 400,000 migrants of non-British background who also have not taken out citizenship. I believe it is known to the Minister that many migrants are reluctant to go through the citizenship ceremony as it is a humiliating procedure, especially in regard to the oath. The requirement for renunciation of their old country is painful to them.

I thank the Minister for the arrangement that allowed me to speak in this debate. A couple of my colleagues also want to say a few words, so I will not extend my remarks. However, I mention to the Minister that the Victorian Minister of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Kennett, is working on an alteration of the citizenship rules to cut out the requirement for migrants to renounce allegiance to their old country. I hope that the Minister will take notice of that and will assist the Victorian Minister of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to alter the wording of the oath and to make the ceremonies more simple and more acceptable to those people who have not taken out citizenship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I represent a portion of the Illawarra region of New South Wales which has one of the greatest concentrations of migrant communities. I also have a name which clearly is not an Anglo-Saxon name, and in fact I was the first member of my family to be born in this country. I speak, therefore, with some feeling about the necessity for migrants who come to Australia to recognise their need to have a real determination to become Australian citizens before doing so. I support what the honourable member for Casey (Mr Falconer) said on this matter. In particular, I want to say that I reject entirely the proposition that a naturalisation ceremony should be described as a humiliating experience, and I was most disappointed to hear the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent), describe it as such. I hope that the tone set by the honourable member is not one that will be maintained in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that in setting a period of three years as the proper limit before one is entitled to become an Australian citizen and therefore to vote in elections, the Australian Government has followed a principle that is accepted throughout the world, with the exception of New Zealand, where a slightly different situation exists. Honourable members opposite must recognise, when suggesting that this period should be reduced to one year, that the countries from which all our migrants come specify a period of residency of at least three years as their basic requirement before allowing people to become citizens. Every one of these major sources of our migrants has a rule that the Opposition says should not exist in Australia. For example, in Australia the period is 10 years; in Germany 10 years; in Greece eight years; in Italy five years; in Holland five years--

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't need migrants.
—The babble opposite indicate that those countries are not inviting migrants. Let me say that in the major migrant receiving--
—They are countries people migrate from.
—I wish that babble would cease. It is such a pest.
—Order! The honourable member for Hotham will remain silent.

—He has had one go which was incomprehensible. I wish he would not keep going now. Amongst the major migrant receiving nations of the world, Canada has a basic residence requirement of three out of the preceding four years. The United Kingdom requires five years, and most migrants in my area come from the United Kingdom. A period of five years residence is required in Britain before a person is entitled to take out citizenship. In the United States of America it is five years. Those are the world's largest countries in terms of receiving migrants. We are not even matching them. In our generous approach to migrants, after three years, instead of five or ten or all the other periods I mentioned, they can become Australian citizens in what the honourable member for Hotham has described as a humiliating ceremony, a humiliating experience. I suggest that the Government deserves support from the migrant communities for taking a very generous view, in world terms, of the amount of time people should stay before being allowed to vote and to become Australian citizens. I am overjoyed to see that the Government is now removing the anomaly by which some people who were British subjects did not have to become Australian citizens before being entitled to vote. I believe it is right that the franchise should be given to Australian citizens and to no other people, except those who have already qualified for the franchise, of course. I support the view that there should be no retrospective action. I think that the Government has done the right thing in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make one final point. It seems to me to be absolutely vital that the Government should protect the citizens of Australia by providing a reasonable time such as three years before migrants become eligible for citizenship. It is possible that, as a result of some error, some people who come to Australia may well not be desirable residents, as is shown by the level of the deportations. The waiting period of three years will protect this country from the very few migrants who come to Australia who are not desirable residents and who prove that by committing offences.

I support wholeheartedly the Minister's statement. Its contents were agreed to by all the States, I think, including the Labor States. That is why I suggest that it is disappointing to see in this House today an attempt to create a feeling of division on this matter by trying to appeal in a pretty base way to some small migrant groups.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say at the outset that the statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) raises more questions than it provides answers. I sincerely hope that the Minister will be able to provide those answers at a later date. I am nevertheless grateful for the opportunity to say a few words. I say initially that I agree with my colleague the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) that the problems which migrants have to face in the citizenship ceremony can be felt and understood only by those who have had to go through it. It is all right for people from the other side of the chamber to make noises but they do not know the problems which this ceremony creates for some migrants. I was not put in the position of having to renounce a previous allegiance. This is the area, I think, which needs to be looked at. I simply hope that the Minister has that in mind.

SPEECH.PARA: I will touch on some points which have been alluded to in the razor gang report. We have an indication that the administrative procedures in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs for granting citizenship will be streamlined. That is all we know, but I hope that that streamlining will provide those migrants who wish to become Australian citizens with the opportunity merely to fill in a form before a justice of peace, if that is their desire. From my own experience, working in the electorate, I have to say that the local government councils do a marvellous job when a ceremony involves a number of people. It is only the comradeship of the local government people and, perhaps, a migrant's friends that takes away some of the problems which he faces at the time of having to renounce his former country. As I said earlier, that is the reason I support the point of view of the honourable member for Hotham on the citizenship ceremony itself.

I will touch on another area which I think is very important. I hope that the Minister will take note of it. I refer to the requirement in the application for citizenship for a person to speak English. I have a constituent, a 57-year-old Greek lady, who was refused citizenship because she did not meet the necessary qualifications. I put it to the Minister and to the Government that at 57 years of age-the Government should bear in mind that this migrant has been here for seven years-the opportunity for her-indeed, her ability-to pick up the language will be quite a problem. In effect she will be being denied citizenship and the right to vote.

I draw attention to the list of countries which has been provided by the Minister. I believe that there are 42 of them. A number of countries on that list are not English-speaking countries. They include Cyprus, Fiji, Guyana, India, Jamaica and many others. Problems can be encountered by people from those countries in meeting the qualifications for voting. A major point in the Opposition's position in regard to this statement is that the Government is not giving something; it is taking away from the current position and privileges that have been afforded British subjects. They did not previously have to fulfil the new requirement that the Government has suggested. Therefore, a new restriction is to be imposed on them. Their status will be reduced. I suggest to the Minister and the Government that it would have been far better to have lifted the privileges enjoyed by other sections of our migrant population to those that have been enjoyed by migrants from the United Kingdom. This is the main thrust of the Opposition's argument.

I conclude by referring briefly to the number of cuts being implemented in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs by the razor gang. I have alluded to the citizenship procedures. The information service is to be terminated. Other roles of the Department are to be rationalised-that is a beautiful word. Adult migrant and refugee education programs will be restricted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Not only is there an agreement in relation to the time that honourable members have in which to speak but also the honourable member for Hindmarsh is raising material that is in no way covered in the statement which has been given to the Parliament today.
—The Chair is not party to any arrangement. Some latitude is given to all honourable members. I will hear the honourable member for Hindmarsh but I remind him to be relevant.

—I accept that there was an agreement in regard to time. If I had not been interrupted I would have finished my speech. I thank the Minister for making his statement. I hope that the points I have raised have been noted and will be attended to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments on the important statement that has been made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee). The statement deals with the eligibility of new settlers in Australia to vote. For a long time different tests have applied to people coming from different parts of the world. That has been a matter of some concern to migrants. That concern is certainly appreciated by me. In the past those people who came from former British colonies were able to enrol in order to vote shortly after their arrival whereas those who came from other countries were not. The Minister has made it quite clear that migrants to Australia, wherever they come from, seeking to vote in Australian elections will be able to do so on the same basis, that is, when they become citizens of Australia. I think that is a fair test.

SPEECH.PARA: There seemed to be some unanimity of view when the Opposition spokesman on this matter, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young), addressed the House. Having heard some of the other Opposition speakers one could be forgiven for believing that that is no longer the case. The Government takes the view that citizenship is the appropriate test for people to be eligible to vote. The principle matter that has been called into question by the Opposition has been the length of time it might take a person to qualify for Australian citizenship. It ought to be clearly noted that Australia provides in its 3-year eligibility test a very generous basis upon which people may seek to become Australian citizens. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) directed the attention of the House to the time it takes to acquire eligibility to apply for citizenship in other countries. That is important when we consider many of the countries whose former citizens come to Australia to settle. Quite frequently those countries set an inordinate time which people who have taken up permanent residence have to wait before they can qualify for citizenship. In relation to some of the European countries, 10 years of continuous residence is required before migrants in Austria and in the Federal Republic of Germany qualify for citizenship. In Greece-a considerable number of new Australian residents and citizens are from Greece-it is required that the people seeking Greek citizenship spend eight of the 10 years preceding the application were spent in Greece. In Italy-likewise there are many Italians who have setled in Australia-five years' residence is required.

I do not wish in any way to appear racist in the matters I am mentioning. I do not believe it applies only to European countries. For instance, in Malaysia 10 years within the 12 years preceding the application-including the one year immediately preceding the date of application-is the period for which people of that country must have been resident before they seek citizenship. I could go on. These comparisons with other parts of the world indicate that the requirements in Australia are extraordinarily generous. But one ought to ask oneself: What do the migrants want? When we look at the figures we find that on average it takes eight to nine years for people who have taken up permanent residence to apply for Australian citizenship; that is, when they exercise their own choice. I do not wish to debate this matter at length.

In case it is thought that Australia, in taking the approach that citizenship ought to be the test, is being unreasonable, let me add one other important fact. In no country, apart from New Zealand, is the test for eligibility to vote other than citizenship of that country. Of course, New Zealand with its very special relationships with countries in the Pacific region has a different basis for that. That, of course, is understood. Citizenship is the natural basis upon which eligibility to vote should be granted. Nobody would expect it to be otherwise. People should have some loyalty to the country in which they settle. I believe that is the test involved in terms of citizenship.

Some criticism has been offered of the tests for citizenship. I see nothing wrong with the test of renouncing all other allegiance. I think it is an important criterion for people taking up Australian citizenship. Imagine people claiming to be citizens of Australia in a situation, say, in the last war, in which they had come from Germany or perhaps Japan, had taken up permanent residence and were seeking Australian citizenship, but were not prepared to renounce all other allegiance in order to enjoy Australian citizenship. Is that what honourable members opposite are saying? If they are saying that these people should not renounce all other allegiance I believe they are selling Australia short. That is what is involved in the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) referred to the fact that about half of our permanent residents are not becoming Australian citizens. There are various causes for this situation, including that which was referred to by my colleagues; namely, the need to shorten the period of eligibility. It should be no more than one year. We urge the Government to consider this change seriously. However, a further factor is very important here. I believe many people are reluctant to become citizens because they do not have the whole of their family in Australia and have little hope of achieving a full family reunion under present circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment the proportion of migrants coming to Australia under the general eligibility scheme which deals with skilled workers is almost the same as that for people coming in under the scheme of family reunion. Yet many of these skilled workers have not been recruited to go to specific jobs. They have immigrated because of a general belief that there is a demand for their skills. The result is that often those entering Australia under general eligibility criteria cannot find employment for their skills and are contributing to the unemployment boom while at the same time they lack an adequate family support system.

While this is happening humane considerations are being thrown aside with respect to the family reunion scheme. Currently, this scheme is responsible for approximately 20 per cent of total settler arrivals. It is clear that this intake is far too small to accommodate many worthy cases. Whilst no statistics are kept which show what proportion of immigration applications are made in the family reunion category, experience in my own electorate and information from other honourable members whose electorates contain large numbers of migrants, strongly suggest that many applications are refused. Whilst we lack hard data as a result of the failure of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to record relevant statistics, an analysis of families of immigrant patients admitted to the psychiatric hospital in Royal Park, Victoria, showed that only one-third of those surveyed had their whole family in Australia.

If this reflects the general situation, clearly the situation is creating considerable distress for many families in Australia who are forced to live without the support of their relatives as well as for those overseas who need the support of their families in Australia. I suggest that this is an important reason why many of those migrants already here are not too keen to become Australian citizens. If more families were reunited in Australia there would be an increase in applications for citizenship.

Apart from purely humanitarian principles there is no reason to believe that immigrants settled under the family reunion scheme are any less successfully settled than those who enter under the Numerical Multifactor Assessment System. I seriously question whether the NUMAS factors are any more likely to result in successful settlement than is the experience of being reunited with, and assisted by, one's family in that complex process. Indeed, it would seem to me that many of the NUMAS factors, such as responsiveness, presentation, and initiative, are difficult and perhaps impossible to assess with any great accuracy and are probably irrelevant to the settlement process anyway. Other factors such as competence in English, education, literacy and adaptability have a distinct Anglo-Saxon bias and do not necessarily result in more successful settlement.

In the light of these observations I submit that there should be a substantial increase in family reunion migration to Australia. In the short term we should be looking at doubling the number in that category while also creating conditions which would allow for even greater numbers in future years. In pursuit of this goal I submit that all permanent residents of Australia should be able to sponsor all relatives, both dependent and independent, who wish to emigrate, with exceptions being made only on the grounds of health or character. Priority should be given to closest relatives such as brothers and sisters with a gradual move to categories such as cousins, nieces, nephews and other extended family members.

Whilst total numbers entering under the family reunion scheme would increase substantially under this proposal, the total number of migrants could remain the same or be only marginally increased. This can be achieved by the abolition of NUMAS and the substitution of a scheme which I have forwarded to the Minister in my submission to him concerning NUMAS. That scheme would ensure that only those skilled workers who have a specific job to which to go would be admitted. I believe if we move towards these changes both British subjects and other residents will be more keen to become Australian citizens, and to participate fully in Australian life-including voting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MACPHEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst several of the comments which have been made have had some relevance to the overall question of citizenship they have been fairly far removed from the statement I made. Therefore, I will dispose of those matters first before referring to those which were relevant to the statement. The honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous), who spoke last, made remarks relevant to the Numerical Multifactor Assessment System review. They will be taken into account by me in the course of preparing my recommendations to Cabinet. However, I wish to leave him with a couple of thoughts. Firstly, he said that we should have almost unlimited family reunion. I ask him to consider the level of the skills of persons and the numbers of persons who would come into Australia. He mentioned in particular that brothers and sisters should get priority. I ask him to consider, under a non-discriminatory policy, how many hundreds of thousands of people that will involve each year and whether--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I did not say 'unlimited increase'--
—Order! If the honourable member is of the view that he has been misrepresented he can raise that matter with me at a convenient time.

—I did not say 'unlimited' either. I do not wish to take up the time of the House by debating that matter. I said 'virtually' or 'almost' or some qualifying adjective. The point I am trying to make is that we can have a thorough-going review. I wish that honourable members opposite would consider the consequences of their recommendations in respect of family reunion, especially regarding the job market, the level of skills, the numbers involved, the infrastructure costs and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the honourable member for Casey (Mr Falconer) when he said that in 1975 in the last calendar of the Whitlam Government there was a net outflow from Australia of 5,000 people. That is hardly consistent with the kinds of statements now coming from the honourable member for Burke. Another matter that was ancillary to the debate was raised by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) referring to the number of Acts that might have to be changed as a consequence of this statement. In fact, I draw his attention to the fact that in my speech I said:

The term British Subject is included in many Commonwealth and State Acts, apart from electoral legislation. I am informed than it is now used only by the United Kingdom and Australia and that the United Kingdom is moving to adopt other approaches. It is fitting, therefore, that Australian legislation be re-examined as well.
It is the Government's intention to do that. I expect that the State governments will do the same.

The honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) also raised a number of matters that are being looked at in the broader context of citizenship. I thank him for the constructive comments which he made. They are being looked at currently by me. I established a task force, in fact headed by Mr Kiosoglous from South Australia, to look at aspects of the Australian Citizenship Act and that includes procedures including the questions of ceremonies. I have to say in fairness to the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) that he and I attend some ceremonies together. Not all of them are of the quality of ceremony that is, in fact, performed in Wollongong about which the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) was speaking. There is a very uneven quality in the ceremonies. I think the recommendations which I will finally put to Cabinet will take account of the comments of both the honourable member for Hotham and the honourable member for Hindmarsh. I welcome comments from both sides of the House over the next few months about the overall question of citizenship because we are planning for the Budget session major reviews to that Act. With the exception of the 1973 Whitlam Government amendments there have been no real amendments to that Act since it was introduced in 1949. It is certainly due for a major overhaul.

The point was made by several people, including the honourable member for Hindmarsh, that somehow or other this proposition is taking away the rights from British subjects. It is not doing that at all. I have gone out of my way today to stress that we are not taking away from any person any entitlement that he or she now has. We are not taking away any franchise. One could argue, I suppose, that in prospect we are taking away from future migrants who are classified in those 42 countries as being British subjects something that they might have expected to enjoy. They will be well aware of that when they migrate. If that deters them from migrating I would be very surprised. If it does, so be it.

It has been argued by the Opposition that we produce equality by lowering the requirement for everyone to the British subject requirement of six months' residency. Then a compromise was advanced to make that time 12 months. I might say that on the argument advanced by the Opposition if we do that we are still taking something away from the British subjects. We are not, in reality, doing that at all. I ask the House to consider this matter: We have a highly complex system of government in Australia. It is not uncommon for us as members of the Federal Parliament to be assailed by people at meetings and elsewhere about matters which we know are within the purview of local government or State government. Indeed, the honourable member for Hindmarsh once raised a matter at Question Time, I recall, with my colleague the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) about a matter that was fairly and squarely within the realm of a State Minister.

If it is difficult enough for people born in Australia to understand the distribution of powers under our Constitution and if it is difficult enough for them to make judgments about where responsibility lies and how votes should be cast it certainly is difficult for persons coming into Australia, especially if they do not speak English when they arrive, to be able to cast their votes in an informed fashion. Despite the efforts now being made in respect of adult migrant education I honestly believe, and the Government certainly believes, it would be irresponsible to give to people, unused for the most part to a federal structure with a bicameral legislature and a proportional representation system in the Senate, the right to vote until they really have understood the nature of the institution. Let us remember too that many of them have come from non-democratic societies.

Another point about the proposal is that it has been discussed fully by the State Ministers and me at two lengthy conferences in the past year. The State Ministers and I reached agreement in principle. We recommended to our respective Cabinets what the changes ought to be. Each of those Cabinets, including the New South Wales Cabinet, came to the view reflected in my statement to the House today. Really, the Opposition would do well to take note of the fact that the eight governments-the Federal, the Northern Territory and the six States-are in agreement about this measure. I have undertaken to the State governments that when the Electoral Act is amended or when the draft of the amendment is available I will circulate it to the States and they will be able to provide for reciprocal legislation. In 1973 the Whitlam Government introduced changes to the Australian citizenship Act and made a three-year residence requirement for everyone, British subject or not. I would have thought that should have been welcomed then as a step in the right direction. I would have thought also most honourable members would have agreed that the principal privilege of citizenship is the right to vote. Whilst it can be argued that some of the great European civilisations certainly allowed residents to be very active leaders in their communities, it can be argued that if a resident can have a commitment is it too much to ask that that resident show the commitment by becoming a citizen? The Government believes the appropriate way is that citizenship should be the basis for franchise, that citizenship is the recognition of commitment to our country.

Finally, I refer to the question of whether we are depriving anyone of any benefits. I remind the House of the statistics that I gave about the number of persons from the United Kingdom who have been here for many years and who have not taken out citizenship. Many of them may now choose to do so when they recognise that the right to vote goes with it. Other studies will be made in the course of the work of the task force on citizenship to find out why people choose not to take out citizenship. In conjunction with the States we will be conducting a citizenship awareness raising program. This is not to get jingoistic and so forth but to encourage more people to make that final commitment and take out citizenship. We have a close system of consultation with the States. Just as I have been consulting the ethnic groups with the honourable member for Port Adelaide over the review of NUMAS we are consulting the ethnic groups themselves and the State Ministers at the moment about the proposal. The State Ministers and I have agreed to meet when I have proposals to put to them about citizenship so that all aspects of the policy, procedures and possible legislative changes will be examined in conjunction with them. There is a great deal of consultation proceeding. I hope that the Opposition, having registered its view today, will reflect upon it and will seek to bring itself into line with the States, the Territory and the Federal Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Fraser Government's further abandonment of consumer interests by, among other means, the disbanding of the Prices Justification Tribunal and the reduction in the consumer protection functions of the Trade Practices Commission.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-
Motion (by Mr Macphee) put:
That the business of the day be called on.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nixon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Wool Industry Act 1972. Honourable members will recall that previous amendments which became law on 23 May 1980 provided for wool grower levies in the Market Support Fund to be progressively refunded to wool growers as the credit balance in the Fund reached agreed satisfactory levels. The Market Support Fund was established in September 1974 to provide funds to operate the Wool Reserve Price Scheme. Since that time wool growers have contributed to the Fund through a 5 per cent levy on their gross sales value of shorn wool.

The 1980 amendments to the Act were introduced after the Government acceded to strong requests from the Wool Council of Australia to revolve the Fund. The views of all sectors of the industry were canvassed at the time and not all agreed with the Council's proposals. However, contributions to the Fund are made by wool growers and it is only right that the views of growers should be given primary consideration. Revolving the Fund means that repayments will be made to the wool growers who contributed the money on a first in first out basis after the Fund has reached an agreed satisfactory level. The Act provides that the Minister for Primary Industry will, with the written agreement of the Wool Council of Australia, make a declaration specifying a period of contributions to be returned to wool growers.

The level of the Fund currently stands well above $400m. This is in excess of requirements to operate the Reserve Price Scheme and it is realistic at this stage to consider refunding levies collected during the first year of the Fund's operation. The continued collection of the 5 per cent levy will enable the Fund to be maintained at the desired level, for its primary role of market support. Development of the administrative procedures has been a complex task and has, however, revealed a number of aspects of the Act which need to be modified to remove certain difficulties and anomalies before the refund scheme is implemented. While the overall administration of the refund scheme is to be in the hands of the Australian Wool Corporation, much of the detailed work will be performed by wool brokers and wool merchants who are registered with the Commissioner of Taxation as agents for the collection of wool tax. These firms are referred to in the Act as 'registered persons'.

It is clearly undesirable for the Corporation, which does not hold the necessary wool transaction records, to be burdened with the task of making refunds to individual growers where this task could otherwise be undertaken more simply and less expensively by registered persons.

Wool growers who sold their wool to or through a registered person will normally receive their refunds through that same person; that is, the firm which collected the 5 per cent levy. The Act as it stands provides that where a registered person ceases to be registered, the Corporation will pay the refunds directly to the wool grower clients. To cater for the situation where the firm concerned has since gone out of business, it was provided that refunds to clients of that firm were to be made by the Corporation. Some firms have ceased to be registered persons for the purposes of refunds because they were absorbed in takeovers or because they became registered under a different name. It now appears that many successor firms are capable of making these refunds, but are precluded from doing so by the provisions of section 42K(7) of the Act, which requires the Wool Corporation to make refunds in situations of this nature. Again, it is undesirable that the Corporation be burdened with the cost intensive task of making refunds to individual growers where this work could be performed automatically by firms which have 'inherited' these growers as clients. Accordingly, clause 7 of this Bill amends the Act to remedy this situation.

A further proposed amendment removes an anomaly created by wool growers entering into certain types of forward selling transactions. Under the Act as it stands at present, a decision to refund 1974-75 Market Support Fund levy payments would mean that some growers who sold wool forward before shearing prior to 1974-75, and eventually paid the levy during 1974-75 after shearing, would not be eligible for a refund. Other growers, however, who sold forward in 1974-75 but did not pay the levy until the following year would be eligible for a refund in respect of 1974-75. This situation is inequitable and not consistent with the first-in-first-out principle for revolving the Fund. Clause 5 of the Bill corrects the anomaly be deeming the time of sale of wool to be that time when payment for the wool is made.

An amendment proposed by clause 4 of the Bill will enable the Corporation, and registered persons assisting the Corporation, to be reimbursed for administrative costs incurred before the formal declaration of a refund period. The Bill amends the Act to enable these costs, which could not otherwise be recouped, to be charged to the Market Support Fund.

A number of other amendments of the principal Act are considered desirable and timely and it is opportune to introduce them now. I will refer to each of them briefly. The Bill provides in clause 10 that a statement given to a wool grower claiming a refund should set out the findings of the Corporation regarding the facts of the claim as well as the reasons for the Corporation's decision. The Bill also provides for an increase in the membership, and in the quorum for a meeting, of the Australian Wool Testing Authority. (Quorum formed). Since a significant proportion of the wool clip is tested in stores controlled by private treaty merchants it is appropriate that their organisation be represented on the AWTA. Additionally, the Wool Council of Australia is of the view that, as growers pay for the bulk of wool testing, the Council should be directly represented on the Authority.

Honourable members will be aware that the Government has made a separate decision to sell the AWTA, but no time scale has yet been set. Nevertheless, it is still appropriate for the Government to provide for the Authority's continued administration. Accordingly, clause 14 of the Bill provides for representation by both the Wool Council and private treaty merchants. As a result of this amendment, all major industry organisations will be represented on the Australian Wool Testing Authority. They will thus have an input in consideration of the future sale of the Authority and a first hand association with the shaping of ongoing testing and certification of wool. Clause 16 of the Bill revises the provision regarding declaration of pecuniary interests by Corporation members. The revision is in harmony with the conclusions and recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest. All members of the Corporation are required to declare any pecuniary interests in matters being discussed or considered by a meeting of the Corporation, and for that declaration to be recorded in the minutes of the meeting. I commend the Bill to honourable members.

The purpose of this Bill is to introduce, as from 1 July 1981, charges to recoup part of the cost borne by the Commonwealth for inspecting fish for export. This is part of the government's program to recover costs of providing export inspection for certain agricultural and fishery products. Export inspection is designed to ensure that products meet minimum standards of quality, hygiene and presentation when exported. In 1979 the Government introduced charging for meat, grain and wool inspection aimed at recovering approximately 50 per cent of the inspection costs of the Commonwealth. The Government proposes that fees aimed at a similar level of recovery should be imposed for similar services provided by my Department to seafood exporters.

Turning to specifics in this Bill, honourable members will see that it provides for the recovery of fish export inspection costs to be achieved through charges on fish inspected for export and for which an export permit has been issued under the Exports (Fish) Regulations. The Bill provides that the person to whom an export permit is issued under the Exports (Fish) Regulations is liable to pay the charge. Exemptions may be provided in the regulations.

To achieve the 50 per cent cost recovery, it is proposed that the following rates be recommended to the Governor-General for promulgation by regulation; rock lobster-3.9 cents per kilogram; all other shellfish except oysters, squid, cuttlefish and octopus-2.5 cents per kilogram; all other fish except oysters in the shell or half shell-0.34 cents per kilogram; oysters in the shell or half shell-1 cent per dozen. On current estimates of fish exports for 1981-82 these rates will yield approximately $1m in a full year. I commend the Bill to honourable members.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nixon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to make possible the granting of proprietary rights, somewhat similar to a grant of patent rights, to people who breed or develop new plant varieties. Whilst this is a new area of legislation in Australia, similar type schemes are currently operating in Europe, the United Kingdom, South Africa, the United States of America, New Zealand, Japan and several other countries. The proposed Australian scheme will, on the advice of the Australian Agricultural Council, be restricted to horticultural, ornamental and other selected pasture and fodder species. The major field crops and annual pasture species will not be considered for registration under the scheme.

The scheme, as set out in the Bill, will permit a plant breeder, who has developed a new plant variety, to apply to a registration authority for the grant of a right to confer sole ownership of that variety on him. Such rights will permit plant breeders, or organisations employing plant breeders, to levy and collect royalties from people selling or producing new varieties registered under the scheme. I emphasise that the granting of a right does not imply that the variety is better than an existing one, but simply, as with other patents, that it is different.

A major advantage resulting from a plant variety rights scheme will be increased availability of new plant varieties to the Australian horticultural, agricultural and plant nursery industries, with consequential benefits to farmers and gardeners. There is evidence that, in the absence of rights, Australia has been denied access to some potentially valuable varieties of plants developed overseas. These varieties have ranged through pasture grasses, grape vines, and a number of horticultural crop and orchard plants.

Plant improvement by breeding is a long and costly process. Rights of ownership of a new variety, with royalties on sales, will compensate to some extent the costs incurred and will provide a stimulus to companies and private breeders to enter into long term breeding programs. Such additional plant breeding will complement the work being undertaken by government funded organisations.

The development of the proposed Australian plant variety rights scheme has extended over several years. It evolved through a series of technical consultations between representatives of the Commonwealth, the States, seed industry groups and the Nurserymen's Association. The legislation covering the operations of similar type schemes in other countries was also examined in detail. I add that the Australian Agricultural Council has been closely involved with the scheme since it was first proposed. The Council will have an essential and key role in the operation of the scheme and it has already contributed substantially to the principles embodied in the present Bill.
In brief these principles are:
The scheme will not have the potential to cover all plant species. It will be restricted in its scope.
Participation in the scheme will be entirely voluntary. A breeder may choose whether to release a new variety without applying for protection.

The grant of a right will be given where a new variety can be clearly distinguished by one or more important characteristics from any other variety whose existence is a matter of common knowledge. These characteristics must be capable of precise recognition and description and the variety must be homogenous and stable in it characteristics-in other words, it must remain true to its description after repeated reproduction or propagation.

Nothing in the Bill will prevent farmers or gardeners retaining seed of protected varieties for sowing of crops for sale for human and animal consumption. Protected varieties will also be freely available for research purposes and to plant breeders for use in breeding programs.
Protection of a right, once granted, will be the responsibility of the owner of the new variety, through the normal legal process.
There will be provision for appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and for the protection of the public interest.

The Act will be administered by my department in which a registrar of plant varieties will be appointed. In the initial stages, only a limited number of species will be eligible for registration. These species will be determined on the recommendation of the Australian Agricultural Council.

The whole question of plant variety rights in Australia has already aroused considerable controversy. This is not entirely surprising, as similar arguments of opposition to such schemes were put forward in the United States, Canada and other countries. Some of the arguments that have been raised in Australia are misleading and show a lack of understanding of what is intended. For instance, there have been claims that under the scheme it will be illegal to grow existing well-known varieties. That is not true. There have even been claims that plant breeders will deliberately breed disease susceptible plants that will require massive inputs of pesticides and fertilisers to survive. That is a ridiculous argument.

Other arguments do raise important issues, but these generally are not related to matters within the scope of plant variety rights schemes. For example, the preservation of plant genetic resources for use in future breeding programs is certainly important. It has been recognised as such in Australia and in other countries. Gene Banks, or seed collections, particularly for the major crops, are in existence in Australia and are expanding. The Australian Agricultural Council has under consideration ways and means of improving existing collections and establishing new ones. However, these matters are completely unrelated to plant variety rights.

One of the most common complaints is that a plant variety rights scheme may lead to takeovers of Australian seed firms by multinational chemical companies. There is no denying that take-over bids can occur in any business activity, including the seed industry. There is nothing unusual about that in a free enterprise system. I am confident, however, that if any takeovers should occur in the Australian seed industry, they will not be as a direct result of plant variety rights legislation.

Safeguards are provided for in this Bill against monopoly control that may not be in the public interest. These include powers for the registration authority to have control over licences and to ensure reasonable supplies of varieties at reasonable prices. As I have already said, species will be included only with the agreement of the Australian Agricultural Council.

Because of the need to encourage a greater understanding of the intentions of a plant variety rights scheme, the Government has decided only to introduce this Bill at the present time, and not to proceed with it further in the Parliament until the Budget session. This will allow several months for interested people and organisations to study the details of the Bill, and will in turn lead to more informed public discussion and understanding.

It should be pointed out that in introducing the Bill, the Commonwealth is primarily carrying out the wishes of the States, as expressed in Agricultural Council. The legislation, as it now stands, accords with what has been envisaged by the Council. The Council will discuss the legislation in detail at its next meeting in August, by which time it should also have before it the views of interested parties. I believe the Bill opens up prospects for encouraging development of small plant breeding firms in Australia, and therefore, an increase in the number of new plant varieties available, and improvements in the efficiency of Australian plant industries. I commend the Bill to the House.
