PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill, in terms both of its size and the range of matters it covers, may well be described as an omnibus measure to amend the income tax law. Three of the measures will give effect to policies foreshadowed in the policy speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) for the last election. These are: An immediate deduction for capital expenditure on the connection of a business property to mains electricity; a concessional deduction for the cost of insulating a taxpayer's first home; and an immediate deduction for capital expenditure on storage facilities for petroleum fuel. Also included are provisions to give effect to the decision, announced by me late last year, that tourist buses may qualify for the investment allowance with effect from 1 January 1976. The Bill also contains further amendments to the gift provisions of the income tax law, including some that will give effect to the 1980-81 Budget decision to allow deductions for gifts to certain overseas aid organisations.

Last, but by no means least in importance, the Bill proposes amendments designed to provide a counter to various forms of tax avoidance. Trust stripping, expenditure recoupment schemes and exploitation of trading stock transfer provisions and of the tax-exempt status of certain bodies are the avoidance areas covered. Extensive details of most of these changes have already been announced and, relying on that and on the detailed explanations contained in an explanatory memorandum that will be circulated to honourable members, I propose in this introductory speech to limit myself to the key points.
Cost of Connection to Mains Electricity

In this respect the Government is aiming to provide assistance to persons who, particularly in remote areas of Australia, face the often heavy cost of obtaining the facility of a mains electricity supply. Capital expenditure on connecting mains electricity, or upgrading an existing connection, to a property on which a business is carried on is to qualify for deduction in the year in which the expenditure is incurred. Qualifying expenditure will be the capital costs incurred by an owner of the property, or by a lessee or sharefarmer, in bringing the mains electricity to the point on the property where the supply authority meters consumption. The deduction will be available only where the connection or upgrading is, at least in part, to be used for business purposes in the production of assessable income.

In its present form the Bill would apply to connections or upgradings effected under contracts entered into on or after 1 October 1980. In the light of representations to the effect that this would disadvantage people in rural areas who, after having contracted for supply may have to wait a considerable period for the connection to be made, the Government has now decided that the concession should be available for connection and upgrading costs incurred on or after 1 October 1980, no matter when contracts were entered into. I shall be proposing amendments to this effect when the Bill is in Committee. I want to add that the Government is aware that some may see scope in the concession for the inflation of costs so as to benefit the utilities that supply electricity. I give notice now that any action of this kind could very well place the continued availability of the deduction in serious jeopardy.
Home Insulation Costs

This concession will provide tax assistance to people who take steps that have an effect of reducing energy consumption. It is proposed that an income tax deduction will be allowed for amounts paid by a resident taxpayer for insulating a first home. Amounts paid by a taxpayer for thermal insulation materials, and for the cost of their installation in a dwelling, are to be an allowable deduction if the dwelling is the sole or principal residence of the taxpayer in Australia. It is a further condition of the deduction that the taxpayer or, in the case of married couples, the taxpayer or his or her spouse, has not previously owned another dwelling in Australia that he or she used as a home. The deduction will be available for insulating a dwelling purchased by the taxpayer on or after 1 October 1980 as well as a dwelling constructed by the taxpayer where constuction started on or after that date. Amounts expended by eligible taxpayers for the insulation of extensions to their dwellings will qualify for the new deduction under corresponding conditions.
Fuel Storage Facilities

The third election policy initiative covered by the Bill relates to the capital cost of storage facilities for petroleum-based liquid or gaseous fuel. The Bill will authorise a deduction, by way of a 100 per cent depreciation allowance, in the income year in which the facilities are first used or installed ready for use to produce assessable income. The allowance will apply to plant in Australia used wholly and exclusively to store fuel held for use in a business as fuel or as trading stock for disposal. Ancillary plant used wholly and exclusively to convey fuel in and out of storage or to measure the amount of fuel stored will qualify. So too will the cost of installation of eligible plant qualify. Storage facilities for crude oil and other fuels being held for further processing will not qualify for the allowance nor will rail, road or shipping tankers, pipelines or containers for use in the transport of fuel. Expenditure will qualify for the allowance if it is incurred under a contract entered into on or after 1 October 1980 or, if the expenditure is on facilities constructed by the taxpayer, if construction commenced after that date. Facilities that a taxpayer acquired second hand on or after 1 October 1980 will qualify if used by the taxpayer at a site other than where they were situated at that date.
Tourist Buses

Honourable members will recall that, late last year, legislation was enacted to give effect to the Government's decision to remove the specific exclusion from the income tax investment allowance of plant for use in connection with amusement or recreation. When introducing that legislation, which applies from 1 October 1980, I announced the Government's further decision to permit tourist buses to qualify for the investment allowance as from 1 January 1976, the date of commencement of the allowance. Measures to achieve that result are in this Bill. By these measures the exclusion that applied for the period between 1 January 1976 and 30 September 1980 of plant for use in connection with amusement or recreation will be treated as not having applied in relation to tourist buses. Buses brought within the scope of the investment allowance by this amendment will, of course, remain subject to the general requirements of the investment allowance provisions. For example, the general exclusion from the allowance of cars and other light vehicles will mean that buses designed to carry fewer than nine passengers will continue to be excluded, as will buses of any size that are hired out on a 'drive-yourself' basis.
Gifts

Amendments under this head will extend the existing gift provisions of the income tax law which confer deductions for gifts of the value of $2 or more to specified funds, authorities or institutions in Australia. One extension will introduce a scheme to authorise deductions for gifts to certain public funds maintained for the relief of persons in developing countries. That proposal, which has been most warmly received, was announced in the 1980-81 Budget Speech. It was supplemented by a Ministerial statement on 18 September 1980 which listed 22 organisations that are to qualify for the concession, with effect from that date. The proposed arrangements will accommodate the decisions announced in that statement and, as well, will make provision for further additions to the list of eligible organisations and funds.

Under the legislative scheme proposed in the Bill, gifts made to a public fund established by an organisation approved for purposes of the scheme by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) may qualify for deduction. It will be necessary that the Treasurer be satisfied that a particular fund is for the relief of persons in a country that is certified by the Minister for Foreign Affairs to be a developing country. A further requirement is that the Treasurer-by notice published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette-declare the fund to be an eligible fund for purposes of the scheme. Generally, gifts to an eligible fund will be deductible from the date of the Gazette declaring its eligibility. Transitional arrangements will apply so that gifts made to a fund maintained by one of the 22 organisations nominated in the ministerial statement may qualify for deduction when made after 18 September 1980.

Other amendments will mean that gifts to the International Disaster Emergencies Committee African relief appeal will qualify for deduction when made after 30 June 1980. Further amendments will ensure that deductions are available for gifts to the IDEC Kampuchean relief appeal made after 30 June 1980 when the present authorisation of deductions was to have terminated. The Bill will also authorise deductions for gifts to the Herbert Vere Evatt Memorial Foundation made after 16 January 1981 and for gifts made after 23 December 1980 to a public fund that is established and maintained exclusively for the purpose of providing religious instruction in government schools in Australia. This later amendment places on a general basis a right of deduction now contained in the law in respect of a limited range of bodies.
Tax Avoidance

I turn now to remaining provisions of the Bill designed to deal with a variety of income tax avoidance practices. With one qualification that I shall specify later, the amendments have all been foreshadowed in announcements I made last year on 5 March, 24 June and 4 August and on 30 January this year. With the introduction of this Bill, all proposals for action against specific schemes of tax avoidance foreshadowed in announcements I have made will have been given legislative form. I also expect that, before the House rises for the winter recess, new general anti-avoidance provisions will be brought before it for consideration.
Section 36A Schemes

The Bill proposes the amendments foreshadowed in my statement of 30 January 1981. These are designed to provide a counter to tax avoidance schemes that set out to exploit the special provisions of section 36A of the income tax law that apply to changes in interests in trading stock, such as changes that occur on the formation of a partnership. This exploitation takes place under arrangements whereby a person who has, for example, some cattle about to be sold or a crop ready to be harvested, enters into a partnership with a company controlled by the promoter of the scheme. The cattle or the crop, as the case may be, is transferred to the partnership for an amount roughly equivalent to market value. However, a special right of election available under section 36A is used so that the property is treated for tax purposes as having been trans- ferred at the substantially lower tax value at which it would have been brought to account if the transfer had not taken place. The net result is that the former owner realises an amount close to market value of the property, but is taxed only on the substantially lower value.

The amendments proposed will make an election under the section ineffective where the person who disposes of an interest in relevant property receives consideration in respect of the disposal that is substantially more than the amount that might reasonably have been expected if the property had been valued at the low tax value applicable as a result of the election. The consequence of the ineffectiveness of an election in these circumstances will be that the person will be treated as having disposed of the property at its market value. Transfers made in ordinary family or commercial dealing are specifically excluded from the scope of the amendments. These amendments will apply generally to changes in ownership or interests occurring after 30 January 1981. However, consistent with action taken previously by the Government to debar the carry-forward of paper losses resulting from avoidance schemes, the Bill will ban the carry-forward from one year to another of such tax losses resulting from earlier section 36A schemes, with first effect for the income year 1980-81.
Trust Stripping Schemes

Changes that I outlined on 5 March 1980 to deal with variants of the trust stripping arrangements against which remedial legislation was enacted early in 1979 are the next matter covered by the Bill. These arrangements, which sought to free from tax altogether the trading profits and other income of trusts, commonly entailed a specially introduced nominal beneficiary being made presently entitled to income of the trust that was to be stripped. By this means, the trustee was relieved of any tax liability in respect of the trust income. The arrangements were at the same time designed so that not only did the special beneficiary escape tax, but the family from which the income was diverted received the benefit of it in a tax-free capital form.

The 1979 amendments are contained in section 100A of the Income Tax Assessment Act and operate to treat income to which a beneficiary is nominally made presently entitled under reimbursement arrangements of this type as income of the trust estate to which no beneficiary is presently entitled. The trustee is thus liable to be taxed on the income at the maximum rate of personal income tax, which for 1980-81 is 60 per cent. The variants of the trust-stripping arrangements with which this Bill deals exploit the exclusion from the 1979 amendments of income of a trust estate to which a beneficiary becomes presently entitled in the capacity of a trustee of another trust estate. That exclusion was intended to ensure that section 100A would apply only in relation to the last link in a chain of distributions through interposed trusts, thereby removing any possibility of double taxation on income as it passed through the chain.

The amendments now proposed will continue the scheme of applying section 100A to the last nominal beneficiary only, but in a way that aims to prevent the exploitation that has been experienced. For this purpose, the exclusion from section 100A of income to which a trustee-beneficiary becomes presently entitled is to be limited to so much of that income as is passed on by the trustee as income to which a beneficiary of that trust estate is in turn presently entitled. Further amendments will deny deductions for losses or outgoings incurred under arrangements to which the section applies. This will prevent the section being frustrated through such amounts being available for write-off against other income of the nominal beneficiaries. The amendments will apply generally to trust income paid to, or applied for the benefit of, a beneficiary after 5 March 1980 and to losses or outgoings incurred after that date.
Expenditure Recoupment Schemes

Legislation against expenditure recoupment schemes already exists. It was foreshadowed on 24 September 1978 and now applies to a range of losses and outgoings. Broadly, the legislation applies to deny a deduction where the specifically designated loss or outgoing is incurred under an arrangement whereby the taxpayer or an associate obtains a benefit the amount or value of which, together with the tax advantage sought, effectively recoups the claimed loss or outgoing. In my statement of 4 August 1980 I foreshadowed action to extend the provisions to deal with variants of the recoupment type schemes that had by then been encountered. These involve paper losses generated in producing or marketing films, in operating gold mines, in purchasing consumable supplies and in carrying out market research. The amendments in respect of these variants are to apply with respect to losses or outgoings incurred after 24 September 1978. The decision to do this follows the clear warning given on that day and repeated subsequently.

I now make public that more recent information coming from returns of income for 1979-80 indicates that, before my announcement on 4 August 1980, still further schemes of the expenditure recoupment type had been implemented. As in the case of the schemes referred to in that announcement it would appear that promoters of the further schemes had chosen to ignore the Government's repeated warnings. In the light of the information now available, and of the clear government commitment to put an end to expenditure recoupment schemes, the Bill proposes extensions of the existing legislation additional to those I have already announced. These latest identified variants against which remedial action is now proposed involve paper losses generated in acquiring a licence under a copyright existing in computer software; by way of commission for collecting assessable income; by way of a fee in relation to the growing, care and supervision of trees; by way of an amount paid in relation to the enhancement of the value of shares held as trading stock; and by way of a fee in relation to the procuring of master sound recordings.

Honourable members would be interested to know that one of these schemes-that built on commissions for collecting assessable income-generated identified claims for deductions for 1979-80 of no less than $111m. The additional amendments will also have effect from 24 September 1978. In pursuance of that, I refer to the clear and unambiguous warning given by the Government at that time. They, and the amendments specifically outlined in my statement of 4 August 1980, will ensure that the ban on the carry-forward from one year to another of paper losses created under tax avoidance schemes, and which at present applies to expenditure recoupment arrangements, will apply similarly in respect of all the latest variants.
Exempt Bodies

In a statement on 24 June 1980, I foreshadowed legislation on tax avoidance through attempts to exploit the tax-exempt status of various entities. As I said at the time, two earlier warnings about the abuse of the privileged status of tax-exempt bodies had gone unheeded, and there was clear evidence that substantial revenue losses were accruing through the use of these bodies as vehicles for diverting taxable income from individuals and companies. I outlined in my statement examples of the kinds of schemes being employed. I do not think it is necessary to describe them in detail again now.

Broadly, however, the schemes involved the diversion of income from a person who would otherwise be liable to tax on it to a body that has no tax liability. The exempt body was required to pay to the person from whom the income was diverted, or to an associate of that person, a tax free consideration equal to the greater part of the diverted income. As a fee for its participation it retained a small amount of the income for its own benefit.

As mentioned in my statement, the legislation will operate where under a tax avoidance agreement entered into after 24 June 1980 an exempt body provides consideration for property giving rise to diverted income and the consideration is substantially more than the amount that, in the circumstances, would be paid by a taxable public company. The income derived by the exempt body in these circumstances, without deduction of losses or outgoings incurred under or in connection with the tax avoidance agreement, will be subject to tax at the maximum rate of personal tax. These measures will apply only to income derived by exempt bodies from participation in the particular tax avoidance schemes. Their ordinary income will continue to be exempt from tax.

Finally, the last, and bulkiest, section of the Bill contains a number of formal amendments, incorporating changes in drafting style. These will result in the adoption, in references to other provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act, of a 'forward referencing' style. Before concluding, I mention that legislation in pursuance of the Government's commitment to provide tax incentives for investment in Australian films is at an advanced stage and will be brought before the House before the winter recess. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr John Brown) adjourned.

This Bill is closely related to measures contained in the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1981, about which I have just spoken. By reason of those measures income tax is to be charged on income diverted to an exempt body under a tax avoidance arrangement entered into after 24 June 1980. The overall design of the legislation is to counteract the exploitation, for tax avoidance purposes, of the privileged status of tax exempt bodies, This Bill will formally impose tax on the diverted income. The rate of tax of 60 per cent proposed by the Bill is the same as that payable by a trustee of a trust estate on accumulating trust income and is equal to the maximum rate of personal tax. I commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr Moore
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The principal purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs Act to give effect to a number of recommendations of the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs. The Royal Commission made a large number of recommendations. In many cases only administrative action was recommended or was found to be required on an examination of the recommendations. There has been substantial progress already towards implementation of those recommendations. Other legislative recommendations did not relate to the Customs Act. Some required action by the governments of the States and the Northern Territory. These amendments give effect to the Government's decisions on those of the Royal Commission's recommendations which are considered by the Government to require action by way of amendment to the Customs Act.

The Royal Commission recommended that responsibility for narcotics control under the Customs Act in situations beyond the Customs barrier should be transferred from the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs to the Australian Federal Police. This recommendation has been implemented by an Administrative Direction and Administrative Arrangements Order. This Bill contains provisions to give clear legislative authority for the division of powers and functions. The division particlarly affects the seizure of goods and their custody, claims for recovery of seized goods, avenues of redress and the final disposal of any seized goods which become condemned to the Commonwealth. The proposed amendments are contained in clauses 3, 26, 33, 34, 36 and 38.

Clause 25 is proposed to implement the recommendation of the Royal Commission that a person seeking to clear goods through Customs might be required to disclose and prove his identity or the identity of the owner of the goods. This measure is designed to facilitate the apprehension of those importers of illicit narcotic drugs who address the drugs to ficticious persons for collection by anonymous agents. The Royal Commission also recommended that the Customs control over ships and aircraft at sea or in air space within three nautical miles of the Australian coast should extend to the area within 12 nautical miles of the coast. This is consistent with international law and convention. The Bill implements that recommendation in clauses 12, 24 and 29. However, the Bill provides that the limitation to the area within 12 nautical miles will apply only to foreign ships and aircraft. Customs control over Australian ships and aircraft will be exercisable to the full extent consistent with international law and convention.

The Bill also proposes a number of amendments of a more general nature. These amendments flow from a continuing process of review and modernising of the Customs Act. All imported goods become subject to Customs control on importation. They remain subject to this control until they are released by Customs. The control is essential to the Customs barrier against prohibited imports such as narcotics or quarantinable goods. It is also essential to Customs duty collection role. The control usually is exercised through a system of documentary checks. These necessarily are supplemented by physical examination of a proportion of the imports.

The Customs Act imposes responsibilities on those who are in possession of goods which are subject to Customs control. They are required to keep the goods safely and to produce them or account for them when so required by Customs. The Customs Act now recognises the passing of Customs entries as the principal authority for dealing with imported goods. When the entry is endorsed as passed the entry document remains in the possession of the Customs. It has been necessary to develop administrative procedures for a written authority to be given to the person in possession of the goods. The authority allows the person, usually a shipping company or an airline to deliver the goods for the purposes for which they have been entered; for example, for warehousing or for home consumption.

It is proposed to give legislative effect to that practice by replacing the passing of entry by the giving of an authority to deliver the goods. Clause 9 proposes that delivery authorities may be as prescribed by regulation. Almost half of the clauses of the Bill are consequential on these changes. The delivery authority will usually be given on the basis of an examination of commercial documents furnished by the owner of the goods, or his agent. However, intelligence may be received from other sources suggesting that narcotics may be concealed in the goods or that the goods are not properly described in the documents. Provision is made, therefore, to permit an authority to be suspended in order to allow a physical examination of the goods.

It is now an offence to move, alter or interfere with goods which are subject to Customs control. This offence is too limited in its present terms. The employee who improperly moves the goods will be liable. The principals, who have the responsibility to keep the goods securely, are not liable for their failure to implement and oversight effective systems for that purpose. Accordingly, clause 5 now proposes that principals should be liable for the acts of employees involved in the unauthorised movement of goods which are subject to Customs control. A defence is provided to protect those principals who do take reasonable precautions and exercise due diligence to ensure proper compliance with the Customs Act. Clause 13 proposes an amendment to section 64 to authorise regulations to prescribe the time and manner for ships, aircraft and their cargo to be reported to Customs after arriving from overseas.

Last year the Customs Act was amended to provide a means for dealing with refugee boats or other illegally imported vessels. Clause 26 now proposes new sections to supplement those powers. New section 207 will permit the speedy disposal of a seized vessel that is too unseaworthy to be maintained by Customs. Customs will be able to dispose of the vessel even though it has not been condemned to the Commonwealth. This will reduce the costs now incurred in keeping such vessels. New section 208B provides that a person with an interest in the vessel has a right to take proceedings to recover the proceeds of any sale of the vessel or the value of any destroyed vessel.

New section 208E allows conditions to be imposed on the sale or disposal of ships or aircraft, which have been condemned to the Commonwealth. By clause 30 they may again be forfeited if the conditions are not complied with.

Customs Tariff Proposals are introduced into the Parliament from time to time following Government decisions to alter the customs duty on imported goods. These Proposals are usually incorporated into a Customs Tariff Amendment Bill or a Customs Tariff Validation Bill. Clause 28 proposes to amend section 226 to extend the validity period of Customs Tariff Proposals from six months to 12 months.
The proposed extension of the life of the Proposals will reduce the number of Customs Tariff Bills. This will not diminish in any way the authority of Parliament to scrutinise Customs Tariff changes.

Provision is made in clause 35 to allow Customs Tariff Notices to have up to six months retrospective effect, except where the proposed alteration would increase the duty payable. The Bill represents a desirable advance towards a modernised Customs Act and will assist effective Customs administration. I commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend section 114 of the Excise Act 1901 to extend the validity period of Excise Tariff Proposals from six months to 12 months. This amendment is being proposed as a consequence of the Customs Amendment Bill 1981. That Bill similarly proposes an extension to the validity period of Customs Tariff Proposals. Excise Tariff Proposals are introduced into the Parliament from time to time following a Government decision to alter excise duty. It has been the practice to incorporate the Tariff Proposals into an Excise Tariff Amendment Bill. These are normally introduced late in a parliamentary sitting. When an Excise Tariff Amendment Bill is unable to achieve passage prior to six months after a proposal is introduced, it has also been the practice to validate that proposal by an Excise Tariff Validation Bill. This proposed amendment will have the effect of reducing the number of Excise Tariff Bills. It will not, however, diminish in any way, the authority of the Parliament to scrutinise excise tariff changes as they occur. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill, the Customs Securities (Penalties) Bill 1981, and the Customs Undertakings (Penalties) Bill 1981, as they are related measures. Sparate questions will, of course be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
-Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these three measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Customs Amendment (Tenders) Bill 1981 and cognate Bills give effect to one of the decisions made last year by the Government on the assistance arrangements to be afforded the clothing and footwear industries. The principal Bill, the Customs Amendment (Tenders) Bill 1981, provides for a scheme to call for and deal with tenders for import quotas on a range of textile, clothing and footwear products. The Bill includes provisions requiring successful tenderers to give an undertaking to utilise fully this quota and to provide a security to Customs in respect of penalties which may become payable for a breach of such undertakings. The other two Bills-the minor Bills-provide for the imposition of penalties for breach of undertakings and for failure to provide securities.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to indicate at the outset that the Opposition does not oppose any of these three Bills. However, I indicate also that the Opposition is not entirely satisfied with the assistance arrangements in respect of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries which have been adopted by the Government, and of which these three Bills form an important part.

Levels and forms of industry assistance are now among the most important economic issues facing Australia. The Opposition shares the view expressed in the report of the Crawford Study Group on Structural Adjustment which recommended that levels of protection afforded Australian industry should be reduced in the long term. However, we do not believe that sudden or dramatic reductions in protection are warranted, particularly at a time of high unemployment such as presently exists in Australia. While the rate of unemployment is at least 6 per cent of the work force, there is no logic in reducing protection so as to throw even more people out of work. I am sure that even this heartless government would agree with those sentiments.

The Opposition's commitment to the textiles, clothing and footwear industries is based on the realisation that the continued employment of about 120,000 Australians in these industries is essential. Many of these jobs are provided in regional centres with few alternative job opportunities. Many of the jobs are held by workers who lack the skills appropriate to alternative areas of industry. To reduce employment even more dramatically than is already occurring is not to achieve a restructing of industry. Rather it is to create more massive unemployment and to concentrate it in certain regions. We cannot countenance that as a proposition.

Having acknowledged the need at this time to maintain protection levels, it is also important to determine which are the most appropriate forms of assistance. We in the Opposition happen to believe that import quotas are appropriate in the case of certain industries, and the textiles, clothing and footwear industries are among these. It is perfectly clear that only quotas can provide the needed degree of certainty to the industry to enable it confidently to invest in plant which will help it produce a more competitive product in the future.

These Bills provide for the administration of import quotas on a two-tiered basis. Most of the quota is to be allocated to bona fide importers who have been involved in importing in recent years. However, a small proportion is to be sold by tender. Because the basic quota is to be fixed for the next seven years, the amount to be sold by tender will increase, assuming that even under this Government there is market growth over the period.

The Opposition recognises that the main benefit of a base quota allocation is stability for most of the importing industry. We recognise also that sale of quota maximises the efficiency of the importing sector and at the same time the auction system ensures that the maximum feasible revenue is gained by the Government rather than by private profiteers. While recognising that there is a trade-off between stability and the benefits of quota sale, it nevertheless seems unfortunate that the profits to be gained by those enjoying base quota allocations will always be greater than those to be gained under sale quota, assuming, of course, that the duty rate bids for sale quota reflect the high, effective rates of protection which import quotas convey. The duty rate on base quota is to be fixed at 50 per cent, whereas sale quota could well involve rates two or even three times this level.

The sale by tender system will reflect the real protection afforded by the imposition of import quotas. It appears to the Opposition that the profits to be gained by this system should accrue to General Revenue as they would under a tariff system rather than to a privileged group of importers. Indeed, it is possible that, through strong bidding for sale quotas by base quota holders, these profits could be unfairly maximised.

These opportunities for profiteering should be overcome. As a minimum measure, the rate of duty on base quota should be reconsidered annually and adjusted in line with the trend of prices revealed by the tender system. The differential between base and sale quota duty rates should never be allowed to become excessive, if indeed it should be allowed to prevail at all. The recent and continuing revaluation of the Australian dollar upwards is causing an increasing disparity between the free on board price of imports and the price of locally produced products. In these circumstances, windfall profits are likely to be made by base quota holders. The Opposition is of the opinion that this should not be allowed to continue.

Indeed, this is only one area of concern to the Opposition. This problem is paralleled by the need to ensure that the price levels on the Australian market are the lowest possible in respect of locally produced goods. This requires a greater degree of planning in the industry. The Opposition has long been of the view that complex and interrelated industries such as textiles, clothing and footwear should be given closer attention by government. It is not good enough to give an industry a level of protection which is possibly the highest in our history and then pretend that we can leave the rest to the market. History proves that market forces are not effective in this area.

We believe the Government has its head in the sand when it comes to the management of the industrial sector of the enconomy. On the one hand, at enormous cost it quite properly protects the private sector from the full impact of a free market environment but, on the other hand, it pretends to deregulate industry by irresponsible actions to remove proper and beneficial interventions such as price justification. We know, of course, what has happened to the Prices Justification Tribunal in the last few days. The Opposition believes that industry-specific policies are needed for industries such as these and that these policies should be appropriately devised and managed by industry authorities established for the purpose.

In addition to these general concerns about the administration of assistance arrangements for the textile, clothing and footwear industries, we have some particular concerns with the provisions of these Bills. We are particularly concerned that the arrangements for quotas do not allow a small number of large importers to tie up the market. Small firms must not be unreasonably excluded, and competition should be maintained. In this respect we hope that due consideration will be given by the Government to the call by Mr Clive Rodger of the Apparel Manufacturers Association of New South Wales that the security required under the legislation not be too high so as to be an overburden on small firms.

The Opposition has also been concerned that the right to buy and sell quotas is not abused and exploited by firms which are not bona fide importers. We understand that the officers of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs will have stronger powers under the legislation in this respect. We are very happy about that. However, it is always essential that adequate staff is applied to these tasks. We call on the Government to ensure that its manic determination to bash the public sector does not result in costly losses in this area. In conclusion, I reiterate that the Opposition supports the Bills as a desirable improvement of the import quota system, notwithstanding its concern that there are a number of areas of the Government's assistance arrangements which are poorly conceived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

Mr John Dawkins Ref: to Clothing quotas 25 February 1981 Dear Sir,
Further to our discussion regarding looking into the possibility of increasing the amount of clothing we would need to import to retain a viable business.

As I explained to you, with the new quota system being introduced as of 1st January 1981. If our quota is based on our base performance for the two year period determined by the Federal Government, this would mean to us a complete loss of our wholesale business.

We have been importing clothing for more than five years, our total imports during this time have been small due to the lack of assistance given to us from Customs Tariff during this time. During the five years I have been in business, we have worked seven days a week, sometimes a twenty hour day just to build our business to what it is today. I feel totally dissolutioned that overnight all the work we have put into our business can be undone through no fault of our own, just at a time when we can slow down to a 6 day week, 10 hour day.

We have built up a good clientel for our clothing during the last eighteen months, and now see everything we have worked for ending, just at a time when we should be receiving the reward we have worked for.
I have enclosed a list detailing clothing imported during the base performance determined by Federal Government, and sincerly hope you will look into this problem for me.
I sincerly hope you are able to help us in this matter, because without your help I do not know what we will do.

I feel this is another example of the small business going under to the benefit of the large retail chain stores. I would like to ask what hope in this country has the small businessman when this unfair balance of power can put small operators out of business because they cannot front up with large amounts of money just to stay in business.
I only wish to be offered the chance to build up a business I understand, and at the same time offer employment to those that are willing to work.
I would like to thank you for taking the time to read this letter, and trust you will endeavour to help me in any way you are able.
