TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these two measures? There being no objection I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The prime purpose of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill that we are debating today is to adjust payments to schools and to tertiary institutions to take into account cost increases which have occurred in relation to certain items since those grants were introduced. The Bills particularly relate to cost increases last year and this year. As well as that, the opportunity has been taken to include a number of other amendments to the funding arrangements for schools and tertiary institutions. These are not of any contentious nature. For instance, some of them are consequent upon some amalgamations which have taken place between colleges of advanced education and a university and a CAE in Tasmania. A rearrangement of funds is necessary as a result.

SPEECH.PARA: In the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, the opportunity has been taken by the Government to put into effect some of the promises which were made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) prior to the last election. I must say that, because of the abandonment of so many election promises, it is a very rare event indeed to have an opportunity to discuss the fulfilment of some. Here we have an instance where action is being taken to commence the process of implementing these election undertakings. Of course, we know, as the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) has indicated on previous occasions, that eduction funding is considered annually. So, we may well have in 12 months time some abandonment of these promises as well. At least we should be thankful for the fact that this Government is, in fact, moving on this occasion to implement promises.

The first relates to the undertaking to provide $25m over three years in the form of capital assistance for non-government schools for them to provide new places. This legislation provides the first instalment of that $25m-that is, $7.4m for this year-in pursuit of that objective. The next Government undertaking which is put into effect by this legislation is to compress the current six levels under which non-government schools are described into three. On this occasion levels two and three are joined. The same subsidy arrangements will apply to those former levels. There is also a new program of assistance for the education of the severely handicapped both in institutions and in their own homes. This is a very welcome initiative.

Finally, the Government has taken the opportunity to commence the implementation of its program to provide support for part time non-profit ethnic schools which are providing supplementary courses in community language and cultural education. I emphasise that the Opposition does not intend to oppose these Bills, but it takes the opportunity to move amendments to these two Bills. I have an amendment in relation to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill and a further amendment in relation to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill. In relation to the motion that the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill be read a second time, I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'whilst not denying the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the reduction in the activities of the Schools Commission as announced in the Review of Commonwealth Functions in that:

(1) the contraction of the information collection and dissemination activities of the Commission constitutes an obstacle to the debate on education policy and will limit accountability for education expenditure, and
(2) the withdrawal of the administrative functions of the Commission at the State level will limit and downgrade the services the Commission provides particularly to the non-government sector'.

As I indicated, I will move an amendment in relation to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill. Whilst I do not formally move it now, I indicate that the text of that amendment will be:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not denying the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the ill-considered and grossly inequitable changes to the funding, organisation and financing of students in tertiary education as announced in the Review of Commonwealth Functions, in that:
(1) the re-introduction of fees is not only a breach of an election undertaking but will grossly disadvantage students with limited means and will compromise Australia's research effort;
(2) the gutting of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme will confirm tertiary education as the preserve of the rich, and

(3) the heavy-handed threat in the review to 30 Colleges of Advanced Education is based on the wholly false premise that the consolidation of single purpose colleges will result in cost savings in spite of the Tertiary Education Commission's advice to the contrary'.

I take this opportunity to move one amendment and to foreshadow another because, whilst the Bills before us do bestow certain benefits in relation to education in this country, they pale into insignificance in terms of the damage that is being done to education throughout Australia as a result of the Government'c decisions flowing from the Review of Commonwealth Functions. It is extraordinarily ironic that we should be debating these Bills, which are supposed to be beneficial to education, at the same time as we have before us the results of the continuing assault that this Government is waging against education. The decisions which have been announced-I will go through them in some detail in a moment-simply represent a continuing part of the Government's resentment of an education system which is open to all, free to all and which provides a quality of education which we all should be aiming for. In fact, this Government has not been interested in maintaining the high level of education in this country. It has been concerned to restrict access, particularly at the tertiary level. It has been concerned to attack the level of research undertaken in tertiary institutions and it has been concerned to downgrade the activities of the Schools Commission, which has transformed school education in this country not only in the government sector but also in the non-government sector.

I mention briefly the decisions which have been made in the context of education as a result of the Lynch committee and to comment on the ways in which these decisions will seriously damage education in this country. In the first instance the Government has decided to re-impose fees for those students undertaking second or higher degrees in universities and colleges of advanced education. The fees will apply to those students who will enroll for the first time in 1982. The Government has decided that the fees should not apply to recognised double degree and diploma combinations. It has also decided that the fees will not be paid by those students in receipt of Commonwealth Government and university post-graduate awards. The scale of fees has not been announced because the Government has said that the level of fees will be set in the Budget context. The Government has said that there will be a reduction in the amount of funding to the colleges and universities as a result of its decision on the Tertiary Education Commission report to take account of the fee income which the universities and colleges might expect from the imposition of these fees.

I think the important point to remember about this is that this is just a repeat of a proposal which was first foreshadowed by this Government in 1976. An identical proposition was put up at that time but not proceeded with. The reason it was not proceeded with was the Minister at the time, Senator Carrick, indicated quite clearly that the costs of raising the fee income would probably exceed the revenue which was collected. That task has been given to the universities and colleges. It is something they have not sought and they do not want. This is clear from the fact that the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee in 1976 strongly opposed the introduction of these fees. It has on this occasion also indicated that it is a great mistake on the part of the Government to impose them. There are already indications that the universities, particularly the staff at universities, are highly resentful of the introduction of these fees.

I want to read out two communications which I have received in the last couple of days. I suspect that this is the beginning of a barrage of complaints which all members of parliament will receive as a result of this grossly ill-considered decision. The first communication comes from the Monash University Staff Association and it states:

. . . urges immediate reconsideration of proposal to introduce fees for later degrees and to close Educational Research and Development Committee. Later degree students make productive contributions to research and to maintenance of professional standards. The consequences of enactment of these proposals will be maximum damage to the nation's human capital for minimal financial savings.

In saying that the Monash University Staff Association simply affirms the remarks which I and the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) were making yesterday in another debate on a related matter. The Department of Economics of the University of Wollongong has also opposed the reintroduction of fees for second and higher degree students without a substantial expansion and upgrading of the Commonwealth Post-Graduate Award Scheme. It goes on to complain about the way in which the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme will be tightened. I will come back to that in a moment. These complaints are not coming particularly from the students concerned, they are coming from the staff association in one instance and the academics from the Department of Economics in the other instance. The reason they are complaining is that they know the value of the contribution post-graduate students make to the research effort in universities and therefore to the research effort throughout Australia.
The other aspect about the introduction of these fees is that it is a clear breach of a pre-election commitment given by the current Minister for Education, Mr Fife. In October of last year he said:

There continues to be speculation about Government plans to reintroduce fees for tertiary education. I have given an assurance publicly and I repeat that assurance, that no proposals are being considered by the Government for the possible reintroduction of tertiary fees.

To any fair-minded person, that simple statement represented a commitment not to reintroduce fees at the tertiary level. On this occasion the Government has reintroduced fees, although only for post-graduate and second degree students. Clearly it is an absolute abrogation of that undertaking which was given by the Minister for Education last year. I want the House and everybody in Australia to note what the Minister has done and to take that on board because, when presenting the report of the Lynch committee, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) solemnly declared that it was not the Government's intention to reintroduce fees at the undergraduate level. What has to be remembered is that this is just another worthless Liberal Party, Liberal Government undertaking. It is just as worthless as the one that the Minister gave in October last year. What we are seeing now is the thin end of the wedge in regard to the wholesale reintroduction of fees at all levels in tertiary education. In answer to a question from me on 25 March this year, Mr Fife clearly said: that the matter of fees was something which had to be taken into account in the annual budgetary considerations. So it is quite clear that this is the decision for this year. The decision is not to reimpose fees at the undergraduate level next year, but it is no guarantee that they will not be introduced at some stage in the very near future. Therefore I think we have to continue to emphasise the damage that the reintroduction of fees could make and would make if we had a reintroduction at the undergraduate level.

I want to refer briefly to a survey which has just been completed at the Macquarie University; a university, by the way, which happens to be in the electorate of the Treasurer (Mr Howard). This is a preliminary paper. The survey was conducted only in the last couple of weeks. It indicated that forty per cent of students would defer or withdraw from undergraduate education if they were forced to pay fees of even a fairly nominal amount of $300 a year. A survey was done in 1976 for the Education Research and Development Committee. That survey was supplemented by other surveys. What has come out of the Macquarie University survey in the last couple of weeks indicates that the resistance to paying fees is very much greater than was thought to be the case at that time. If fees of $1,000 had been imposed on law students this year half of those students, who one would expect go into professions with fairly high incomes after graduation, would not have enrolled in law school.

The Government has to recognise that the imposition of fees does provide a direct and severe deterrent to people to continue with their tertiary education. The fact that the Government is, at this time, imposing fees for post-graduate students and for second degree students means that this will severely disadvantage the most needy of those students. Clearly, the only assistance available in the form of post-graduate awards is awarded on the basis of merit and not on the basis of need. Therefore, students who are quite successful and who can make a positive contribution will not be able to afford fees unless they are amongst the most able students who are lucky enough to be in receipt of post-graduate awards of one kind or another.

I think the point is that the Government, obviously, thinks that it will receive a fair amount of revenue as a result of the introduction of this measure. But as inquiries and calculations that I have made show the Government is likely to receive not more than one per cent of the total amount which the Commonwealth spends on tertiary education as a result of the imposition of these fees. Not all post-graduate students will pay, but in addition many of those students who will be forced to pay will be discouraged from enrolling and, therefore, the Government will not receive fees from them. So, in return for imposing a measure damaging to Australia's research effort, highly disruptive to university education as a whole and highly disruptive to the administration of universities-these fees cannot be collected for nothing, as all that will be raised in the form of revenue is about one per cent of the amount that it currently spends on tertiary education.

I refer quickly to the proposals that the Government has in mind in relation to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and loans. I do not want to go into all the ways in which TEAS has declined over the last few years; but we know that a declining number of people are receiving TEAS benefits and, particularly, that a declining number of people are receiving the maximum benefit. I did go into this matter in some detail in an earlier debate in this House. We cannot look at the loans scheme in isolation from TEAS, because the Government has stated clearly that from the time it introduces the student loans scheme it will set the benefits in relation to TEAS in the knowledge that extra supplementary assistance will be available through the loans scheme. There is absolutely no doubt as to what that means. The Government will either freeze the TEAS benefits or reduce them in order to force more and more people to take out loans to support themselves through tertiary education.

This is at odds with a recommendation from the committee which the Government set up to inquire into the student loans scheme and which reported in 1977. That committee, the Butcher committee, said at the time that any loans scheme ought to be introduced purely as a supplement to the existing system of tertiary education assistance, that is, it did not say that a loans scheme should replace a tertiary allowance or even replace it in part. It said that there was a case for the introduction of a loans scheme on a supplementary basis for students who were unable to support themselves entirely on the existing level of TEAS. That is not what the Government is saying on this occasion. It is forecasting that TEAS will be gutted. It will be available to fewer and fewer people. Clearly it will be available at a lower level of benefit than is the case at the moment. That will compel students to take out loans in order to pay their basic living costs.

There will be great resistance, particularly from students with poorer backgrounds, to incurring debts at this time of their lives. They are being asked to incur a debt at the age of 18 or 19 which they would pay back upon graduation. It is the Government's theory that once they graduate and obtain a job they ought to repay to society some of the investment which society has made in their education. It is a grossly unfair system in practise.

I refer again to the Macquarie University's survey made in the last couple of weeks. Four hundred and eleven students were asked how they predicted their ability to repay the loan. Only 6 per cent said that they would certainly be able to repay it, 25 per cent said that most likely they would be able to repay it and something like two-thirds said either that it was unlikely that they would be able to repay the loan or that they would not be able to repay that loan. If that is what they thought they would not take out a loan in the first place.

The reason they doubt their ability to repay the loan is that these students are aware of the high level of graduate unemployment that exists in this country. They are aware also of the fact that once they graduate in their early twenties that will be just the time when they will incur other debts for houses or cars or whatever. They do not want the extra burden of repaying the cost of having to support themselves through their university or college course. Repayment may be possible for those people who float straight into highly remunerative occupations upon graduation, but that will not be the experience of most gratuates. The people who will be most in need of extra support will be least likely to be attracted to the loans schemes.

I urge the Government to reconsider this matter. It is certainly not a cost saving device. In the short term it will cost the Government more as it makes available the funds for the loans scheme. It is true that over time some of the money will be repaid. The Government expects that it will save, presumably by gutting the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. But at the same time, this year and next year it will certainly cost the Government more. I suggest that the Government carefully reconsider the question of introducing a student loans scheme. It will discourage people from entering tertiary education. I desperately hope that it is not the intention of the Government to discourge people from going on to higher education. Already we have appalling falling levels of participation in higher secondary and post secondary education in Australia. What we really ought to be attempting to do is increase the number of young people who are participating in education, not providing further serious impediments to their continued participation in education.

I refer to one other matter which relates to the area of schools education, that is, the quite absurd decision of the Government to close down the Curriculum Development Centre. The Curriculum Development Centre was established by--

TALK.START.PARA: —If the States want it they can contribute.

—The honourable member for Dundas says that the States can contribute. I am sure the States are going to be terribly enthusiastic about making all kinds of contributions to the Commonwealth from now on.
—If it is useful they will be enthusiastic.

—What the honourable member for Dundas has to remember is that the States now know that the Commonwealth has withheld from them $70m which it could have made available for this and other purposes. They are not going to be enthusiastic. They are not going to be the slightest bit enthusiastic about taking over on a voluntary basis functions which are quite clearly national functions, Federal Government functions, and have been at least since the inception of the Curriculum Development Centre.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision in respect of the Curriculum Development Centre is not a huge matter of national importance, but it does highlight very clearly the absurdity of many of the decisions in the education area which were made by the Government as a result of the Lynch committee. The Government has just spent $200,000 on refurbishing premises for the Curriculum Development Centre in Lyneham. It was only on 18 March, something like six weeks ago, that the current Minister for Education opened those new premises. He said that he was very pleased to have been invited to perform the official opening of the new premises. He then went on:
In the five years since its establishment the Curriculum Development Centre has undertaken a formidable array of projects which have resulted in an enrichment of the fabric of Australian education.
He further said:

Perhaps the highlight of the Centre's efforts was the release last year of the discussion paper entitled 'Core Curriculum for Australian Schools' which has been acclaimed both in Australia and internationally as an important contribution to this aspect of the education debate.
He went on:
I am sure that when public reaction to the paper has been assessed and analysed a refreshing approach to curriculum through a core curriculum concept will result.

This exercise is, however, by no means an isolated undertaking. In co-operation with the State education agencies, the Curriculum Development Centre has produced a most impressive array of curriculum materials of national importance.

Through its work the Centre has demonstrated to Australian educators, and others involved in education, the importance of on-going curriculum development, as well as the value of having identifiable areas of specific curriculum focus, as our education system strives to keep pace with rapid social change.

That is what the Minister thought just six weeks ago when he went over to turn the key at the CDC premises in Lyneham. He is to go back in a couple of weeks time to put up the shutters. That is a most deplorable turn-around. I would like to know what it is that has possessed the Minister to have such a complete reversal of attitude in just six weeks.

I take the point of the honourable member for Dundas. I certainly hope the States will contribute to the costs of continuing the CDC although not because I think it is their obligation to do so. I do not think it is. This is a national task which costs the Commonwealth only about $2.5m a year. It is not an expensive undertaking, and already the States are making a contribution of just under $1m to the cost of running the place anyway. It is just a stupid decision of the Commonwealth. I hope that the States will come to the party and keep the centre going, though I might say that the chances of the States responding in that way would be much greater if the Commonwealth would turn round and hand over the $70m which, in my opinion, it deceitfully withheld the other week from the States.

I wish to raise one other matter and I refer to the quite short-sighted decision of the Government to restrict the activities of the Schools Commission. The Schools Commission has been making an invaluable contribution to the education debate in this country by the provision of information and the dissemination of that information. Through the activities of the Schools Commission we in this place and others around Australia have been able to make a more informed contribution to the education debate and have been more aware of the amount and direction of education expenditure in this country. The Government's decision to contract that activity is most unfortunate and undemocratic and will result in serious problems for government and non-government schools.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak later.

—Before I call the honourable member for Wentworth, I remind the House that although the honourable member has had extensive experience in another parliament this is his maiden speech in this Parliament. I request all honourable members to extend to him the normal courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Bills before the House, but before speaking in particular on the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1981 I seek the House's indulgence for a moment. I want to take this opportunity to thank the people of the Wentworth division for electing me as their representative in this historic House and also those hundreds of members and supporters of the Liberal Party who in the period from my pre-selection as candidate in March to my election as a member in April worked so hard in the campaign. I will strive to justify the trust that they have placed in me.

SPEECH.PARA: The division of Wentworth is a Liberal Party stronghold in the eastern suburbs of Sydney. As some members of the Opposition frequently noted during the recent by-election, Wentworth has never been held by the Australian Labor Party, although nowadays, as a result of boundary changes, it has some booths where the Labor Party wins the support of a majority of voters. It is my intention as well as my duty to serve them all, regardless of party allegiance.

The division of Wentworth has always been well represented in this House by members who have played a major role in the national life of the country. One need only mention the three members who preceded me: Sir Eric Harrison, who in his 25 years in this House served in many ministeries before becoming Australian High Commissioner in London; Leslie Bury, C.M.G., who also held a variety of portfolios with distinction; and Robert Ellicott, now the Honourable Mr Justice Ellicott of the Federal Court.

Robert Ellicott, my immediate predecessor, set a standard that I can only hope to emulate. He has left a legacy which speaks for itself. I am referring not only to his great reputation for integrity but also to the variety of measures for which he was responsible. He established the Federal Court, the office of Ombudsman, the National Institute of Sport, Art Bank, the National Women's Advisory Council, to mention only a few. He introduced tax incentives for film makers, he completed the purchase of Cocos (Keeling) Islands, and he introduced self-government to Norfolk Island. As a local member and not as a Minister Mr Ellicott established the Inner City Legal Services Centre in Oxford Street in the electorate of Wentworth. I have mentioned these illustrations of his achievements only to indicate the loss to this Parliament which his elevation to the Bench represents. However, it may be that Robert Ellicott has not yet really resigned from politics. So intermeshed now are legislation and litigation, parliament and the judiciary, that as Mr Justice Ellicott he will, I am sure, continue to play a major role in the public life of this country.

Turning now to the measures before the House, I am grateful for the opportunity to make my maiden speech in this chamber on the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, not only because it was introduced by an old colleague and friend from the Parliament of New South Wales but also because in one package it expresses so much of the philosophy of the Liberal Party. The Bill expresses the Liberal Party's real commitment to freedom of choice in education, the importance it attaches to the rights of minority ethnic cultures in the Australian community and its concern to assist the severely handicapped among us.

I will start with the third theme of the Bill and the clauses which provide for the introduction of a new scheme to encourage the development of educational programs for those victims of life's genetic lottery or of other afflictions-the severely handicapped children in institutions or homes. This measure represents the adoption of the 1979 Queensland study 'A Survey of Special Education in Australia' prepared for the Schools Commission by the Fred and Eleanor Schonell Education Research Centre in the University of Queensland. That survey estimated-one can only estimate-that there are about 108,000 handicapped Australian children and adolescents. These are children who are blind or visually handicapped, deaf or partly deaf, physically handicapped and suffering, for example, from cerebral palsy or spina bifida and those severely or mildly, mentally handicapped. For generations voluntary organisations and the State educational authorities have had or have assumed the responsibility for assisting parents in the education of these children. In recent years the Commonwealth has accepted its share of responsibility in this field both in research and in the funding of programs.

In 1977 the Schools Commission expanded and re-formed its Special Education Advisory Group and decided to undertake the detailed national study which is the basis of this legislation. This year the Commonwealth Government has already committed $17.8m for the Special Education Program and now this Bill commits a further $2m for the severely handicapped. Recent Commonwealth commitments, the Schonell survey and now this Bill represent the beginning of a significant new deal for the severely handicapped, and I congratulate the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) on it.

I turn now to a potentially more controversial part of the Bill, that concerned with funding ethnic schools-the multiculturalist theme of the Bill. This grew out of the report prepared by the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs called Review of Multicultural and Migrant Education of September 1980. So we are in an area where there has been increasing debate. We hear warnings that multiculturalism is being carried too far, that it will produce a backlash, that earlier generations of ethnic migrants for nearly 200 years were assimilated into Australian society without hearing the word 'ethnic', let alone having special ethnic institutes, programs, and so on. We are being warned that multiculturalism is becoming a growth industry exploited by opportunist, pseudo-idealistic bureaucracies that will in the phrase of one commentator-himself an ethnic migrant, if one must use these terms-transform a decent, well-governed Australia into a racist cauldron. One must note such warnings when they come from sincere and intelligent critics. Obviously if carried to extremes multiculturalism would destroy our national cohesion and identity. I have no doubt these critics will be against this aspect of the Bill before us, yet I do not believe the criticisms are justified.

Ethnic community schools, part time and operating after regular school hours and at weekends, have spread across Australia. There are about 600 such schools in which about 100,000 students are taught. They are voluntary organisations and are larely self-financing, although they receive some State government and some foreign embassy support. They are here to stay. They specialise in ethnic languages and cultures and they help cushion the student's transition from the country of origin to Australian life. They reduce the traumas of assimilation. Probably every member in this chamber has been to scores of naturalisation and citizenship ceremonies where speeches have been delivered stressing that the taking of Australian citizenship involves the renunciation of any other citizenship but not an any ethnic heritage. This Bill and these ethnic schools do no more than encourage the retention of those heritages-a practice and method that has in any case been maintained, although not on current scales, for generations without any government assistance by the German, Jewish, Greek and Italian communities in Australia. Nevertheless, it is the case that there has been some dissatisfaction, even among sympathisers, with the schools. The 'Review of Multicultural and Migrant Education' reports that the quality of education given in these schools is not uniformly good, that some of the teachers are not adequately qualified, that much of the teaching material is unsatisfactory, that many of the premises used are makeshift. Above all, public authorities really know very little, with any certainty, about the schools.

The Bill, in accordance with the recommendations of the review referred to aims to improve this situation. It provides for financial assistance to approved programs. In other words, it will give money to the schools-up to $30 a child-but not without strings. The money will go only to approved courses. This excludes instruction that is predominantly political or religious. One further consequence is that in the process of examining courses for the purposes of giving approval, a good deal more information will be obtained about the schools. I believe this information will enhance the standing of these voluntary enterprises. In short the schools deserve support for three reasons: They are an outstanding example of the voluntary principle, they reduce the shocks and traumas of assimilation into Australian society and they contribute to the maintenance of the linguistic and cultural inheritance of Australians. I am glad to be able to support this part of the Bill.

The third theme of this Bill concerns Commonwealth assistance to government and to independent schools. It seems to me that two of the great problems of the day in the field of public education are, firstly, to arrest the disappointing erosion of confidence in government schools arising out of what parents perceive as a fall in standards of literacy, numeracy and discipline in government schools despite the investment of massive sums of money in them and, secondly, to cope with the consequent rising public demand for the services of independent schools, whether church or secular, traditional or experimental, so that real freedom of choice between different kinds of education continues to be possible. The arguments about literacy and numeracy in government schools continue without agreement being in sight. No doubt one can always find some expert on either side to prove anything. Meanwhile parents are voting with their feet in favour of independent schools. In my electorate, which contains some very famous government high schools, about half the students attend independent schools; the waiting lists for these schools are growing and there is talk of closing down at least one high school-a measure to which I am completely opposed.

The solution to the government school problem lies primarily with State governments, State departments of education and the state school teachers. The crisis will not pass until they take the steps to restore educational standards to the place they used to have in government schools. In my view this involves a range of policies from renewed emphasis on the three Rs to the restoration of serious and respected public examinations. If that happens-the sooner it happens the better-I believe the move to independent schools will be less pronounced. Yet, from the point of view of Commonwealth involvement in education, the issue is not only one of educational standards-fundamental as that is-but also of parents' freedom to choose between different kinds of school, government or independent. We see today, as I have said, an expansion not only of traditional independent schools but also of more innovative or experimental ones. There would be even more if we adopted some version of the voucher system for the choice of schools. But be that as it may, the freedom of choice which parents now enjoy would be quite impossible without financial assistance from government of the kind provided for in this Bill.

One might sometimes be forgiven for believing that this is now, after all these years, a bipartisan policy shared by government and opposition but in fact we know that the Opposition, or at least strong elements in it, does not yet really believe in parents' freedom of choice and the legitimacy of both independent and government schools. One has only to remember the reaction of the Opposition to the razor gang's common sense proposals to return a variety of government functions to the private sector- a reaction that in some cases seemed about to cause seizures, if not hysterical fits, so great is the horror of the private sector, including the private educational sector, to the socialist mind. I believe there really is no true basic consensus on this question of freedom of choice in education. It is still an issue that illustrates the philosophic differences between the Liberal Party and the Labor Party. I congratulate the Minister on this aspect of the Bill. Taken together, the three themes of the Bill illustrate compassion for the handicapped, concern for the welfare of ethnic minorities and a determination to maintain real freedom in one of parents' most important choices-the education of their children. In my view, the Bill can stand as a simple symbol of the policies of the Liberal Party and this Government for the 1980s.

It has been a strange experience for me to be listened to in comparative polite silence after some 10 to 11 years in the Legislative Assembly of New South Wales. I now look forward to later debates in this famous chamber when I should not expect, or wish, for such quietness. Nevertheless, I thank the House for its courtesy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Dr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to convey my congratulations to the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) on making his maiden speech. It is quite fitting that he should make it in an area on which State parliaments base so much discussion-the area of education. I also welcome him to that growing circle of former members of State parliaments who have entered Federal Parliament. However, I must warn him that if he expects his State colleagues, even of the same parliamentary persuasion, always to look upon him with admiration, he will be sadly disillusioned.
—It happens on our side.

—It does happen on our side. I am afraid events of recent days will reduce the honourable member's popularity. As has been said by the honourable member for Wentworth and the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins), members of this House do not oppose the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill or the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill. In fact, they honour Government undertakings and, after all, that is a rare event in this House in recent times. So we can but approve them. I draw the attention of the House to the statement by the Minister for education (Mr Fife) about the Government's policy on education. On page 1862 of Hansard of 30 April, he is recorded as having said:

SPEECH.PARA: This is in conformity with the Government's resolve to ensure equality of opportunity and freedom of choice for all Australian school children and their parents.

I will go back to that statement later. I must admit that with regard to the schools assistance legislation I did have sympathy for the point of view put by the honourable member for Wentworth regarding the program to assist non-profit part time ethnic schools. These schools are well established in our communities and they do require assistance. Variations in standards are involved and I am pleased to see that this extra assistance will be paid to those schools where the children are undertaking approved supplementary community language and cultural education programs, because here there is some degree of accountability. So, whilst I support these particular part time ethnic schools, I am concerned about the contribution that is made to multicultural education. It seems to me that although those schools satisfy the requirements of that one group in preserving the language, culture and knowledge of history of that group-a very laudable objective-they are still not breaking down the barriers between the culture of that group and those of other groups. Australia is now rich in ethnic people and ethnic culture. I would like to see the opportunity for multicultural exchange. This is not provided for in our schools at the moment in any effective form. The attempt in South Australia, with its program in a number of primary schools, does give some sort of lead but it has not gone very far.

I now move to the other program, which is to develop education programs for severely handicapped children. We are told the Bill makes provision for the introduction of a new scheme. What is the scheme and how will it operate? It will cost $19.3m but what is its objective and how will it be carried out? Just as an objective, it is acceptable. But are we not sensible enough in this Federal Parliament to be told how it is to operate, what accountability there will be and what its objectives are? How far would it go? The Preston Institute of Technology had the Education Program for Infants and Children which dealt with Down's syndrome children. This was started under a special grant from the Department of Social Security. It was an early education program which began with babies affected by Down's syndrome in their first year of life. It was eminently successful and because of its success it drew numbers beyond those approved for the pilot scheme. The effect snowballed and about three months ago the Institute thought it would not be financed beyond 30 June. Only recently has it been told it will be allowed to carry on.

What is its future? What is the future for similar schemes under this education program for severely handicapped children, or does it not apply to those schemes at all? It seems to me that it is programs such as those for the severely handicapped which we should support. We are given insufficient information concerning them and the Government's objectives. I think the Minister ought to take some time to explain the objectives of that program to us. I come back to equality of opportunity and freedom of choice. I have a telegram from N. Robinson, the Secretary of the Preston Institute of Technology Association of Professional Staff. It states:

General meeting of academic staff Preston Institute concerned at introduction of fees for post-graduate and continuing education. This will cause hardship to students and lead to shortage of Australian specialists especially in technological and business areas.

When the Whitlam Government started massive involvement of Federal funds in education programs it seemed to start at both ends. One may have questioned why it started first with the tertiary area and the abolition of tertiary fees. The fact is that at that stage tertiary education was elitist and exclusive. Only a very small percentage of people were able to break through the barrier of fees and the expenses of attending a tertiary institution. Some of us were able to do it by working during the day and studying at night, but there were very few indeed and it was done under very difficult circumstances.

In the early 1970s tertiary institutions expanded and they were freed of fees. There is now a deliberate attempt to return these institutions to their former exclusive and elitist state. This introduction of fees for second and post-graduate degrees is an example of this. It will affect those who come from poorer economic circumstances far more than any others. Surely we will not be told by members of the Government that a primary degree is the end of tertiary education. Surely anyone looking for expertise in the technological, scientific and business fields would say that the first degree just lays the base for expertise. Why should it be forced upon those who wish to continue their education to improve their skills, which are needed in so many fields in Australia, that they must be able to afford to support themselves and pay fees? Not only have there been cutbacks in this area but also there has been the question of the facilities which are available for tertiary education. The Tertiary Education Commission pointed out:

The situation is a serious one . . . Despite the fact that total student load has levelled off, there is a backlog of demand for teaching space . . . There are a number of examples of overcrowding, the use of unsuitable temporary accommodation and substandard facilities which require replacement as a matter of urgency.
That appears on page 7, volume 2 of the TEC report. It is further stated on page 9 of that volume:

. . . that the capacity of universities and colleges to meet their teaching and research commitments will be seriously impaired unless there is an increase in the funds for capital works above the level available in 1980.

In this House we hear so much about natural resources, their development and how that will build up the country. Surely the greatest natural resources in Australia are human resources-the development of their skills and abilities. The overall effect of the cuts in this area will be to reduce staff numbers, raise the size of classes and, bit by bit, cut back on the number of places available to students. In 1974 the maximum Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance was 75.4 per cent of the Henderson poverty line. Today it is 61.7 per cent. If we look at the cutoff point for means testing for the allowance we see that the cutoff point declined from 100.1 per cent of the average male wage in 1974 to 80.1 per cent today. The student income cutoff point dropped in real terms from 28.3 per cent of the average male wage in the previous financial year to 12.8 per cent. These cuts make it harder for children of working class families, mature age students and people living in country areas to enter tertiary education. So much for equality of education and freedom of choice in education!

My colleague the honourable member for Fremantle has already referred to student loans. It is impossible to expect students to carry out their courses, after obtaining loans and be hit by repayments at the time when, if they are from working class backgrounds they are already struggling because they have not been in the work force for so many years. It is no solution at all. I speak from experience of that situation, although it was many years ago. My colleague from Fremantle would say: 'Anyone with science and medical qualifications is one of those who gets into the high income group as soon as he hits the work force'. Well, it is still a battle if such a person has to pay back student loans.

Let me return to the area of primary and secondary education and the question of the Schools Commission. We were disappointed that the involvement of the Schools Commission in program administration and information collection in the States is to be reduced. The State offices are pretty vestigial already. Further cutbacks in their involvement will mean a further lack of, or indeed the absence of, information which gives us any degree of accountability of programs in schools whether government or non-government, primary or secondary. We cannot afford this. The introduction of the Schools Commission provided us with a source of information to enable us to judge just how adequately or inadequately the programs were working. Here we intend to cut it back further. We will cut out special support for educational research. We have reached the stage where we can afford to cut out involvement in educational research.

I have heard many comments that the schools program has been a failure regarding literacy. I must admit that sometimes when I see the spelling of some tertiary graduates I am inclined to believe it, but the fact is that those schools programs have not been a failure. Today a much higher number of people, through those programs, can communicate, whether verbally or by writing. No one can deny that. Literacy has improved. The sort of campaign that has been conducted to suggest that the position is worsening is ridiculous and only inspired to return us to the good old days of the master and servant situation as far as education is concerned.

I now turn to the question of the Curriculum Development Centre. We were told that if it is abolished it will provide a saving of money to Federal revenue. Once more the gun has been held at the States to agree to contribute 50 per cent of the operating costs. What purpose does this serve? There will be a disappearance of a centre that has served a real purpose in curriculum development. If there is concern for literacy surely this is one area to which particular attention should be paid.

Whilst as members of the Opposition we do not oppose these Bills, we have our reservations about the Government's so-called attitude to equality of opportunity and freedom of choice. Financial restraints restrict those opportunities and the freedom for children who, if they come from the lower wage earning group, are already disadvantaged through the facilities that are available to them in the home. I trust that at some stage members of the Parliament will be able to sit down and talk about the sorts of national objectives in education that are needed to potentiate the human resources which are the best natural resources this country has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to have the opportunity to congratulate the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) on his maiden speech in this House. I am glad that it was on such an important topic as education. I believe his contribution to the debate was in keeping with the usual high standards that the Australian community has learnt to expect from the honourable member for Wentworth. I attended university with him in Sydney. I then worked with him in the late 1950s on the staff of a magazine called the Observer which ultimately merged with the Bulletin. The honourable member for Wentworth then became a most distinguished editor of the Bulletin magazine. I was very glad to work with him as the financial editor of that magazine for some years. I am overjoyed to see him as a member of this place and to hear the quality the contribution that he has made to the debate on this important subject of education.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now deal in detail with the burden of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, particularly the Government's commitment to provide over three years a total of $25m for capital grants for new places in non-government schools throughout Australia. I will concentrate on the problem facing the non-government school system in Australia. I am a little tired of hearing speakers opposite talk about the disadvantages suffered by lower income groups in Australia in the education system as though this disadvantage related entirely to the State school system. The bulk of the Catholic education system is directed towards providing education for the disadvantaged, lower income earning groups of this nation. It is arrant nonsense for honourable member opposite to suggest that to give any taxpayers' funds to the Catholic education system is to look after people who are privileged. The reality is that the Catholic education system operates at a resource level of only 70 per cent of the level available to the average State school. The Karmel figures on resource allocation indicate that the Catholic education system suffers a 30 per cent disadvantage. The bulk of the system provides education facilities for the lower income earning groups in our society. It is about time the Opposition stopped suggesting that the Government's provision of assistance to this section of the education system is providing something to a privileged and advantaged section of the community. That is nonsense.

Let me detail the manner in which the non-State education sytem, in particular the Catholic education system, has been subjected to a significant degree of disadvantage. Figures demonstrating the point I am making are recorded in the Schools Commission report for the triennium 1982-84 which was released last month. I draw the attention of the House to the fact that there has been a growth in the non-State system in recent times. There is no doubt about it. As a result of this Government's activities, there has been an increase in the number of enrolments and proportion of enrolments in the non-government primary school area following a degree of assistance given by this Government to that section of the education system. I point out that the recovery in that proportion, which is now 20 per cent of all enrolments, took place after a substantial fall in the number of enrolments in non-government schools which was generated under the Labor Government. In 1972, in the term of the previous coalition Government, the proportion of students who attended non-government schools in Australia at the primary level was 20 per cent. That is exactly the same as it was last year. In other words, there was a fall under Labor and there has now been a recovery. We have restored a degree of choice in education which was being diminished by the policies of the Labor Government. I think that point should be made.

There has also been a significant increase in the resources available in the State system and no doubt some increase in those available to the non-State system in terms of the number of teachers. For example, in the time span I have just mentioned, from 1972 to 1980, there was an increase in the number of State school teachers of 35 per cent. The increase in the number of non-government school teachers was only 31 per cent. The State system, which it is alleged this Government has knocked down, has increased its number of teachers at a faster rate than has the non-State system even though the proportion of students attending school in the two systems is exactly the same now as it was in 1972. To pretend that this Government's policies have massively disadvantaged the State system as against the non-State system is evidently nonsensical.

Let us look at what will happen in the future. There is no doubt that all the projections indicate a growing distaste within the community for the styles of some State schools and State school teachers. There is an increasing desire, evident in the projections, by people to exercise a greater freedom of choice to use other systems. In the Schools Commission report the lower projection for the non-government primary school enrolments, which last year accounted for about 20 per cent of all enrolments, is an increase to 21.7 per cent by 1984. The higher projection is an increase to as much as 23.8 per cent, which means that the State schools would suffer an off-setting reduction. At the secondary level the same sort of trend is expected. In 1980 26.4 per cent of students attended non-government secondary schools. The lower projection is an increase to 27.3 per cent by 1984. The higher projection is an increase to 28.5 per cent, with off-setting reductions, of course, in the State school system.

Many people might ask: 'Why are people expressing this choice?' It could well be held that the more the people of Australia see of the activities of some teachers federations around this country the more concerned they become about the level and quality of teaching and the attitudes of teachers in the State school system. The House probably does not need reminding that the New South Wales Teachers Federation got solidly behind the producers of the recently controversial homosexual kit prepared which they hoped would be distributed in New South Wales schools. The Teachers Federation got so much behind it that it threatened to sue the Federal Government if the money for the kit was withdrawn. Of course, as a result, the Federal Government, regrettably, had to provide that money. This occurred despite the fact that approval for the provision of that money was obtained by deceit. It is important to note that the Teachers Federation took a strong position requiring the Federal Government to provide the money for that homosexual kit even though approval for the money was obtained in a deceptive manner.

Let me dramatise further the disadvantage that the non-State school system has. I refer to student-teacher ratios. Once again, the position is evident from the Schools Commission report. The latest figures available are those in 1979. In government schools in the primary sector the student-teacher ratio was 20.3 per cent compared with 24.4 per cent in the Catholic school system. That indicates a massive disadvantage in the Catholic school system. Yet there are continual objections from honourable members opposite to our attempts to eliminate that disadvantage. The States are responsible for the State school system. We believe that we have an obligation to provide freedom of choice and equality of opportunity through the non-State system. Quite frankly, I would much rather the subsidies which at present are paid for each child under this Government's policy than the old system which relied much more heavily on a substantial taxation deduction. Under the old system the richer a person was the bigger deduction he got for having a child at a non-State school. That system did not provide enough assistance to the Catholic education system in particular, which, as I have already outlined, caters to a large degree for the underprivileged and lower income groups in our community.

The disadvantage which I outlined in the primary school system also obtains in the secondary school system. In 1979 government schools had a pupil-teacher ratio of 12.3 to 1 but in Catholic schools on average there were 17 pupils per teacher. This trend is evident in the total staff-pupil ratios in the government school systems too. In particular, I think it is worth pointing out the differences in the ways in which the various States run their education systems. It intrigues me when I hear many honourable members opposite and members of the New South Wales Parliament endeavouring to attack the Federal Government for a situation which is far from perfect in the New South Education system when in fact the Federal Government is obliged to adopt an even-handed approach across Australia, unless the States agree that it should not do so. Yet when we look at the New South Wales education system we find that its achievement levels under the Karmel targets are way behind those of other States, particularly Victoria.

In 1979 the student-staff ratio in New South Wales was 13.4 pupils per staff member and in Victoria the figure was only 10.9. Why are there these massive differences? For example, why is the New South Wales student-staff ratio of 13.4 so much worse than those in Tasmania, Victoria, South Australia, and so on? It seems to me that it bears a direct relationship to the manner in which the New South Wales Education Department runs its school system. Whether or not that Education Department is competent is a matter for the State education authorities. But it is a matter for us that for the past few years the New South Wales education authorities have mucked around with the allocations by the Federal Government to education in New South Wales State schools. I am only too well aware of this situation. There is a disastrous need for a third high school in my electorate. Over the past four years the Federal Government has provided enough funding for this high school to have been built, heaven knows how many times over, but the high school has not been built for the very simple reason that the State Government of New South Wales has diverted an average of $6.5m a year out of our capital funding to New South Wales for schools and into the recurrent funding area. It is entitled to do that. I regret that it is entitled to do that, and I point out to the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) that I have raised this matter several times in the past. I would be most grateful if the Federal Government could look into this matter as closely as possible.

It seems totally wrong and unfortunate that in a State such as New South Wales, which is crying out for additional capital facilities for new school buildings, particularly in rapidly developing areas such as mine, the federal money allocated for this purpose can be diverted into recurrent spending. Basically, it means that this money can be diverted into placating the demands of an aggressive and hungry Teachers Federation in New South Wales which would rather see the month spent on teachers' salaries-in other words, increasing the number of teachers-than on increasing the facilities which are so desperately needed in developing areas such as mine. When we have a choice between reducing class sizes and providing enough schools in developing areas, surely our first priority should be to provide enough schools in developing areas. It is quite evident that that priority is not supported by the New South Wales Government. Not only has it diverted $6.5m over the last four years out of its capital allocation from the Federal Government and into its recurrent spending but, I understand, it also plans to do so next year.

In the few minutes available to me I want to say briefly that there has been a lot of discussion on the question of whether or not tertiary education should be free. Many honourable members have received a lot of correspondence on this matter. Certainly criticisms have been levelled at the question of whether or not a second degree should be provided at the expense of the taxpayer or at the expense of the person seeking the degree. Many people in my electorate are in the blue collar worker category. Their prospects of sending a child to university, as I understand it, are something like seven times less than the prospects of a professional family sending a child to university. Yet these blue collar workers are required to provide through their taxation the means by which the professional people of Australia perpetuate themselves through their children by sending those children to university. It seems to me to be immoral and improper that the working people of Australia, with this seven to one imbalance, should be required to contribute to the funds of people attending university when there has been no increase whatsoever in the prospects of children of blue collar families attending university since this new free tertiary eduction system commenced. I believe that that is demonstrated in the William's report.

The best thing for us to do would be to wipe out this system, whereby we are perpetuating a professional class at the expense of the worker, and restore a system of means tested scholarships and then open exhibitions for particularly bright children to ensure that the children of working people can go to university. In particular, we should use the savings from the money being wasted because it is being spread far and wide at the moment to increase the living and other allowances available to people in the poorer income groups seeking to go to university. In this way we would do something positive to diminish that savage inbalance. I hope the Government will take that proposition on board. I believe it would be much more democratic than the present system, which works so much to the disadvantage of most of the people of Australia. Nonetheless, I strongly support the present Government's activities in the education area. I commend the Minister for his outstanding contribution in this area. He certainly has been of major support to me in my electorate and to the education systems of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence by taking up the point put by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume), which was based on a half truth. I agree with one half of that truth. There is, as he said, a 'savage imbalance' between the participation rates in tertiary education of the children of blue collar workers and children from the professional classes. My own electorate of Lalor illustrates that very clearly. In a sense, when the honourable member said that we ought to prevent that 'Robin Hood in reverse' situation where the parents of poor children subsidise the children of the rich he was really assuming that nothing can happen or will happen in the whole base of our education system to increase the participation rates of working class children. That seems to be based on a pessimism or fatalism about the future of tertiary education with which I would not want to agree.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) and will coincentrate my remarks on the States Grants (Tertiary Education) Amendment Bill. It is not adequately grasped how much access to universities and colleges of advanced education is confined to particular segments of Australian society and specific geographical regions. For example, in the Melbourne metropolitan area the provision of tertiary educational facilities is almost exclusively found in the centre, the north-east and south-east, with grossly inadequate provisions in the north-west and west. This is not confined to Melbourne. We could find a similar situation in comparable areas of Sydney, Adelaide, Brisbane and other large cities. Rural areas are similarly disadvantaged.

I have done some work in comparing educational participation rates in three Victorian federal electoral districts-my own electorate of Lalor, which is an industrial area to the west of the city, with a heavy migrant concentration; the electorate of Kooyong, a residential area in the inner eastern suburbs; and the electorate of Mallee in the north-west of Victoria, running up to the South Australian and New South Wales border. Education participation rates have an enormous cyclical influence in determining the type of community which emerges. For example, without a significant number of tertiary students it is unlikely that there will be many bookshops in an area. Without bookshops people are likely to devote their free time to television. Children are unlikely to be stimulated by books and may lose any desire to go on to higher education. They are less likely to participate in theatre, live music, and so on.

There is a cyclical process by which high education participation leads on to a wide range of skills, occupations or wages, leading on in turn to a broad demand for services, a larger range of service employment, more educational institutions which, in turn, leads on to high educational participation. So the cycle goes on. Conversely, low education participation rates lead to significant contractions in job opportunities, demands for services and demands for educational facilities.

Let me illustrate this point: The 1976 census showed that in the electorate of Kooyong 6.92 per cent of the total population had a degree or graduate diploma; in the electorate of Lalor 0.54 per cent; and in the electorate of Mallee 0.98 per cent. If we look for the number of students at universities or CAEs expressed as a percentage of people aged 17 to 24 the figure in Kooyong is 46.05 per cent, in Lalor 10.74 per cent and in Mallee 4.5 per cent. For every person in Lalor with a degree or graduate diploma there are two in Mallee and 13 in Kooyong. The census figures do not distinguish between universities and CAE students, between pass and honour students or between full time and part time students. If full time university students had been isolated in this group, there would have been a far wider discrepancy. Lalor and Mallee have educational profiles like Mississippi, Kooyong like California.

My electorate of Lalor is part of an educationally disadvantaged area or, that is, Melbourne's western suburbs with 520,000 people comprising 19 per cent of the metropolitan population but, because of the particular demographic profile of the area containing an atypically high number-perhaps 23 per cent or 24 per cent-of Melbourne's children. Melbourne has three universities-the University of Melbourne, Monash University and La Trobe University-with in 1979, a total enrolment of 38,562 students, and 19 colleges of advanced education with 45,950 students, both figures including full time and part time students. Only one tertiary educational institution is located in the western suburbs. It is the Footscray Institute of Technology-I never lose an opportunity to point out the excellent work that the institute is doing-with 2,580 students, only 3.05 per cent of Melbourne's total enrolments.

So, the west starts off with 23 per cent of Melbourne's young people and finishes up with 3 per cent of the enrolments at tertiary institutions. It is true that the Deakin University established at Geelong with 4,400 students has some students from Melbourne's west. The tragedy is that the report of the Victorian fourth university committee in 1971 concluded that there was insufficient demand in the western suburbs to support a university and recommended that priority be given to a fourth university in Melbourne's eastern region. That seemed to exhibit a depressing circularity in argument. In other words, it is said: 'If there is no institution, there is no demand; if there is no demand, there is no need for an institution. Where then is there a demand? Where there is already a high level of demand.' So the already existing structure of demand is reinforced and little is done to increase the possibilities of people in the west of Melbourne. I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard Question on Notice No. 43 and the very interesting answer given on 4 December 1980 by the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) under the heading 'Secondary and Tertiary Education'.
Leave granted.
The question and answer read as follows-
Mr Barry Jones asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

(1) Is he able to say whether, in Australian secondary education, there is (a) a high drop-out rate of 45 per cent between Years 10 and 12, (b) differing retention rates between Government, Roman Catholic and independent schools, (c) a variation in retention rates at year 12 between State systems, e.g. 32.4 per cent in NSW and 24.3 per cent in Victoria, (d) a declining proportion of students proceeding from Year 12 to higher education of 54.6 per cent in 1974 and 48.7 per cent in 1977, and (e) a variation in urban educational participation compared to rural participation; if so, what estimates have been made of the percentage of young people aged between 17 and 24 years who would have the intellectual capacity to benefit from tertiary education in Australia.

(2) Is he also able to say what proportion of Australians in the 17 to 24 years age group are actually undergoing tertiary education compared to those in (a) the United States of America, (b) Canada, (c) Japan, (d) Switzerland, (e) Norway, (f) Denmark, (g) Sweden, (h) France and (j) the USSR.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Fife

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) (a) Enrolments in Australian schools in Year 12 in 1979 were 39.6 per cent of those in Year 10 in 1977. This implies an apparent drop-out rate of 60.4 per cent between Years 10 and 12. It is an apparent, rather than true rate, because the method of calculation does not explicitly take account of net changes to the school population due to migration, nor of those students who spend more than one year in the same grade.

(b) the apparent retention rates from the first secondary year (Year 7 or Year 8) to Year 12 vary between the types of schools specified. In 1979 the respective apparent retention rates to Year 12 were:
Government schools-28.9 per cent
Catholic schools-44.1 per cent
Other Non-Government schools 87.1 per cent
Note that the above apparent retention rates are affected by transfers between types of schools, as well as by those factors mentioned in (a) above.
(c) there is variation in apparent retention rates between State systems. In 1979 the respective apparent State system retention rates to Year 12 were:
% New South Wales 39.9 Victoria(a) 23.1 Queensland 31.1 South Australia 30.8 Western Australia 28.4 Tasmania(b) 24.8 Northern Territory 22.7 Australian Capital Territory 70.5
(a) Excludes students in the Tertiary Orientation Program in Technical Schools.
(b) It is possible to obtain the Higher School Certificate either at the end of Year 11 or at the end of Year 12,

(d) of those students enrolled in Year 12 in 1973, 54.5 per cent proceeded to universities and colleges of advanced education in 1974. The corresponding proportion in relation to 1976-1977 was 48.7 per cent. It should be noted however that over this period enrolments in Technical and Further Education institutions were rising rapidly. Statistics on the proportion of Year 12 students proceeding directly on to Technical and Further Education are not available.

(e) there does appear to be a variation in urban educational participation compared to rural participation. Research studies indicate a greater retention rate to Year 12 exists in metropolitan and other urban areas than in rural areas. Once matriculation level is reached, however, the proportion which make the transition to higher education is about as high for country as for metropolitan students.
No estimates have been made of the percentage of young people aged between 17 and 24 years who would have the intellectual capacity to benefit from tertiary education in Australia.

(2) The proportion of 17 to 24 year old Australians undergoing tertiary education compared to other countries is shown in the table below. The proportions are estimates based on the latest available Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) data. Comparable data for the USSR are not available. Care should be exercised when interpreting this data. In particular the OECD statistics for Australia and the other countries listed refer only to full time students in higher education (i.e. excluding TAFE). Other factors to be considered are differences in education systems, the emphasis placed on part time education in some of the countries listed (for example, Australia), and deficiencies in the scope and coverage of the statistics. A description of how the education systems in each country are classified is contained in 'Classification of Education Systems-Summary Volume' OECD Paris 1975.
