TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. There is one point in this answer that I want to point out. I asked, amongst other things:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . what estimates have been made of the percentage of young people aged between 17 and 24 years who would have the intellectual capacity to benefit from tertiary education in Australia.
There was an uncharacteristically bleak answer from the Minister for Education. His words were:
No estimates have been made of the percentage of young people aged between 17 and 24 years who would have the intellectual capacity to benefit from tertiary education in Australia.
In other words, we do not know the degree of intellectual wastage. We do not know where it is found and we do not propose to find out. That was an extremely depressing answer from the Minister.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, on 4 December 1980 the Minister for Education gave an extremely interesting answer to a question about secondary and tertiary education. He provided some very depressing figures about the degree of wastage, that is the drop out in secondary schools from the year 7 or year 8, to year 12. There is an enormous variation in the degree of drop-outs between the three school systems. The retention rate in government schools was 28.9 per cent. In Catholic schools it was 44.1 per cent and in other non-government schools it was 87.1 per cent. In other words, more than 70 per cent of government school pupils drop out. In Catholic schools over 50 per cent drop out and in the non-Government schools-the so-called private schools-only 13 per cent drop out. There we see a perpetuation of the stratification of Australian society due to poverty in education.
—There is a class difference.

—There is a very strong class difference, and poverty in education is largely inherited. In the 1960s education was a very big issue in Australia. Part of the process of de-Whitlamisation since 1975 has been a turning away from education, a kind of complacent sense that we had gone as far as we could go in Australia. As I said in another debate last night, in 1980 the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development economic survey on Australia showed out that this country ranked fourteenth of 23 nations listed for educational retention rates for young people aged between 15 years and 19 years. The Williams report on Education, Training and Employment confirmed:

SPEECH.PARA: while 60 per cent of our 15-19 age group are in the labor force comparable figures are 24 per cent in Japan and 28 per cent in the U.S.A.

We have the paradoxical situation in Australia of the highest youth unemployment in the advanced world and also the highest youth employment. The reason that it is possible to have both figures is that we have a very much lower participation rate at the tertiary education level. Although some attempt has been made as far as Technical and Further Education is concerned to increase the actual numbers involved, it is very far from being the equivalent of full time education.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be worse when the Government introduces fees. Universities will be only for the rich then.

—If the Government introduces fees, of course, the situation will become far worse. Why have we slipped so far behind other technologically advanced nations in education? We are afflicted by a combination of ignorance, apathy and self-satisfaction-a dangerous mixture. What is the explanation for our low participation rates? I can think of three possiblities. First, Australians may be smarter than everybody else and our natural gifts do not need formal education for them to mature. The second possibility is that we are dumber than the people of comparable nations and education could not really help. Third-I suspect this is the correct answer-we are culturally so isolated and so lacking in vitality that we fail to understand that the educational revolution, aborted here, is still going on elsewhere and as a result we are slipping behind. The Williams report made it clear that there is a yawning gap between those who receive tertiary education and graduate to professional employment and those who leave school with minimal and unmarketable qualifications, with skills that are appropriate only for the contracting number of routine and repetitive jobs. The question that this nation and this Parliament have to face is: How can working class people be given access to education which maximises their skills and leads to satisfactory personal and vocational outcomes?
—Charge them fees.

—The Goverment's answer and the razor gang's answer is to charge them fees. The school is an excellent sorting machine. It classifies people and sets them apart. Just as cattle and sheep are branded, so school leaves its brand or caste mark for life. Few succeed in washing or shaking it off. If a person attends a poor school and lives in a povety striken social environment--
—He is fixed for life.

—He is fixed for life. The school system will do relatively little to overcome these disadvantages. If one is disadvantaged, school will tend to extend those disabilities through life. Cultural poverty seems to be inherited and it is extremely difficult to shake off. It is an irony that as we approach the goal in some areas or a satisfactory class-pupil ratio in conventionally equipped classrooms-a goal that has been pursued by all parties for some time-this goal may recede, turn into a mirage and prove absolutely irrelevant. The crippling effects of educational and cultural poverty are causes of and consequences of unequal access to power. The middle and upper classes have access to information and power but the working class does not. If existing economic, social or educational systems create or reinforce information poverty, then in an increasingly information-based society the degree of disability suffered by the poor must grow wider with every additional year of unequal outcomes in education. While this disparity exists it will be impossible to bring about a political redistibution of power and existing hegemonic structures must continue. The 'skill mix' shifts each year to the disadvantage of the poor. Language ability was less relevant when migrants were employed as labourers or process workers in factories, but with higher personal skills being required in sophisticated service employment, a poor command of English will disqualify many migrants from work. It is true that the Sttes Grants (Schools Assistance) Act does make some attempt to improve access to multicultural facilities, but there is a strong element of tokenism in it-not intended necessarily by the Minister for Education-but I believe that is what the effect will be.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by pointing out that there are basically two kings of educational experiences people need to cope with life. There is the education that assists the development of the inner life, the personality and there is that education that is used to strengthen the outer life. Education for inner life covers personal growth, creativity, independent thought and evaluaton, the generation of psychic income, and aesthetic factors. Education for outer life covers economic relations, employment, consumption pattern, tool using, income generation and group responses. In Australia middle class education puts a very heavy emphasis on personal development. I regret to say that in working class areas-we have heard these expressions from many Ministers, not from the Minister for Education but certainly from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner)-a tremendous emphasis in the thinking is that all that is needed in working class education are qualifications for income earning.

I think that the emphasis on personal development in middle class education in teaching languages, the arts and literature, does not inhibit employment prospects or the capacity to generate income. In fact it is quite the reverse. While consumption is the standard measure of outer life, on which we place so much emphasis, creativity and expression remain the key to inner life. The increasing tendency towards division of labour and the fragmentation of knowledge forces many people to seek fulfilment outside work, by active participation in sport, gardening, hobbies or the arts, or to suppress self-expression through increased dependence on alcohol, drugs, spectator sport and television. As the American education writer, James Coleman argued, life used to be experience-rich and stimulus poor; now it is experience-poor and stimulus rich. Culture is often perceived as an optional extra, reserved for the highly educated-the icing on the cake. Four thousand years of human history before the Industrial Revolution demonstrates how creativity and work were integrated and that the urge to make appears to be universal. Some nations have had long traditions of intense personal participation in specific cultural forms-for example, pottery, calligraphy and writing poetry in Japan; music in Hungary; and soccer in Latin America. In addition, creativity has often been associated with a happy and vigorous old age.

In working class education, highly specific training-for example, in typing and shorthand, dressmaking, cooking, woodworking and metal-working-does not necessarily guarantee employment, income or personal development. Indeed, the reverse is true. The idea that a young man's prospects could be ensured by putting a spanner in his hand, pushing him out the door and watching him go on to fame and fortune is now anachronistic, dating from the time when people were described by their function, as 'hands'. I say to the Minister that the extent of unrecognised and untapped talent in the working class in Australia remains the great unknown in Australian education. Very often we are inclined to take the patronising view that there is nothing we can do about it, that it is futile to try to expect people in working class areas to be able to aspire to a higher degree of participation in education. We tend to get that recurrent cycle--

TALK.START.PARA: —They get locked in.

—They get locked in, with low expectations. Because there are low expectations there appear to be low demands. Because are low demands poor provisions are made. That is a tragedy and the social wastage that is involved in Australia is not in this nation's interest. I urge that before the Minister comes back with his next Bill he asks the Schools Commission to examine the principles on which it is operating to make sure that the educational participation is truly democratic and pluralist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week the people of Australia witnessed some of the most reprehensible actions yet taken by the Fraser Government. Given this Government's continuing shameful record, I put to the House that that is, indeed, a mouthful. Nevertheless, I stand by it. I think the actions of last week really add to the total shame of this Government. Last week the Government cut, slashed, shaved, revised, eliminated and sold off. These were the themes of last week. Since Australia is, by any standard, one of the world's most prosperous and most affluent countries and certainly one of the major trading powers, one can only ask why. Have we gone crazy; has the manic obsession of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) with deficits and with getting his own way pushed him past the point of reason? Affluence has changed Australia, at least under this Government. We were once a country of adventurous and radical people deeply concerned with social rights. We have changed to a conservative country, more deeply concerned with preserving the standard of living of the haves, with great regard for the have-nots both in and out of Australia. Under this Government, overseas aid to developing countries, to countries in our area, the Third World countries with a shamefully low standard of living has almost disappeared. I instance, he cutting off of aid to Vietnam. Surely we owe the Vietnamese people some assistance. This has not been so under this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to come back to the new health care proposals. The changes to the health scheme announced last week and the recommendations of the Lynch razor gang together amount to little other than a second Budget and can be regarded only as a part of an overall move by this Government to opt out completely of its responsibility to the States and to the Australian people. No longer is this Government prepared even to pretend that it is providing services to the Australian people in return for their taxes. It now intends simply to collect the taxes and tell the people to look to State governments or to private enterprise to provide the services. All this has been done in the name of smaller government. The Prime Minister has embraced the term 'smaller government' as his philosophy and quotes it as if it were holy writ. What is this smaller government that the Prime Minister is always talking about? The Government's total expenditure on the public sector has been running at 38.8 per cent of total government outlays. The great inroads into this figure and the much heralded cuts in government expenditure produced by the razor gang will reduce government spending in the public sector by all of 0.4 per cent, when it is running at 38.8 per cent. I remind honourable members that during the period of the Whitlam Government which was widely criticised by the then Opposition for encouraging big government and for letting growth in the Public Service run wild, total government expenditure in the public sector was only 36 per cent, less than this Government's expenditure even after the effects of the razor gang have been taken into account. So much for this Government's rhetoric about small government.

But there was a strange manifestation this week. I am sure honourable members can recall that when tax indexation was introduced it was presented by the Prime Minister as a means of keeping government honest and small, to stop its spending rising in line with the inflation fed expansion of Commonwealth Government income tax collection. By abolishing tax indexation the Prime Minister has cynically abandoned any notion of small government. But to do so in the same week as the razor gang reported is simply an insult to common sense. It is a ludicrous state of affairs.

What the Government did last week in reneging on its responsibility for health care and in cutting government services is just a continuation of its general philosophy of creating an even wider division between the wealthy and those who have to bear the burden for the wealthy-the low and middle income earners. The Prime Minister, like a latter day Otto Niemeyer, might I suggest, would have us believe that everyone in Australia must be prepared to make sacrifices for the good of the economy; that we all have to pull our belts in a little, including you, Mr Deputy Speaker, which might be a decent problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I trust that is not a reflection on the Chair?

—No, sir, only on the expansion of your personality. We all have to pull in our belts a little, even me. To use the Prime Minister's much quoted expression, life was not meant to be easy for any of us. I wonder what the vast majority of low and middle income earners in this country feel when they see wealthy professionals all around them employing smart accountants to develop schemes by which they can avoid paying taxes or when they read in the papers about people such as Mr Robert Holmes a'Court cooly paying out $800,000 for a racehorse at the recent yearling sales. Obviously life was not meant to be easy for that type of privileged person! When the Government with its much-vaunted cuts has been able to shave a miniscule part of government expenriture, it is strange that people such as Robert Holmes a'Court, who can pay almost half a million dollars for a racehorse, can manage, as he has in the last few years, to amass a total of $59m tax free because the Government will not close the loopholes or will not introduce some form of tax on wealthy people such as him who are leaving the working class of Australia to pick up the tab for the Government's expenses.

SPEECH.PARA: There was another strange manifestation in Sydney last week. The Lend Lease corporation sold Australia Square, a rather prominent building in the middle of our city, for a nice tax free profit of $50m. I wonder what the taxpayers earning $9,000 or $10,000 a year think about that when they are asked to dip their hand into their pocket every week. If the razor gang wanted to do something why did it not do something in that area? It is not the Holmes a'Courts of this world who will be disadvantaged by the Government's dismantling of the health scheme or by cuts imposed by the razor gang. Those who bear the brunt of the Government's policies will be those people struggling to raise a family on a low wage and who are now forced to find several hundred extra dollars a year to pay for health insurance.

Perhaps we might think of hard working public servants whose jobs have been placed in jeopardy by a Government whim. It is easy enough to deal savage blows against these people with the stroke of a pen. This Government ignores the human suffering which these changes will entail. What the cuts in the Public Service mean is this: Not only are 17,000 jobs under threat but also public servants, those people who serve the public, will have less time to spend on their tasks. They will have less research back-up, less training and development and so we will have a less able, a less open, a less informed, a less innovative and a less compassionate administration. Is this really a step forward for society in Australia in 1981? Could members of the Government really justify that as a step forward? Is this what the Prime Minister wants? Does he want a situation in which the more affluent we become the more selfish we become?

If we look at the changes to the health scheme as an example of the hardships the Government is imposing on ordinary people we find that there has been a return to the pre-Medibank dark ages of the 1960s. I am sure that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), who is at the table, would not be proud to be the present Minister for Health. I am sure that he is happy he is now the Minister for Transport and does not have to preside over these sorts of health cuts. In the 1960s the people were forced into health schemes or else ran the risk of facing huge hospital bills if they were unlucky enough to become ill. Is that the way that life runs in Australia in 1981? Should life be a lottery for people who are too poor or whose income is so low that paying into a health insurance fund becomes a hardship? Do these people have to live life like a lottery hoping that they or their kids will not get sick?

To make matters worse the Government has slashed its overall funding of health care, forcing the States to find the necessary finance to keep their hospitals from closing. The people of New South Wales, which happens to be your State, and my State, Mr Deputy Speaker, are probably more fortunate than others in this respect because they at least have a sympathetic State government and a Premier who refuses to bow to the pressure placed upon him by the Federal Government to impose a second income tax. Nevertheless, money for health care has to come from somewhere and New South Wales will have to find some $150m extra this year in order to meet its health commitments. Obviously, hospital fees will have to rise dramatically and, in fact, it was announced today that hospital bed costs will rise from $50 to $80 a day in New South Wales. This increase will be passed on to individuals in the form of greatly increased health insurance contribution rates.

I read an article in the Sydney Sun Herald over the weekend in which I noticed that the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) was questioned about the liklihood of increased health contributions. He said that that would be a matter for the States to determine. In this, as in everything else, the Government is ignoring its part in causing the problem and is pushing the responsibility for the inevitable cost increases on to the States. The Feds committed the crime and they are simply using the States as scapegoats. Who is going to benefit from the changes to the health scheme? Certainly not the State governments and certainly not individual Australians. Those who will benefit from the Government's action will be the shareholders of the health insurance schemes, who will reap a bonanza from a vastly expanded membership, the owners of private hospitals and the doctors. The high income earners of our society will be the beneficiaries, not the men and women struggling to bring up children on low incomes in places such as the western suburbs of Sydney, which I represent, or the western suburbs of Melbourne.

Health care is just one area where ordinary people will suffer. If we look at the Lynch report we can see many more areas where suffering will occur. The Government claims that in making the cuts that it has set out in the Lynch committee's report it has merely trimmed off those services which were not an appropriate field of government activity. What will happen instead, though, is that huge gaps will now be created in services such as nutrition research, preventive medicine and education innovation simply because government is the only body interested in those areas. Private enterprise just will not fill those gaps. The Government pulls out of those fields because there is no profit to be made in them. Inevitably, private enterprise will not fill those gaps. The big sufferers are the public and the country as a whole.

The Lynch report has advocated the elimination of 17,000 Public Service jobs. The Government claims that this will be achieved largely through natural wastage. People who leave the Public Service simply will not be replaced. This is all very well. However, the people who leave will be those who have the brightest prospects in private enterprise. It is precisely those people who have represented the cream of the Public Service who will be most tempted to leave a service where morale is low and rewards poor to seek brighter opportunities elsewhere. This will leave a dispirited Public Service lacking in talent, overworked and unable to cope with the demands of those they should be serving-members of the public. Already government departments are finding it difficult to cope with inadequate staffing levels, morale within the Public Service is generally low and the public is forced to endure delays in its dealings with government offices. The effect of even greater staff cuts will be devastating.

In the few moments left to me I would like to refer to a problem within my own electorate. In 1973 the then Whitlam Government purchased a block of land in Parrmatta at a cost of something like $5m with the intention of building a Commonwealth office building on that site. The rationale behind that was not just the housing of public servants in a building owned by the Government, by the people, but the many social benefits inherent in it. Anybody with a knowledge of town planning believes that to get the public servants away from the centre of Sydney and out into the areas where they live is a social advantage. They are saved from the problems of travelling for an hour a day and the cost of transport, and from the inherent problems of clogged roads and over-utilised trains in which they travel to the city.

The building started by the Whitlam Government included some very necessary community facilities which are very much need in my city. As soon as this Government came to power in January 1976 building was stopped and the plan was shelved. Since then the project has languished. A few months ago I was optimistic because the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) visited Parramatta and encouraged us to believe that the Government might be about to make a decision to build. However, no decision has yet been made, and I noticed in the Lynch report that funds have been cut for government buildings already started in Adelaide and Townsville. Also, in one bland statement it was stated that surplus Commonwealth land would be sold, and I fear that that might be the prospect for the land in Parramatta. Obviously, the Government would get a big profit because the land is now worth about $20m. I dare say that land in Parramatta is under great threat.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does Tom Uren think?

—Someone mentioned the honourable member for Reid. I add also that I have noticed that the Glebe Estate is now on offer to the New South Wales Government. I hope that that Government will take over the Estate. The purchase of the Glebe Estate was one of the great achievements of the Whitlam Government. This area of old homes was bought, the houses were restored, and the traditional residents of Glebe have been able to stay there. It would be a dreadful tragedy if this land were passed over to private enterprise.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) outlining the Government's review of Commonwealth functions. The Opposition has adopted a very curious position on the Government's expenditure reduction policy. It seems to want to have a bob each way. It spent all of the last election campaign criticising us for being a party of big government expenditure and high taxes. It was certainly curious to hear the socialists criticise the Government on those grounds. In fact, the socialist party almost won the last election by criticising the Liberal Party for being the big government, high tax party. On philosophical grounds at least, that was a curious position for Opposition members to adopt. Therefore, it is also curious that they should now criticise the Government for trying to redress the imbalance by moving towards smaller government and lower taxes-the very things they seemed to espouse during the last campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is even more curious when we read of the socialist party's own position regarding the public sector and taxation. Its position seems to depend on whether it is in government or opposition and whether it is approaching an election. For example, last week the Leader Opposition (Mr Hayden) severely criticised the Government for reducing the Government sector in order to allow the more productive private sector to expand. Yet in 1975, when the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer, he said:
We expect that as the expansion of public sector activity is restrained, the opportunities for private sector expansion will improve.
When in opposition, and well removed from any election, the Leader of the Opposition said when talking about the desirability of getting lower taxes in Australia:
This sort of approach strikes directly at the democratic socialist notion that equality and equity can only be assured by a stronger public sector.
In 1978, also far removed from any election, the shadow Treasurer said that a future Labor government would:
. . . face a mammoth task in rebuilding the public sector and an equally mammoth task in convincing the electorate that it should pay a higher level of tax to enable us to do so.

It seems to me that the ALP is all over the place on this issue. It has different views at different times and seems to be guided more by votes and political expediency than by high principle. If the Labor Party is now suggesting that we should have tax cuts but no expenditure cuts then it basically is advocating its old economic policies of massive deficit blowouts, to be financed either by printing more money and causing inflation, or by going into massive debt, causing interest rate hikes and placing future generations of Australians in debt because we, the present generation, decided to live beyond our means.

The basic reason for the present cuts is to reduce the overall public sector borrowing requirement which has been a major cause of the interest rate rises in Australia. The fact remains that governments have to either tax or axe if they are to have responsible Budgets. If that is not done government expenditure rises. Any government expenditure increases that is not financed either by taxes or borrowings simply leads to more inflation. The ALP still clings to the old economic doctrines in accusing this Government of increasing unemployment to control inflation. The shadow Treasurer said this very recently when commenting on the latest consumer price index increase. The Leader of the Opposition still seems to share that belief. Yet in 1975 the Leader of the Opposition, the then Treasurer, said:
Today it is inflation itself which is the central policy problem. More inflation simply leads to more unemployment.

Once again, there is no consistency in ALP economic policy. It just happens to be convenient from time to time for it to change its policies to meet the political demands of the moment. This Government has been criticised for being harsh. People have said that the razor gang decisions will cause more unemployment. I think that the Press comment in this regard has been most interesting. Many editorials have criticised the Government for not going far enough, but they have agreed that the nation would be better off for the trend established by these cuts. The Australian Financial Review last Friday stated that there will not be wholesale redundancy of public servants. It made the point that the staff reductions of about 17,000 people would be achieved by, to use its own terms, natural wastage, resignation, retirements and lower recruitment.

To suggest that decreasing government expenditure will increase unemployment ignores the fact that such expenditure is financed by taxes. Higher taxes simply mean that people have less to spend and therefore businesses have less to sell and must reduce their costs and levels of operation, including their levels of employment. The Labor Party obviously has forgotten its own experience in government, when record increases in government expenditure led to record increases in unemployment. It tried to explain its poor economic performance in terms of depressed international economic conditions rather than in terms of its own domestic mismanagement. At the present time, with depressed international conditions, the policies of this Government of expenditure restraint and reduced deficits have led to a situation where almost every economic indicator available shows that we in Australia now have a stronger economy than almost any other country in the industrialised world.

Employment levels over the past two years-years of government expenditure restraint-have risen substantially. Labour force figures released this week show that total employment rose by 146,900 in the year to March 1981 and by 328,500 in the last two years, with the overall position of school leavers improving strongly. Certainly, unemployment is still too high, but at least we are making some progress on this very pressing problem. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) today issued some more figures which state the unemployment situation in April. He said:
. . . preliminary unemployment estimates released today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics were the best figures since the monthly surveys were introduced in February 1978.
The Minister further stated:
. . . the estimated total of . . . people unemployed and looking for full time work was the lowest April figure recorded.

To suggest, therefore, that in economic terms expenditure cuts are both heartless and incorrect policy completely ignores not only economic sense but also the facts of recent economic history, both in Australia and overseas. Surely the latest employment figures and the soundness of our major economic indicators suggest not an abandoning of our policies of expenditure restraint but a strengthening of these policies as outlined in the Prime Minister's speech. I cannot see how these results indicate a harch policy or one lacking compassion. There was no mention of hitting the needy in the welfare area, and neither should there be any mention of that. Surely this policy is the only one which offers a humane, longer term approach to our major economic and social problems. It has already led to better economic performance and to more employment. What is harsh about that? What is harsh about increasing the capacity of the Government, through these cuts, to increase its manoeuvrability by giving it the option of moving towards a combination of lower taxes and/or a concentration of more resources on the really needy sections of society? This is a flexibility which the Government did not have before these cuts were announced. These cuts have proved that the capacity of the Government to move in these directions can be increased without in any way placing increased burdens on the welfare sector.

I believe the Government can do much more in this direction. For example, we should now decide not to proceed with the construction of a new and permanent parliament house and, similarly, we should look at some of the more extravagant fringe benefits enjoyed by members of this Parliament. In this context I want to stress to the House the importance of the present public perception of members and senators of all parties. I think some cynicism and scepticism about elected representatives is a good and healthy thing but my own contact with my electorate indicates that there is a belief-rightly or wrongly, it does not matter-that we as the elected representatives confer benefits upon ourselves quickly, generously, unobtrusively and with unanimity but, at the same time, expect others in the public sector to accept restraints and cuts. I believe it is important that the cuts involve an equal bearing of the sacrifice by all sections of the public sector, including ourselves. If this program of public sector cuts, which I support, is to have credibility and gain the degree of public acceptance we require, we should apply to ourselves the same standards we apply to others in the community.

I want to refer to the new parliament house which, at present, is expected to cost in excess of $300m at current prices. Certainly that figure will grow. Within my own party I have long been opposed to the construction of this building. I believe it is now appropriate, given the Government's report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, to restate this view because, after all, it took some 350 decisions of the so-called razor gang to save something like $560m worth of taxpayers' funds. With one decision not to proceed with the new parliament house we could effect savings equal to 40 per cent of that total amount achieved by the razor gang. When the decision to proceed with the new parliament house was made it was said that it would provide the nation with a sense of national identity, a sense of national pride, that it would be a memorial to parliamentary democracy, and so forth. Very lavish phrases and many superlatives were thrown about. I reject that proposition on several grounds. Firstly, the integrity of parliamentary democracy or the achieving of a sense of national pride does not depend on bricks and mortar-it depends on what happens inside that building; it depends on the quality of government and the dignity of the members of parliament who sit within that building.

The second point I make relates to some of the other major projects in the Australian Capital Territory which are being shelved at the moment, such as the national museum. The point is that most of my constituents in Perth, and most residents of Western Australia, because of our isolation and the present structure of air fares in this country, are denied the opportunity to visit and see these so-called national buildings which their taxes have helped to build. I sometimes think that some of these things, such as the National Art Gallery and national museums, ought to be built in some of the more populous centres of this country.

The third point I make in regard to the new parliament house is that the building we occupy now is an historic building and with some minor additions, and some changes to our present Standing Orders, it could certainly suit our foreseeable needs. As I said earlier, I extend my argument in this regard to include also certain fringe benefits enjoyed by members of parliament, particularly those benefits which have no real influence on how well we do our jobs. I mention the need to restrict members' fringe benefits not because they constitute major public expenditure savings; they do not. It is not a matter of dollars and cents. I raise the matter because some action ought to be taken in those areas if we, as members of parliament, wish to apply expenditure restraints in other areas of the public sector and in so doing maintain credibility and some degree of public acceptance for these expenditure cuts.

I support the concept embraced in the statement by the Prime Minister last Thursday. It is in accord with every major strand of economic thinking by respectable bodies overseas. Within Australia there have been many comments in support of this strategy. I would like to quote from the latest monthly publication of ANZ Bank Business Indicators. That publication said:
The outstanding feature of the Australian economy is the lift now occurring in private sector demand and in total employment.
It goes on to explain rises in consumption expenditure and the massive increases in private investment expenditure in Australia, and then states:

This expansion by the private sector should lift the flow of revenue to Government. At the same time it should also obviate the need for direct Government involvement in stimulating economic activity . . . In particular, the growth in private sector economic activity should provide scope for some reduction in the growth of Government spending without adversely affecting total economic activity. Considering present and expected growth in total investment expenditure, it would be desirable for the Government to lessen its demands in order to maintain an economic environment conducive to further abatement in the rate of inflation.

On economic grounds, responsible management grounds and compassionate grounds I believe the decisions of this committee of review announced last Thursday are responsible and in the best long term interests of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is in response to the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to Parliament last Thursday on the Review of Commonwealth Functions. We are told that this review had as its aims the streamlining and fining down of Commonwealth operations, partly by withdrawing from functions more appropriately handled by the States or private enterprise and partly by rationalising the functions which properly belong to the Commonwealth. The Prime Minister went on further to say that the aim of the review in the wider perspective was to establish the conditions under which there can be increased opportunities for all and better care for those in need. To complete the scenario of the results of the review's findings, one needs to read to the end of page 3 of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: If one did not know our Prime Minister and those who support him, or at least sit behind him, one would think that those who sit on the Government benches really had the interests of all Australians at heart. But we know differently. What has been written in this review is fairy story stuff and is unworthy of being espoused by this Government. The speech writers who prepared the scenario should be writing for Disneyland or the Hanna-Babrera organisation, because they are writing about matters affecting Australians of which their political masters could not care less.

The Government has expressed the view that there should be small government and increased activity taken up by the private sector with the object of creating employment opportunities and of giving people a greater say over their lives. Hence, we have seen a series of attacks on the Public Service and the public sector by this Government over recent months, culminating in the decision to reduce public services as outlined in the review document. In so doing, the Government is taking a typical Milton Friedman attitude. Friedman holds that such services are relentlessly in conflict with liberty and that the market accords to the individual the sovereignty of choice, whereas the state, as it endarges it services, curtails or impairs that choice. But its acceptance of a large Public Service and a protective role for the state, democracy commits itself to an irreversible descent into totalitarianism and communism. Professor Friedman is firm about this prospect, and has stated:

If we continue our present trend and our free society is replaced by a collective society, the intellectuals who have done so much to drive us down this path will not be the ones who run the society; the prison, the insane asylum, or the graveyard would be their fate . . . or shall we have the wisdom and the courage to change our course, to learn from experience, and to benefit from a rebirth of freedom.

Obviously Government members have been made disciples of Milton Friedman's theories because what they are proposing has a marked similarity. The Government had best beware as there are grave disadvantages in being associated with a policy that will not work. It should be noted that this arch exponent of monetarism, Professor Friedman, has already been forced to disassociate himself from Israel and Chile where he was once celebrated as a prophet. The Friedman policy in Britain has so far produced only high inflation, deep internal stagnation, the highest unemployment since the Great Depression and some indication that he would like to be detached from these policies as well. I believe the Government is misreading both the economic signs and the political signs in taking the actions outlined in the review and by reducing the public sector community involvement. The policies of smaller government espoused by the Thatcher and Reagan administration have not worked and will not work.

The attack which we see on the public sector at the present time is a generalised attack. Education, urban services and other conventional functions of government as well as assistance to the sick, public housing funding, assistance to the unemployed and the unemployable and other government enterprises are all under attack. We are told that people must be left free to choose. The divesting of government activities to private enterprise is supposed to supposed to create a greater freedom of choice, more employment, economic growth and a better life for all. In putting forward such theories, of course, the Government is pretending that the giant financial institutions and multinational corporations do not exist. These corporations control and govern the world economy-not governments. These corporations have the power to set prices and to create employment or unemployment, whichever suits their need, from country to country. They influence extensively the taste of consumers and, similarly, they organise their supplies of raw materials. With all of this influence these corporations erode the power of the market.

Does anyone suggest that corporations such as the Bank of America, Shell, IBM, Philips, Exxon and Esso do not have a great influence on the finances and market forces of Australia? It is because of these influences that the Government's policies will not work. The disbandment of the Prices Justification Tribunal will make it even more difficult to control any excesses. It needs to be remembered that the abolition of the Prices Justification Tribunal will not be welcomed by the rural industry also. Inquiries into stevedoring, woolbroking charges, spare parts and fuel prices all save primary producers a lot of money. The National Farmers Federation recently said that PJT recommendations meant a $43.5m saving on fuel prices for primary producers alone.

I will now turn my attention to some of the more specific matters outlined in the Review of Commonwealth Functions. One of the hardest hit areas is that of education. In that area we have seen monetary reductions over a wide range of activities. The first item is to restrict the opportunity for persons over 19 years of age to receive a Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance while doing their Higher School Certificate through the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme. This is a miserly decision as not more than 2,000 persons throughout Australia took advantage of the scheme during 1980. Many of the people who were unable to complete their HSC during their school life saw this as the only opportunity to better themselves in later life. Similarly, the decision to introduce fees for students undertaking second degree or diploma courses in universities and colleges of advanced education is obviously only the thin edge of the wedge for the eventual reintroduction of fees for all levels of courses.

Over a period of many years this country has established a proud record in the availability of free education which has enabled all persons, including young people, irrespective of their financial background, the opportunity of education so that they can procure a better standard of living for themselves and their families. Education must never be linked to the financial standing of individuals. The restriction of payment of TEAS allowances to those persons required to live away from home by reason of geography or home conditions means that the only students eligible will be those from country locations. At the present time the scheme is a joke as the majority of students receiving the allowance come from country locations. Because of the fact that their families usually operate under income splitting schemes this allows them to be satisfactorily means tested so that they receive the benefit.

The supposed rationalisation of colleges of advanced education will do nothing but reduce the effectiveness of these colleges. In New South Wales those hit the hardest are those located in the heavily populated areas where the need is greatest. The Milperra College of Advanced Education, which is within my electorate, is one of those affected. The population of the region served by this college is as large as that of South Australia. It is the only college in the south-western region of Sydney-the fastest growing metropolitan area in any part of Australia. The college has 800 students' 62 on the academic staff and 62 non-academic staff. The college conducts a great many courses including those concerned with teacher education, multicultural education, career education, social welfare and the arts. Should that college be amalgamated, it would deprive access to tertiary education to 20 per cent of those students because of travel problems. It may be of interest to note that few of the colleges of advanced education in the country were affected. For instance, the Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education, which is in the electorate of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony), has not been the subject of any cuts of the razor gang. If one has seen this college one would say that it should be the first to be affected. So much for rationale and fairness!

Another area to suffer from the Government's decision is Aboriginal affairs. The cruel reductions by the Government have seen the percentage of the national Budget spent on the recovery of Aboriginal Australians reduced from 0.9 per cent in 1974-75 to 0.6 per cent in 1980-81-a reduction of over 30 per cent in the six years of this Fraser Government. The hopes concerning the lives of these, our fellow Australians, have been dashed once again-just after their hopes had been raised in the early 1970s by a caring and sympathetic Labor Government. It makes the policy of self-determination impossible because they are being denied the resources necessary for management. This is not good enough for the Aboriginal men, women and children who should be treated as equal partners in the development of our great country.

The 44 pages of the Prime Minister's statement made no commitment to the future but instead showed that the Government had opted out of significant areas of government responsibility. It has no mandate from the people for doing so. I suggest that the Australian people will not support the supposed free enterprise government for much longer because they will come to realise between now and the next election that this Government has abrogated its responsibilities to others rather than pursuing a course of providing incentives and assistance to those in our coummunity who are most in need of them. In those important areas of education, health, job-creation, pensioner benefits, housing and urban transportation, the Government has failed the people of Australia.

The Government's cynical exercise of cutting back on necessary welfare areas so that it can give some rebates in direct taxation payments in 1982-83-just prior to the next election-whilst increasing indirect taxes, will not be accepted by the Australian electorate because this Government has lost its credibility. The big difference between members sitting on this side of the House and those on the Government side is that we care about people. We care about their quality of life, the type of world that they live in and the type of world that their children will grow up in. We believe the benefits derived from the resources of this great country should be shared amongst the people of Australia. We have always held to those principles in the past and will hold to them in the future because we belong to a party of principle. We believe only governments can ensure that people receive their rightful share of a country's wealth and that they are cared for in time of need. We do not believe the private sector can ensure those things.

The private sector friends of this Government do not have a good record in corporate responsibility or public service. In fact, the oppsite is the case. Hardly a day goes past without one of its corporate colleagues being arrainged for corporate crime. Today's Sydney Morning Herald records the fact that a friend of this Government and, I understand, a former Treasurer of the Country Party, Harry M. Miller, is to go for trial on 22 charges for breaches of the Crimes Act or the Securities Industry Act following the collapse of the theatre booking agency, Computicket Australia Pty Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was appointed to a number of boards by this Government.

—That is correct. He was appointed to those boards by this Government. These friends of the Government put our former bushrangers to shame. Yet it is to these people that the Government is saying that we should entrust our future. I have no doubt that the unprincipled activities of this Government will be fairly judged by the people of Australia at the next election when a Labor government, dedicated to improving the quality of life for Australians, will be elected. The people of Australia will not forget the way in which this Government has deceived them by its constant breaking of election promises since it took office in 1975. This Government of deceit and deception, which now lies in tatters, should resign and let the people of Australia decide what type of government they want.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was intrigued by the speech of the honourable member for Banks (Mr Mountford). He implied throughout his speech that the Federal Government and, I assume, the State governments should increase their spending for various types of public enterprise. I suppose to the electors in the electorate of Banks and other electorates held by Labor representatives that might seem to be terribly attractive. Nowhere in the speech by the honourable member for Banks or, for that matter in speeches by other Opposition members, was the correlation made that increases in public spending also mean increases in taxes. Governments can spend only the moneys they take from the people in taxes. If the Australian Labor Party advocates that governments should increase expenditure, for what ever reason they are also saying that they should take more money in taxes so that they can spend it. If the Labor Party is the party of principle and honesty it claims to be why do not its members tell the people that if they are to spend more money they will also take more from them in taxes? If they are going to be honest, they have to admit that.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us refer to some of the things that the Australian Labor Party would do if it were given the opportunity to govern. I refer to what the Labor Party said at its conference held in Adelaide in July 1979. It said:
Labor is committed by its Platform to 'an expanded interventionist role by Government, and a responsible development of the public sector to satisfy social needs and provide employment'.

What the Labor Party is advocating and what it was charged to carry out by that conference in Adelaide, rather than a reduction in the size of government and the taxes that are taken by government from the people, is an expansion of the role of government to involve itself in the private lives of individuals throughout Australia. In order to do that it was also charged to take more taxes from the people. It was committed to do that by the conference in Adelaide. It will do it in a number of ways.

I cannot go through all the motions passed at the Adelaide conference but I will inform the people of Australia about some of them. Let us look at the Labor Party's health policy for a start. The most discredited policy that was implemented by the Labor Government during the years 1972 to 1975 without doubt was the Medibank policy. It cost this country more than it could possibly afford. It pushed health costs through the roof. We are still paying the price of that policy. This Government, through announcements made last week by the Minsiter for Health (Mr MacKellar) has finally decided to bite the bullet and break down the final vestiges of that Medibank policy. All I can say is that it is five years too late. What would the Labor Party do if it got back into office? Again I refer to its conference in Adelaide in 1979. It was stated:
The new ALP Platform states that 'A Federal Labor Government will introduce a universal health scheme to be financed by an income related contribution . . .'

It is proposed to return to its discredited policies of 1972 to 1975 and reintroduce Medibank. It could not be afforded by the people of Australia then and it cannot be afforded by them now. The Labor Party is proposing to impose such tax burdens on this country as cannot possibly be afforded. I can only assume that I have hit a very raw nerve with Opposition members who are trying to interject. I leave it to my friends in the Opposition to contemplate the truth of what I am telling them at this stage. Let us pass on from the Labor Party's health policy. What else would it do if it were given the opportunity of governing? I return to the Adelaide conference. Let us look at the Labor Party's policy on oil and mineral exploration. What would it do? At the conference it was stated:
Labor will establish an Australian Hydrocarbon corporation, a Government owned fully-integrated oil company.

It was proposing to spend $1,000m, based on estimates at that time, in socialising all our oil and mineral exploration. Can this country accept socialised exploitation of our mineral wealth at a time when the Australian people are demanding tax cuts? It is simply not possible. What it illustrates is that the Labor Party has not learnt its lessons of 1972 to 1975. It is intent on expanding the role of government in the community and charging more in taxes to do so. This Government, on the other hand, is intent on reducing the role of government in the community and, as a consequence, reducing the taxation burden on the Australian community.

There is only one thing wrong with the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions presently being debated, that is that it does not go far enough. The report proposes very good policies on the part of this Government, but it must be only a starting point for other things to follow at a later stage. The report presented by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) proposes that there be a reduction of 17,000 public servants. Why only 17,000? Why not get rid of a whole lot of dead wood in the Public Service and, more particularly, in the statutory corporations that this country can well do without? The taxpayers cannot afford to keep those public servants in their cushy jobs. I wonder whether my friends in the Opposition have studied some of the statements made by a former respected member in this place, Mr Clyde Cameron. Do they know what his comments were about feather-bedded public servants? They are defying that respected former member of this House and saying that we should continue to feather-bed them. I do not believe we should. I do not think the Australian community can afford to do so any more.

I ask why we are reducing the Public Service by only 17,000 people. Why are we not looking further into the statutory corporations? The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations suggested that there are 260 statutory corporations employing about two-thirds of the public servants in this country. Why has not more been done to reduce the number of employees of those statutory corporations in the light of that Senate Committee report? It highlighted the dead wood and the inefficiency within those statutory corporations. More should have been done to weed out the dead wood in that element of the Public Service. I have mentioned previously that whilst I believe that the report that has been brought down by the Government is a good report, and it is heading in the right direction, it simply does not go far enough. The honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous), who has migrated from Greece, is trying to interject. Perhaps his former country is socialised but we do not want socialisation in this country.

The report is a direct response to the Coombs report presented in this chamber by the Whitlam Government. The Coombs report suggested a whole range of measures through various departments socialising all the activities throughout the Australian commercial world. It suggested ways of doing that. The Whitlam Government mercilessly pursued the suggestions made in the Coombs report. The report we have before us reverses the trend that was put in train by the Coombs report. There is only one thing wrong with this action of the Government and that is that it is five years too late. We should have done this in 1976 when we first took office.

There are still further things which I believe the Government should do. We should be cutting back further on our Public Service. I cannot understand why in this report there is a notation against the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet which states: 'The staff interchange program will be expanded'. Does it mean that staff will be transferred from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet or does it mean that staff will be transferred into that Department?

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think?

—I do not know. If it means that staff are to be transferred into the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet I would strongly oppose that. I do not believe that Department should be expanded beyond it present size.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to deal with a few other areas where I believe the Government should also have cut back further. I cannot justify the continuance of the Industrial Relations Bureau. I believe it should have been scrapped and we should have reverted to the former Industrial Inspectorate. The Industrial Relations Bureau has not justified its continued existence in the light of criticisms that have been directed at it not only by the trade union movement but also by employers and all others in the field of industrial relations. I strongly urge the Government at the earliest possible opportunity to scrap the Industrial Relations Bureau and to go back to the former Industrial Inspectorate.

I believe the Government should have done far more to cut back on the irresponsible spending by the State governments. We have reached a stage where spending by State government is very much in the limelight. The present Federal Government cannot be expected to cut back its expenditure and, in the process of so doing, reduce the burden on the taxpayers of Australia while the State governments continue to spend taxpayers' money in an irresponsible and cavalier fashion. That cannot be done. If there is to be a reduction in taxpayers' charges and a reduction in the role and the involvement of the Government then the States also have to play their part. We cannot justify State premiers simply screaming poverty when they come to Canberra, expecting the Federal Government to bail them out of their economic problems, and then charging back to their home States and spending taxpayers' money irresponsibly on the basis that they have not been charged with raising that money from the taxpayers. This raises two propositions. Either the State governments must be more responsive to the directions of the Federal Government's policy proposals, in cutting back the size of their involvement and their Public Service, or they must take far more responsibility in raising their revenue by way of taxes. The Premiers cannot have the best of both worlds simply by coming to Canberra, screaming poverty, wanting more money and then going back to their home States and spending it in a totally irresponsible manner.

I think this Government should go a little further. I strongly recommend that the Government divest itself of more involvement with statutory corporations and other areas of public enterprise. I cannot justify government intervention or involvement in any form of commercial practice or activity. I do not need to go any further than to instance Trans-Australia Airlines. TAA has been shown to be grossly inefficient-far less efficient than its private enterprise competitor. The Government has taken a decision to turn TAA into a private company. I disagree with the Government in that I believe that the shares in TAA should not be offered either in majority or in total to public subscription. I do not believe it is the role of the Government to maintain an interest, let alone, a controlling interest, in a commercial enterprise such as TAA. When the company is established I strongly urge the Government to offer all the shares for private subscription.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the things that I noticed about the speech of the honourable member for Wilmot (Mr Burr) was his generalisations-broad sweeping statements. He said that there were 2,000 statutory authorities; that half of them should be done away with. Members of this Parliament, irrespective of which side of the House they sit, usually know their own areas and their own electorates best. If the honourable member knows of Commonwealth services in his electorate then he should name which of those services he considers should be discontinued. If his State is receiving government assistance then he should stand up and name those areas of assistance that he thinks are exorbitant. The facts are that the last three years he has spent half his time in the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) trying to get greater levels of government assistance for his electorate and his State--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I would be grateful if the honourable member for Corio would give me another 15 minutes to outline--
—Order! Does the honourable member for Wilmot have a point of order?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I beg your pardon. At an appropriate time I will claim to have been misrepresented.
—I suggest that the honourable member wait for an appropriate time.

—Every honourable member in this House knows of the successful efforts which were made to get freight equalisation and other benefits for Tasmania. I am sure that the apple growers and potato growers of New South Wales are complaining about these measures because Tasmania is undercutting the New South Wales market with the help of Commonwealth subsidies. I am not disagreeing with that but I suggest to the honourable member that when he asks for subsidies he should not get up in this Parliament and say that they are not proper and appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions reveals some strange bedfellows. I do not think the report is a sound one. There are to be cuts in government expenditure but I doubt whether many wool growers-certainly the representatives of the wool growers-will consider that the Government is taking a step forward by getting rid of the Australian Wool Testing Authority. When the Authority was run by private enterprise it was inefficient and costly and did not do the job expected of it by the wool growers. Under its existing management it is efficient and profitable. Now the Government steps in to bring back inefficiency in the name of private companies. If the Government can make a quid it does not matter who suffers.

Honourable members all heard the talk about this great new health scheme. The user pays-that is the principle we are talking about. Who is the user of a health scheme? What are his economic circumstances, especially if he is a low income earner living from hand to mouth, not a pensioner but a low income earner with a family?

TALK.START.PARA: —You can help the poor people.

—I am not talking about the poor people either; I am talking about the ordinary people who live in the community, the Australians whom some honourable members opposite ought to consider sometimes. I am talking about a family with a child who has a disability, who cannot eat certain foods, who has to have regular hospitalisation, who has to have dialysis treatment or many of the other treatments which are extraordinarily expensive in our society. What does the Government say? If that family is unlucky enough and cares enough to want to do something about that child then the Government says that the user should pay! The misfortune of ill health is not something that we choose ourselves. It is not an affliction, and it is certainly not a sign or some evil thing that we have done to ourselves or our children. It is something that happens to us. The user pays-what utter rot! The user pays idea is an easy way out for people who want to avoid their responsibilities to their fellow human beings. In the field of health the Government has abdicated totally its responsibilities to its fellow human beings. It has no heart, no care, and no responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all right for the Prime Minister, he talked today about unnecessary subsidies. Ask him to come into this Parliament and list the subsidies he gets on his own property. In many instances they are greater than the costs for the sick. But the user pays! In the field of health the community has a responsibility to itself to ensure that those people who have need of treatment are entitled to get that treatment at the most resonable cost possible. To criticise the situation of payment for health services on the basis of ability to pay is to talk about abandoning the sick because their ability to pay is the lowest of any section of the community. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Wilmot, made it a virtue that the poor should not get treatment because they cannot pay. Within 12 months it will cost $700 to $900 a year to be adequately covered by a scheme. That is the cost that the Government is about to inflict on the average family in Australia. Not too many families, large families especially, will be able to afford the cost. When the Government inflicts that charge on those families it whould just remember that many will not be able to afford it. They will not be adequately covered.

What is a public hospital to do when the father of that family has a massive coronary, arrives at the hospital door, does not have adequate medical cover and does not meet the criteria for being disadvantaged? Does it say to him when he needs open heart surgery and intensive care treatment: 'I am sorry. Take him home and arrange for the cheapest funeral you can afford'? The medical costs involved to save the father, the breadwinner, of such a family are between $10,000 and $20,000. The user pays! Perhaps we should say that the family should sell the house, as people do in America, the free enterprise way. Not on your life. Most Australians disagree with the Government's proposals on health. It is a coward's castle. Clearly, the Government is running away from its responsibilities as a national government.
I want to speak also about a number of other matters. Firstly, I will deal with some specific matters in the areas for which I have responsibility on the Opposition benches.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Capital Territory.

—The Australian Capital Territory and Defence, and I speak also as a member of the national parliament. I make just one point. Someone here tonight spoke about getting rid of Parliament House as a cost saving factor. In the last couple of days the Government has been talking about government borrowings being one of the causes of high interest rates. It is not much more than a year ago that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Howard), who are now talking about the evils of government borrowings, were going to the State governments and encouraging them to take up loan funds for infrastructure borrowings. If people want to know the most irresponsible action that has taken place in the financial world in this country in the last three years, at the behest of this Commonwealth Government, it is over $300m of borrowings for an international trade centre in Melbourne which is one of the greatest white elephants in this country's history. It is a monument to the incompetence and irresponsibility of the Victorian Government, and a monument to the double standards of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, who encouraged and advocated those borrowings. They now come in to this House and tell us that it was evil.

SPEECH.PARA: May I make a contrast with those borrowings. A small amount of money was borrowed to establish the Belconnen Mall in Canberra, which was set up under separate management. The Commonwealth contributed $1m. The Mall currently has an estimated value approaching $54m. It has a debt situation of around $40m. This year its profits on running equalled the original Commonwealth investment. It is providing for the community in which it is established considerable infrastructure in the form of playgrounds and other recreational facilities which a community would expect from its local government body, if Canberra had one-it does not. The Mall is providing those things at no cost to the responsible government, being the Commonwealth Government. If it is sold, over a very short period there will be a profit to the Treasury of in excess of $20m if it is sold at anything like its market value. Who gets the benefit of that $20m?

TALK.START.PARA: —The taxpayer.

—The taxpayer, my foot. It will go into providing more subsidies to people like Malcolm Fraser. That is where it will go. Government members do not seriously think that their Government is in the business of benefitting the taxpayer. The Government has transferred $4,000m of taxpayers' funds from community-based operations, operations which would normally be of value to the lower middle income earner-in other words, the 70 per cent of Australians who earn their living by means of manual or other forms of labour-mainly to overseas companies. But the biggest and the wealthiest people in this Commonwealth have been the beneficiaries of $4,000m of resources transferred in five years. We should remember that the people are paying more taxes and the Government is spending more as a percentage of gross domestic product than the average spent during the three years of the Labor Government. Let us not kid ourselves about small government or saving taxpayers' money. The Government is spending taxpayers' money as hard as it can go. What the Government is doing with it, of course, is paying off the big contributors to its parties' funds. Utah got a $120m dividend for a donation to the two political parties that govern this country, and there has been plenty more of that.

SPEECH.PARA: I have about three minutes left to speak and I want to use that time to discuss a couple of things, including the area of defence, which notably was left alone. Whilst a number of teachers colleges, an early childhood development centre, and a couple of Catholic teachers colleges in Melbourne have gone, an organisation that this Parliament through one of its committees, indicated was a waste of public funds, is to continue. I did not hear the honourable member for Perth (Mr McLean) mention this, but it was stated in a report to this Parliament that the Australian Defence Academy was a waste of public funds. Of course, the Academy is sacrosanct because it is the Prime Minister's favourite project. It is like the 707s. It does not matter what they cost, the Prime Minister wants them, therefore the country must need them, and the taxpayer must be glad to pay for them. It is a waste of public funds, no more and no less, but it is still in the Government's --

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the new Parliament House?
—I said that the honourable member had mentioned that.
—Do you agree with it.

—No, I do not agree with anw of the Government's cuts. The Government is moving to close the Defence Printing Establishment. It is also moving to close the Bendigo Ordnance Factory, although there is some charade about sale to private enterprise. I suppose that since the Government did not tell the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Bouchier), it had to put up some sort of charade, but the fact is that the Government is going to close it. The charade is that within a year the Defence Printing Establishment will be transferred to the Australian Government Publishing Service. But the report of the Department of Administrative Services says that the functions of the Government Printing Office will be disposed of to private enterprise immediately, execept for those essential requirements of Hansard and immediate Government Printing. The Defence Printing Establishment carries out at a high technological level a considerable amount of sensitive and important printing, which is necessary for the armed forces of this country. It is to be sold off so that someone can make a quick buck. Damn the armed forces and damn the requirements they might have for accurate and secure printing! The Government has no worries at all about the people who work there.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government must have a friend Melbourne who is prepared to make a big donation and who wants quickly a printing works or some section of a printing works. For any government to sell off any essential defence establishment as a cost saving exercise is a repudiation of its responsibilities for national security and defence preparedness; and that is exactly what is happening in this instance. The Defence Printing Establishment provides a highly confidential printing service for the Department of Defence. The Government is saying that its printing requirements should go out to private contractors. Honourable members ought to read what the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said in the Review of Commonwealth Functions because the Defence work is not being transferred to the Government Printer. The Government Printer's functions are being sold to private enterprise, and that is all there is to it.

There is only one thing that can be said with regard to Canberra. Canberra is completely defenceless in the face of a ruthless and exploitive Federal Government. It is about time the Government gave the people of Canberra, whether they want it or not, the responsibility of making their own decisions with regard to their own money. The Government talks about letting people make decisions on how to spend their money yet in Canberra it has a principality with an absentee prince and an authority which it is paying but which has no decision-making power at all. It is a disgrace to any democratic society and it is a disgrace to this Parliament that that situation continues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hyde Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The observation I must make to the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) is that a loud voice and assertion is no substitute for argument. If the Opposition is going to insist that all these things which the Review of Commonwealth Functions mentions can be retained in the public sector and that they will necessarily be more efficient and so on and so forth. I point out that it is as incumbent on the Opposition to provide argument as it is on us. The report of the co-called razor gang is something of a watershed. To understand that we need to understand some recent history. Ever since 1975 the Liberal Party has talked of small government. In 1980 we introduced what was the biggest Budget in real terms in Australia's history. That was followed by an election which the Australian Labor Party came close to winning, although it was still appreciably short of the majority of public opinion; but it achieved that result by costing the Liberal Party's promises. The interesting thing about the election is that during the latter part of it the Labor Party spent its time--
—Criticising the Governent.

—The Labor Party spent its time criticising us about big government. It seemed to win some votes on that. Socialism is normally defined as the public ownership and control of the means of production, distribution and exchange.
—There's nothing wrong with that either if it is--
—Order!

—Just pipe down a second and let me complete the argument; it will demonstrate to the honourable member that we are both in a fairly inconsistent position. Since that time, in terms of small government, the rhetoric from this side of the House has been excellent. The Governor-General's Speech was clearly a speech in favour of small government. On behalf of the Government the Governor-General said:

SPEECH.PARA: My Government will give particular attention to encouraging the growth of the private sector and to increasing the freedom of choice of taxpayers in spending their own incomes. It will be an important policy objective to continue to restrain public expenditure so as to provide scope for reducing the burden of taxation.

We read a similar recommendation in the Prime Minister's speech to the South Australian Liberal Party. I will not read that speech as honourable members can look it up. The Tuesday before last in this House the Prime Minister said:

The Government's direction has always been that individuals are the best judges of how to spend their own earnings, that the disadvantaged and the needy must be provided for, that the tax burden must be reduced, that employment must be increased, that freedom of choice must be paramount.
