I agree with all those things, and I agree with them very strongly indeed. Small government requires two things: It requires a small public sector and it requires small regulations of the private sector. The two areas we have to get out of are these: The public controlling of the society, because we own it and take all the decisions; and we have to get out of the business of telling all the individuals in the society how they will spend their money and, as a result, how they will occupy their time. Last Thursday's statement was a very important first step in the right direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a disgrace.

—The honourable member is welcome to his opinion because he wishes to go in an opposite direction. It is a different point of view, which is consistent with the philosophy that we have espoused over some time. The Razor Gang report is closing the gap between that rhetoric, which I think is excellent, and our performance. That is why it is a watershed. It is a very important step in the right direction. The announced cuts are not big but they will close that gap. Let us look at what some of our critics have said since last Thursday. I shall quote from what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) said at page 1880 of Hansard. I hope that in being selective I am not doing him an injustice. He said that the cuts were:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . nothing less than a massive liquidation sale of national assets and public confidence . . .
He said further:
. . . condems the Australian people to even more hardship and distress . . .
He went on:
. . . this wholesale slaughter of national responsibilities.
They are separate quotes but I am trying to give the House the tenor of the argument. He continued:
This review is a policy for more unemployment.

The honourable member for Oxley is quite wrong in his assessment. The Australian private sector is now expanding rapidly by Australian standards. The non-farm growth is around 4 per cent per annum. By Australian standards that is high.

TALK.START.PARA: —And internationally.

—Well, it is high by international standards unless perhaps we look at some of those countries to our north which have much better trade policies than we have. That is why I did not go into the international area. The non-farm growth is certainly high by many international standards, including those of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. The resources to permit that expansion have to come from somewhere. The public sector is in competition with the private sector for capital and for manpower. To permit that expansion some of the capital and some of the people must come from overseas, but we are unlikely to be able to accept or attract either in the area of immigration or foreign investment the quantities necessary to provide for all the private sector development that we have before us. Australians currently unemployed could fill some of the need if only the award wage system would permit them to work for wages matched by price with the additional goods and services they produce. Sadly for the unemployed, I see little sign that wage demands will ease and that those people will be able to find employment, thus earning much more than can on the unemployment benefit in much more satisfying circumstances.
—The unions do not represent them.

—No. As the honourable member for Perth has pointed out, the unions do not represent the unemployed. The public sector should make room for the more productive private sector. If taxes are lowered, private citizens will choose what to buy and where to invest. Only a very conceited person would claim to know each citizen's well-being better than he knows it himself. That is why the choice of what to buy and where to invest should be a decision for individuals in the private sector. If public sector borrowings are lower, private enterprise can raise more capital to invest in any of a multitude of opportunities. If, on the whole, the private sector spends and invests more wisely, productivity, employment and wealth will rise more rapidly than if big brother makes all those decisions. This is, in fact, the record.

SPEECH.PARA: In the mid-1970s, with a rapidly expanding public sector, employment fell. In the late 1970s and in 1980, with more slowly expanding public sector, employment rose-just as one would expect it to. Why did it rise? It rose because the marginal dollar was better occupied. That is why employment was able to rise during that time.

Let us look at another group of critics. The Government's critics are inconsistent. There are those who say that the cuts are cosmetic, that they are not real and that the Government is not really making cuts. I will concede that some of the 300-odd items do not amount to much. But others are significant. Consider the sale of surplus Commonwealth land. Why should that public asset be tied up doing nothing? The Government's printing and publishing services are to go to the private sector as will cleaning and food provision services. Surely these are things that the private sector is singularly skilled at doing. The abandonment of the Prices Justification Tribunal will take the PJT off the back of industry and allow price to determine who does what, with the buyers and the providers allocating their resources to maximising the benefit to both. The decision regarding the Canberra Commercial Development Authority was a first class decision as was the decision in relation to rent and price control in the Australian Capital Territory. The decision in relation to shopping hours is also a first class decision. Why does the shopper have to be told when she can buy her goods? The Australian Labor Party made much of making Canberra a social laboratory for socialism. There is no reason why Canberra cannot be a social laboratory for free enterprise.

The next group of critics are those who assert that the Government will not carry the cuts through. they say that the proposals are real and important but the Government will not have the courage to see them through. Only time will tell that. I expect that there will be some backsliding on some of the items. I do not think that it is reasonable for any group of men to have picked all those items accurately to the point that they have foreseen every difficulty. I accept that; that will not worry me. What will worry me is if another list is not presented at Budget time, that the process is not ongoing, that we cannot look to more cuts in more significant areas. It will not worry me if a few of the items fall by the wayside because of unforseen circumstances.

The last group of critics suggest that the cuts are too small. I certainly think that the cuts are too small. We have further to go. But bear in mind that this is a very significant turn-around in direction. For the first time I can say that government is not getting big more slowly, but is actually getting smaller. That makes the cuts very important indeed. Where do we go from here? I suggest that we look at introducing university fees for people wanting to obtain first degrees. For the life of me, I do not understand why people who come from relatively low income areas, such as Lockridge in my electorate, should pay for the education of people who, almost entirely, come from very high income families. That does not seem to be justice to me. Why should not those who have access to an education that allows them to earn much higher lifetime incomes pay for that education so that it is not a burden on those who earn low lifetime incomes. They could obtain money for the fees through a student loans scheme and pay it back over a lifetime in amounts geared to their incomes. This does not have to be a hardship for anybody. It will allow the poor people enter the system.

The isolated patients travel accommodation assistance scheme is impossible to administer fairly because of its complexities. It is too complicated for the Government to administer. The new Parliament House and the proposed Defence Force Academy should also be cut from Government expenditure. We could make this present Parliament House big enough by changing the Standing Orders so that we did not have divisions by ambush. We could then use West Block, the Hotel Kurrajong and the old Hotel Canberra fully as Westminster uses all of Whitehall. We could get over the problems of this building for the cost of amendment the Standing Orders. Recommendations on decentralisation assistance grants involve $9.6m. As far as I can make out the people who are supposed to benefit most from the multicultural broadcasting do not want it. About $21.2m of the taxpayer's money is involved. In relation to airport development, the business of putting up airports seems to be an election hazard. Airports have taken over from dams. Now during elections we feel airports coming on. Railways are a special problem. Australian National Railways is expected to have an operation loss of $53m on a revenue expenditure of $170m. The liquefied petroleum gas subsidy involves $25m and on the petroleum products freight subsidy, $125m. Those subsidies fly right in the face of the parity pricing policy. There is plenty of room left to go further and we should be contemplating further cuts now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde), who preceded me, spoke about deregulation. But he forgot to mention that he comes from a background which is the most subsidised and protected in Australia. I do not know whether he is a grazier or a wheat grower. He sounded like a peasant anyhow. He expounded the theory that profits are sacred whilst losses are communal. He talked about taxpayers' money, forgetting to mention that he receives a lot of it in subsidies.

SPEECH.PARA: Until last week I was under the impression that we, in Australia, are being governed by a government and the two Houses of the Parliament. However, my naive belief was shattered by the revelations of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), the former Minister for Industrial Affairs, who stated that the Co-ordination Committee introduced by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is effectively superimposed over the Cabinet. So we learned about the existence of this powerful instrument of the Prime Minister, the gang of five, as the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) called it. Of course, we already knew about the Ministerial Review Committee, the razor gang. It is obvious now that we are governed by two gangs-the gang of five and our very own gang of four. Between these two gangs presides the sinister and divisive figure of the Prime Minister.

As the result of the activities of the Co-ordination Committee, the gang of five, we have just lost the only remaining relatively able and decent Minister in the Fraser Ministry. The result of the activities of the razor gang will be much more disastrous. It will mean more unemployment, fewer services to the public, and the sell-out of people's assets to private enterprise. On the basis of Liberal philosophy that profits are sacred and private, whilst losses are communal, profitable government enterprises will be handed to the private sector while unprofitable services and Commonwealth responsibilities will be transferred to the States. Let them worry about it. The list of savage cuts is too long to be repeated here. The Prime Minister's shameful recital last week lasted more than an hour. The cuts, not mentioned before last year's elections, will create more and more unemployment. Yet it is questionable whether they will result in any savings. No announcement has been made about where the money is going. There was no mention of tax relief to the public. This Government, despite its rhetoric, is the highest taxing government in Australia's history. Its last Budget amounted to more than $36,000m. There is every indication that the expenditure in the next Budget will be even higher. But even if we paid less taxes-a promise never fulfilled by the Prime Minister-would that really mean more freedom?

According to the most vocal advocate of less taxes on the rich, Professor Milton Friedman, an essential part of economic freedom is freedom to choose how to spend one's income. Of course, Milton Friedman forgets, as honourable members opposite do, the recipients of social welfare payments-the unemployed, the widows, the old age pensioners and others-who will not be able to have the freedom of choice how to spend their income if they are not going to get any. Pensioners and many others will not have even the freedom of movement if public transport, on which they solely rely, is neglected further as a result of the policies of this Government. Public services like public transport, public hospitals and public housing are important for the least affluent. Unemployment and welfare benefits are important to those who have no other income.

The rhetoric of small government or less government intervention is only a cover-up for an attack by the Fraser Government on the living standard of the Australian people. Behind the Government's rhetoric there is an assault on all the civilian services of modern government. One does not have to look far to establish where the orders for such an assault are emanating from. I will quote a few lines from the March bulletin of the Australian Industries Development Association. The bulletin states:

The political difficulty of biting deeply into welfare expenditures is acknowledged. Nevertheless it is clear that not only constraint on growth but expenditure reduction is necessary in the welfare field.
Further it stated:
Potential savings in administrative expenditures are less significant than potential savings in programs.

We have just seen how this Government takes the advice of AIDA. We have just witnessed the last vestiges of our health program axed by this Government whose Prime Minister promised: 'We will maintain medibank'. It took him five swings of the axe to take us back to the fifties to the chaos of inefficient and costly private health insurance. Let me get back to the Prime Minister's mentor, the AIDA bulletin, and quote further from the leading article. The article stated:

Before proposals for expenditure restraint can be made, it is important to identify in some detail the factors in the growth of social welfare outlays. There are essentially six main categories of outlays, known generally as:
Assistance to the aged (mainly age pensions);
Assistance to veterans;
Assistance to the handicapped;
Assistance to widows and single parents;
Assistance to families (mainly family allowances);
Assistance to the unemployed and sick.

This reads like direct terms of reference to the razor gang, to axe what is left of our welfare program. Of course, there are already hints and statements by the members of the gang that they are sharpening their razor to shave off the thin veneer of civilisation and caring for the less privileged, to expose the society's selfishness and barbaric greed for profits.

Let us analyse what is behind the action of the Government. Is it only a move to line the pockets of the rich friends or a deliberate pursuance of a dogmatic philosophy? It would be very charitable if I said that it is motivated by both, as the sell-out of the nation's assets is general whilst the dogmatic ideology of the Government is applied only selectively. The measures introduced by the razor gang are applied so selectively that they hurt only the ordinary people of Australia while the rich escape the razor's edge. The selective imposition of cuts, ceiling and restraints indicates a deliberate onslaught of the conservative forces on the living standard of the Australian family.

Why was it, that at this point of our history, the capitalist conservative establishment chose to abandon its human face and use the ugly, mean face of the Prime Minister instead? In the era of the 1950s and 1960s, when the post-war capitalist economy was booming, there were few dissenting voices in the Western World to the demand that governments intervene in the management of the economy so that unemployment and inflation were kept to the minimum. There was a general consensus that only governments could provide services such as low-cost housing, health care for the disadvantaged and urban transportation, which by their nature are not available from the private sector or on which the private economy defaults as there are no profits to be made in these fields. It was generally accepted that measures to assist the unemployed, to extend welfare payments, to increase old age pensions, to introduce environmental protection, consumer protection and so on were the proper function of government. The role of government was to protect the individual in our society. In other words, government was used to hone off the rough and harsh edges of the capitalist system. Hence the introduction of Medibank, migrant translator services, increased funds for schools, colleges and universities, abolition of tertiary fees and a score of other measures to improve the quality of life in the early 1970s in Australia. Unfortunately, the introduction of better welfare services in Australia was delayed because of the reactionary Liberal Government under Menzies. By the time we started to introduce mild social reforms the capitalist economy was already heading towards a deep crisis from which it has not emerged even today.

If we have this analysis in mind it will be much easier to understand the sudden switch to Fraserism. Whilst the economy of the Western capitalist countries, including ours, enjoyed a period of steady growth and relatively stable prices in the 1960s, there were already forces in operation which later upset the economic equilibrium and drastically altered both the economic and the political context of macro-economic policy. The phenomenon I refer to is the continual growing of corporate concentration, an unavoidable feature of capitalist development. The enormous size and power of multinational corporations enabled them to resist so called free market forces. They could dictate prices and increase them at will, thus avoiding the discipline of the market. They effectively used their power to set aside the market and increase prices and profits. The ability of multinational corporations to use their power to this effect became a new intractable cause of inflation. Prices now rise not as a consequence of strong demand but because of the strong upward push of corporations.

Of course, we do not hear the Treasurer (Mr Howard) or the Prime Minister talk about the upward price push of large multinational corporations which control the market forces. They still fallaciously talk about the upward push of wages knowing only too well that wage increases do not precede but follow price rises affected by the power of big corporations. This new development-inflation caused by concentration of corporate power and not by increased demand-made it impossible for the Government to use the old tried-out capitalist weapon of resorting to create a pool of unemployed to reduce inflation. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer resorted to such tactics; they created more than half a million unemployed. To their consternation their inhuman strategy did not work; nor is it working today.

The only result of Fraser's economic policies was the lowering of living standards of Australian families and as a consequence the Prime Minister came close to losing last October's elecion. The last mini-Budget, the abandonment of the Government's responsibilities for our health care and hospitals, the withdrawal of half tax indexation, the razor gang's proposals for reduction in employment opportunities and the sell-out of the people's assets will further erode the living standards of the people.

The razor gang's proposals will not benefit any section of our community bar a few speculators who consort with this Government. In main, the razor gang's activities were motivated by the dogmatic ideological views of the Prime Minister. Take for instance the sell-out of government assets and land. What kind of business accumen do those people opposite who support such a proposal have? Did I hear the Treasurer say the other day in the House that he and his colleagues are advised by people who have extensive business experience in the private sector? What kind of business prudence is the sell-out of one's assets to pay the bill, or as it is in this case, to balance the Budget?

The honourable gentlemen opposite proved that they are very good businessmen when they manage their own affairs. They are all hanging on to their assets and accumulating even more. Some people were so eager to lay their hands on more cash or land that they got in trouble. Yet when it comes to the people's assets the Government wants to squander them. This is what happens when the custodians of publicly owned land are people such as the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch). It is like putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank. The people of Australia will remember how the Liberal-National Country Party Government sold their assets and how they squandered them. There is nothing that can save this reactionary lot in the next election. We will have a Labor government in 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —If not before.

—I hope before. I hope that one of our first tasks will be to repossess the people's assets-not to buy back the assets but to repossess them-that this Government is using to line the pockets of its corporate friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The concept of repossession is fascinating and one that is expressed widely throughout the nation. In fact, a member of the Australian Labor Party said tonight that Labor Party policy is to walk in and take up, giving no compensation but walking over any enterprise that such a government might choose to pick up, dominate and incorporate as part of the public sector. The sort of rubbish we have heard suggested from the other side of the House tonight includes, would honourable members believe, the retention of the post of collector of scalps in the Australian Capital Territory. Those are the sorts of positions and expenses that this Government has taken to with the razor. It has dispatched the unimportant, the irrelevant and those parts of the public sector whose removal will not interfere with services. In fact its actions will make for a leaner, and more efficient and worthwhile government sector to serve the people of Australia.
—Have you thought of that as a job for you one day?

—I am sure that honourable members opposite, and particularly the honourable member for Lalor, appreciate that so much of the funds that we collect from taxpayers are eaten up by administration. I am sure that all honourable members will agree that the people we really seek to help miss out because of inefficient methods in giving them their due. In Aboriginal affairs and social welfare so much of the taxpayers' funds are taken up by administration because of the complicated nature of what we are endeavouring to do in a fair way and with good intentions. It is time that we as a nation dealt with these factors and delivered to people their due deserts and the benefits we believe they are eligible for.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Labor Party's dedication to large government and the real differences between socialist philosophies and anti socialist philosophies have been indicated in this debate. Accountability of government is a principle supported by the Liberal and National Country parties. Irresponsible government is sponsored by the socialist movement within Australia. It believes in the idea that if government is doing it it must be right. That is the theme of the argument that we have heard expressed on the other side of the House. We hear that if government is involved it must be good. That is not true. I do not think that the people of this country should tolerate the argument that because a government wishes to do something it must be right.

In New South Wales we have a Premier determined to enter the Federal Parliament. He is building an entertainment centre in Sydney at a cost of $34m. That will be his means of entering the Federal House. Today I read an interesting story to the effect that the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Les McMahon) will be made the manager of that centre in order to allow the Premier to come into the Federal Parliament. We are told that anything a government does for whatever purposes must be of good intention. In New South Wales we have a Premier seeking to spend taxpayers' funds in order to achieve for himself a place in the Federal Parliament. What a ridiculous and irresponsible and unaccountable process.

We have also heard that Premiers around the country have been talking about the reduction made in the Commonwealth grants to be made to the States and also speaking about the way in which decisions made by the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee will affect their fund raising capacity and ability to deliver services. Yet we have State governments entering into activities such as the purchase of coal loaders-activities of the sort which they need not participate in. There is absolutely no need for government to become involved to the extent that the Labor Party wishes them to become involved. In New South Wales alone $1,000m could be saved in a year by getting rid of those services in which the Labor Government need not be involved. As I understand the philosophy of the Labor Party it should not be involving itself in such projects. It has been diverted from its original intention. This is a great shame for politics today. The Labor Party has been diverted from its intention and commitment to assist those who are needy and those who are poor. It is natural that the middle ground is filled by non-socialist parties who have a compassion for and understanding of those who are needy. They will in fact deliver services and develop programs and systems to help the needy. Governments should not be in business; governments should be helping people. Governments should be caring for and thinking of individuals. Getting involved in large government and large business enterprise is not helping anyone. It is not helping the Government and it is not helping the needy. In fact, this Government has made a decision to reduce services by slashing the superfluous.

I believe that the mechanical decisions made by the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee are a first step. In fact, what we need to have throughout the administration of government services is an understanding of the benefits that can result from efficient administration and a commitment to that which is well deserving and well delivered. A knowledge and understanding of good administration can provide many more services and provide them more cheaply. Over a period of five or six years or even longer-in fact since the Labor Party came into government-there have been many examinations of the functions of government and the administration of government. It is only this Government that has taken decisions.

Honourable members opposite will remember the Royal Commission into Australian Government Administration on which there is no action whatsoever. Honourable members on this side of the House will remember the Administrative Review Committee set up in 1975 under the chairmanship of Sir Harry Bland. There have been investigations of all sorts. They include the Medibank review of 1976, the review of delivery of services financed by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the inquiry into care of the aged and infirm, the Myers inquiry into unemployment benefit, the Norgard inquiry into the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Baily task force inquiring into health and welfare and review of procedures and processes in the Department of Social Security. A great deal of examination and thought has gone into a careful assessment of government administration. Each step of the way this Government is seeking to improve its efficiency and ability to give services that are well thought out and based on sound policies and to deliver them in an efficient way.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure is another example of what this Government has sought to do to ensure effective and economic implementation of government policy and administration. The Auditor-General is charged with reporting on the efficiency with which departments are administered and the way in which programs are delivered. I believe that that record alone, without the decisions made by the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee, demonstrates that the anti-socialist parties have a commitment to effective accountability and responsibility in government and a desire to ensure that programs do not go on year after year. Established programs can become ingrained so that at Budget time departments put up their bids to extend and increase their every section, every function and every division of administration. It is time there was a reassessment, a re-examination of exactly what departments and people do. It is ridiculous that the Australian Capital Territory has had a Collector of Scalps for so many years. I understand that the other place in this Parliament has had people coming in for five years to collect the mail on Saturday mornings even though there have not been mail deliveries. I find that typical of examples that I see from day to day of things which should be attended to. Let us start right here, in this place, and extend it so that there is a proper understanding of responsibility, of effective management, and an effective corporate view.

The findings of the Bland committee indicated that, despite close questioning, of the 26 heads of Government departments only two on a regular basis sought to find out how their department was standing, with a running sheet, with a cash flow situation, to see whether they were operating effectively and within budget. It is unbelievable that only two heads of Government departments took the trouble to find out whether they were living within their budgets. I think that a sense of corporate planning and corporate responsibility is needed with the Australian Public Service. I hope that the next step that this Government takes will be to ensure that incentives and also restrictions are placed on the Public Service so that attitudes can be fostered and so that, without cuts or reductions, services can be delivered efficiently and cheaply.

The sorts of proposals I believe would bring this about include the requirement that all Government departments live within their budgets unless directed by Cabinet to undertake additional expenses. I do not believe any government department has a right to overrun its budget through poor management, unless it is directed to take up additional programs. I do not believe that any department has a right to draw down the Advance to the Minister for Finance unless a proper submission has been approved by Cabinet. I do not believe that that process is proper. The processes of poor budgeting, poor accountability and poor assessment cannot be tolerated. The easy way out is to make those poor calculations and then draw down additional finances by way of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. Any department which underspends its budget without detriment to its projects or programs and can carry forward those funds to the next years should do so. There must be encouragement for efficiency. There must be some sort of fostering of that which is excellent in administration. Too often in this country, too often in the departments of the Commonwealth Government, and always in the departments of State governments, those people who overspend, who are inefficient and who ask for more are the ones who get more. Those who manage carefully and seek to support those whom they should be serving are the ones who in some way are penalised and marked down.

I believe that the Public Service Board should notify all personnel within departments which underspend or meet budget that their personal advancement will be improved by their performance in good management. We should encourage good management and a concern for the way in which funds are spent and handled. I believe also that unfavourable reports by the Auditor-General should be regarded by those department which receive them as a mark of disapproval to the extent that personnel in those areas shold not be considered for advancement at the same rate that they would normally be. The progress and development of the expenditure of funds is most important and most significant. The decisions that have been announced in this place take one step towards rationalisation and the sweeping away of cobwebs that have developed over many years. They are cobwebs that I believe have no significant effect on the Australian community. If honourable members opposite want to talk about education for example, and really have a feeling for those people in need, I suggest that they go to the Williams report and read it instead of coming into this House and making statements that are neither researched nor understood. The Williams report into education, training and employment indicates that Anderson, Bowen, Fensham and Powell in their study Students in Higher Education, carried out for the Tertiary Education Centre of the University of New South Wales and sponsored by the New South Wales Government, referred to the abolition of fees at universities. The view has been endoresed time and again that fee abolition, as they said:

. . . had at best a marginal effect on the accessibility of higher education to socially and economically disadvantaged groups. At worst the abolition of fees can be seen as a further benefit to the economically advantaged.
I suggest to honourable members opposite that before they come into this place espousing half-baked policies they should really research them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The events of the last couple of weeks have showed the Government's lack of concern for ordinary people. We have seen a devastating assault on health services, then the review of the much vaunted razor gang last week, and on Monday we moved to the scandalous events of the Premiers Conference. All of this amounts to an attack on the role of government; an attack on the quality of services supplied by government to ordinary people. Basically, all of this reflects the national and world view of this incompetent, accident prone, divided and anti-people Government. We reject its view of Australia's future, which is to allow unrationalised resource development, to depend upon jobs that may or may not be generated in the services sector as a result of export earnings, to ignore the essential brittleness of such an economy, to allow the de-industrialisation of many manufacturing and secondary industries, to allow a situation of declining expenditure to meet social needs in the community, and to continue with a most subservient, puerile foreign policy. The Australian Labor Party rejects this approach and puts forward an alternative national view. This alternative national view is one of a multi-tiered economy with balanced resource development in which we would maintain and expand manufacturing and secondary industries, which in turn would generate increased growth in a firmly based services and public sector. Above all, we stand for a peaceful world and an independent foreign policy.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to comment on some of the extraordinary events of the last few days which have been generated by this Government that espouses small government. We have seen attacks on specific purpose grants for health and housing, and the extraordinary interim formula which has been put forward to bridge the gap between this financial year, with the demise of the 39.87 per cent formula, and next year, when we will see general purpose grants to the States based on a percentage of total income tax. We have seen the extraordinary way in which the States have been cheated out of $70m and how they have been locked into a continuing loss because that $70m will be part of the new formula, as a percentage of total taxes, as it applies year after year after year. It is not a once-only operation. We have seen the extraordinary behaviour of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard). Why have they behaved like that? Obviously it has been because the Prime Minister is still basically insecure, leading a divided Government, worried about a certain person on the back bench, and worried about impressing the corporate sector. He is worried by those people on the back bench, known as the drys, who keep espousing smaller and smaller government, no matter what damage that does to the economy. A factor that emerges out of all this is that never again will the State Premiers be able to trust the Commonwealth's final offer as being the absolute limit of Commonwealth capacity.

There is an argument for restricting Loan Council borrowings.According to the Prime Minister's special program, they have already been endorsed to an extent of $5,000m. Now the States are after another $5,000m. It may be that they are asking too much in that area. When this Government talks of control it does not mean the control of finance to provide the infrastructure for resource development to aid transnational companies which seek to exploit our non-renewable national resources; it means the control of expenditure on items which satisfy basic social needs such as health, public housing, public transport and so on. Let us see when the Premiers meet again in June whether it is strong enough to rein in infrastructure expenditure for the servicing of resource development projects.

Let us look at what the Government intends to do in the area of environment and home affairs. Firstly, it says that responsibility for regulation and control of nuclear activities in Australia is to be implemented as far as possible by the States. It wants to hand over responsibility for the financing of the Northern Territory environmental regulatory services to the Northern Territory Government. It wants to hand over the day to day management of our national parks in the Northern Territory and the Northern Territory Government. If there is one truly national legislative responsibility it is in relation to the dangerous, dirty and selfish uranium and nuclear industry. The Government's proposal to hand over to the States the regulation of this industry is grossly irresponsible. It will create more government, not less government. It will create greater costs, not lower costs, and more risks to the people who will be working in the industry.

There is no uniform effective environmental assessment legislation to process conventional resource developments, let alone uranium developments. The situation is that resource development legislation, under which the States are supposed to assess the environmental aspects of such development, is lacking in uniformity. Only the Commonwealth and New South Wales have legislation which allows the public display of environmental impact statements and/or public, local or regional inquiries. Even then the federal Environment Protection Impact of Proposals Act relies on other constitutional powers, such as the issue of export licences and Loan Council Authority for borrowings to implement recommendations of these inquiries when they are held. In Queensland and Western Australia, the twomajor resource development States, there is no worthwhile conventional environmental legislation. There is no provision for public display of environmental impact statements and no provision for public inquiries. It is the action Minister who instigates a resource development proposals who makes the final decision on whether it will go ahead. This position is bad enough, but the current legislative position under which uranium projects are assessed and the industry operates is even worse. It will become worse under this Government.

There is a multiplicity of current Federal and State Acts which govern the development of the uranium industry. On a Federal level there is the Atomic Energy Act, the Environmental Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act and the Environmental Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act. The Northern Territory Acts include the Uranium Mining (Environment Control) Act and the Radioactive Ores and Concentrates (Packing and Transport) Act. In South Australia there is the Mining Act and the Mining Act Amendment Act (No. 2). In Queensland there is the Mining Act and the Radioactive Substances Act. In Western Australia there is the Mining Act and the Nuclear Activities Regulation Act. There is a multiplicity of almost meaningless legislation which has no overall Federal umbrella to pull the whole thing together and give it support. Of course, as an Opposition we do not support it. Now the Government intends to make the situation even worse. It intends to hand over responsibility for regulation and control of the uranium and nuclear industry to the States.

Against that background let us look at the multiplicity of projects which the Government is talking about. There is the Ben Lomond project in Queensland and the Honeymoon proposal in South Australia which was endorsed today by the Tonkin Liberal Government. This provides for in situ acid leaching of uranium from the ore body and the return of the radioactive liquid waste back into the water-table. That is the sort of mine that is proceeding at this stage under State legislation. The Government wants to give the States even more power. There is also the Beverley project, the Koongarra project, the Yeelirrie project and the Roxby Downs project. All in all that constitutes about $1.5 billion worth of development in uranium mining. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. All of these projects will lead to a tremendous overproduction. Even the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, that wonderful environmental authority, forecasts that by 1985 world demand will be about 39,000 tonnes. Our share of the world market, the Commission says, will be 8,000 tonnes maximum. This Government is pushing the States into a position where they will be producing 14,000 tonnes by the middle and late 1980s. We will never be able to sell the stuff and there will be an unseemly scramble to sell on a declining world market with a resulting weakening safeguards and fall in in environmental standards.

SPEECH.PARA: In this situation, giving nuclear regulatory powers to the States is the worst thing a government could possibly do. It will lead to competition in mines. It will lead to plans for enrichment plants. It will eventually increase demand for nuclear power stations. The Premiers of Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria and Queensland and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory almost slaver at the mouth in anticipation of completing the nuclear power cycle by the establishment of enrichment plants and power stations. They are all on the public record as being in support of completing the development of the nuclear cycle. In the uranium and nuclear areas we can expect to see the same sort of competition which now bedevils the nation in the area of coal development. An amount of $9 billion is involved in coal development; $8 billion in aluminium smelters and $10 billion in power stations. No wonder the Government is worried about the Loan Council. The same situation applies in relation to coal to oil plants. Competition is occurring throughout the States. Now the Government actually intends to encourage competition to extend into the uranium and nuclear industry by handing over control to the States. The Government does not even know how it is going to legislate for this.

TALK.START.PARA: —And cut back the funds for social infrastructure.

—It will be doing that the same time. Major uranium producing nations-even the United States of America and Canada-all have federal legislative control over nuclear activity. We would be the only banana republic in the world that had the stupidity to say to the States: 'You look after this dangerous, dirty and sensitive industry'. In the United States regulation of all activities related to uranium mining processing and nuclear power generation are under the control of the federal Government. There is no question about that. Control over all radioactive materials rests with the United States Nuclear Regulatory Committee. What does the Government think about that with its small government proposals? In Canada after uranium has been discovered, exploration, mining and milling licences must be sought from the federal Government, with control over all radioactive materials resting with the Federal Atomic Energy Control Board.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now, in the few minutes which I have left to speak, to deal with the proposition that the control and management of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service parks in the Northern Territory-Uluru and Kakadu-should be handed over for day to day management to the Northern Territory. That is a completely wrong concept. It proves that only State parks are wanted, not national parks. Under Fraserism, areas of national significance will not now be declared national parks if the Government moves out of this area. If the States or the Territories leave them unprotected that will be it. There is clear Commonwealth responsibility under the Constitution, if the government so desires to pick it up, to establish national parks not only in the Northern Territory but also in the States. There is no question about that.

The cop-out to the Territories is even more disgusting than the abrogation of the Government's rights to set up, if necessary, parks in the States. The Commonwealth is promoting more rather than less bureaucracy by having a separate park system in each State or Territory. A plan of management for Kakadu National Park came into force in April 1981 and it should remain in force for five years. The Northern Land Council has stated that it does not want any change to the administrative procedures of the park because it does not know the strength--
Debate interrupted.

Mr Hodgman-I require that the question be put forthwith without debate.
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Northern Land Council has been told about what the Government intends to do and it opposes it. It does not trust the Northern Territory Government. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, like the Aborigines, has been kept in the dark about the plans for Kakadu. Not only were the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Northern Land Council not consulted on recent decisions affecting Kakadu's future, but also they heard of them only after the announcement was made last week. Koongarra is probably the most glaring example of what the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth Government intend for the Kakadu National Park area. It is an enclave in the Kakadu Park which Justice Fox considered too ecologically sensitive to bear uranium mining. Now, because the company Denison Australia Pty Ltd and its predecessor Noranda Mines Ltd made a mistake about the boundaries, the Department of Trade and Resources rather than the Department of Home Affairs and Environment is now making plans to alter the boundaries to intrude further into the Park without any consultation with the Northern Land Council or the National Parks and Wildlife Service,

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may presume on the House for a moment, I inform the House that tomorrow will be the 65th birthday of the Deputy Principal Attendant, Mr Collins. He will be retiring after 17 years service with the House of Representatives. Mr Collins, who is more familiarly known to most of us as Andy Collins has served for the greater part of his time here in the chamber and, since 1976, he has been the senior chamber attendant. I am sure all honourable members will join me in thanking Mr Collins for his many years service to the House and in wishing him many happy years of retirement.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Without usurping the position of the Opposition on the adjournemt debate I join in the remarks made by you, Mr Deputy Speaker. A number of colleagues from both sides of the House have observed over the last 16 years the diligent, unassuming work that Andy Collins has rendered in this chamber. He is a very popular man. It is good to see thim leaving this place looking so sturdy and fit. He has had a healthy background. I have been told tonight that he was once very famous as a captain-coach of the Leeton rugby league football team. He came from Captains Flat and played a very distinguished role in that mining area. Mr Deputy Speaker, I join with you on behalf of the rank and file of the Parliament in saying that this man represents a silent service. He has set a great example for others to emulate. I hope he maintains his good health and gives the superannuation scheme a damn good shake.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek indulgence to add to the remarks passed by my colleague in relation to the birthday and retirement of Andy Collins. I think the Opposition Whip, the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Les Johnson), summed up extremely well the feelings of all members of this House. We are very much in debt to Mr Andy Collins for the service he has rendered to the Parliament and, more importantly, as my colleague has said, for the friendship that he has extended to honourable members. Whilst in some respects it is a sad day, like the honourable member for Hughes, I am delighted that Andy is leaving this place looking fit and young and, I hope, with many years of happy retirement ahead of him. On behalf of members on this side of the House I join in the remarks passed in the early stages of the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned at news which has reached me today of a proposal which has been put to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) by a man who purports to speak for a great number of friends of those with impaired hearing in Australia and the Australian Deafness Council in Queensland. I refer to Mr Colin Lamont, a former Liberal member of the Queensland Legislative Assembly. Apparently, he has proposed a major sell out of the National Acoustics Laboratory to private enterprise and that a deterrent charge be imposed on persons acquiring hearing aids from the Government or, alternatively, that some kind of voucher system be devised whereby persons could get a contribution from public funds to pick up their hearing aids from the private sector. There was no reference to any perpetuation of the National Acoustics Laboratory or the preservation of its technical expertise. Rightly, concern has been expressed by people in Queensland who have contacted me about this matter. I understand that they will be contacting the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) and possibly other Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: During my time as Minister for Health many allegations were made by some of the leading private manufacturers in the supply of hearing aids that NAL was inefficient and obstructive in some way to their activities, that it was not adequately training and counselling people in the use of their hearing aids and that they were not getting the most benefit from them. I satisfied myself by visits to the various places providing services that any deficiency in that regard was purely one of available resources. If such services are cut by razor gangs efficiency will be reduced not because the expertise or the dedication of the people in the service has been changed but simply because they are not given the tools to do the job.

At the same time, some of the private suppliers and manufacturers are indulging in great rip-offs and con jobs by which they filch from the pockets of unsuspecting pensioners their life savings to pay for hearing aids which are no better in many cases than the ones they can get free from NAL. They advertise their services in a deceptive way with statements such as: 'Pensioners free hearing tests. Come and see our visiting expert in Rockhampton.' Some of them, of course, are reputable tradesmen as in most other trades and professions. They explain thoroughly to pensioners what they are letting themselves in for and what the alternatives are. In fact, they invite people to go to NAL to get another quote which will cost them nothing. The hearing aids and batteries from NAL will cost them nothing under the scheme introduced when I was the Minister for Health. Nevertheless, there are proposals to erode all these provisions. In the report of the razor gang we were told that the manufacture of hearing aids is to be farmed out on contract to private manufacturers.

I am not against involving private manufacturers in the supply of goods and services when this can be done to the best effect and with the greatest efficiency. I introduced this practice in the supply of free artificial limbs. The repatriation artificial limb factory co-operated with private enterprise to supply artificial limbs for all people in Australia. What I am objecting to is the proposal that there be a blanket handout to private enterprise and that the expertise at NAL, whose employees are world leaders in producing hearing aids and testing equipment and devising new methods, will be sold out to charlatans who are importing expertise and not developing equipment of world standards as NAL has done. The Government has no reason for doing so other than a mad, manic devotion to a private enterprise philosophy. It believes that if an organisation produces profits for anybody but the taxpayer it is all right; if it produces a service for the public efficiently and if it obtains world recognition as a service which is contributing to the economy of the country by reducing deafness, it is no good.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say to Andy Collins 'All the best'. I would not have been as polite to him as I have been over the years if I had known that he had coached a rugby team. Never mind. After all the discussions we had, I always thought he followed Australian rules. That aside, I wish him all the best.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not spoken for a long time on the petroleum industry, but in the last couple of months a few things have occurred and I think it would be remiss of me if I did not bring them to the attention of the Parliament. I know that the razor gang has recommended the removal of the Prices Justification Tribunal. A few points have been made as to whether or not it should have been removed. I firmly believe the Prices Justification Tribunal was not able to set the wholesale price of petrol equitably and sensibly in the area of petroleum marketing. I always thought if the PJT recommended a maximum wholesale price in every capital city the oil companies in certain selected areas would be able to sell petrol at a price cheaper than the maximum wholesale price. I believe that was one of the contributing factors to the problems associated with the marketing of petrol.

The oil industry is ever-changing. As a result of the Royal Commission on Petroleum in 1973 the industry changed dramatically. Honourable members will be aware that a couple of the major oil companies have moved into the area of marketing at their service stations. They provide a 24-hour service for groceries, toiletries and other foodstuffs. This is a move which I believe will spread. It is estimated that in America 35 per cent of total petroleum sales is from these super-sites. I note that there is an oil glut at present in America. I believe the removal of the PJT and the change of strategy by the oil companies will create problems. Therefore, I hope that the organisation the Government sets up to determine the price of wholesale petrol in Australia will take into consideration how the oil companies are able to move in different directions and how, sometimes to the detriment of people working in the industry, they are able to do certain things that may jeopardise the consumers of petrol in this country. When the Government forms this organisation to price petroleum in Australia I hope it will get the right people-people who know a little bit about the industry. I have found that very few people in this place know very much about the marketing of petrol. They leave it to other people to determine what should be done. I repeat that that has been one of the contributing factors to the problems associated with that industry for a long time.

Another extraordinary point to which I wish to draw attention is the fact that restrictive trade practices disallow oil company managers to talk together. They may have been able to overcome some of the problems associated with that industry. They are all intelligent people, all hopeful of getting a share of the market and all hopeful of improving the lot of the shareholders and the people who work in that industry. Because of the restrictive trade practices legislation-with which I do not disagree-the oil company managers cannot talk together about the price of petrol. Subsequently they never meet. This creates problems because they all work against one another. They seem hell bent on ruling the industry and on trying to break each other. If they had worked unison they might have been able to overcome some of those problems.

It is too late for that now, but I hope that the PJT will be replaced by an organisation which will know something about this complex industry and which will take into consideration the changes taking place within the oil industry. I hope that organisation will take into consideration that the price of petrol is at a high level because of this Government's import parity pricing policy. The consumers realise that. Petrol is precious to them; therefore it must be distributed equitably in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my intention to speak tonight on the decision of the Tasmanian Government to proclaim the Franklin and Lower Gordon rivers, in Tasmania's south-west wilderness, as part of a national park. I was holding back my comments and my congratulations to the Lowe Government in the expectation that one of my Tasmanian colleagues, probably my friend the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), would grab the opportunity to congratulate the Tasmanian Premier. However, as he was conspicuously silent on this matter I, as a Victorian member, decided to take the liberty to speak on behalf of my less vocal Tasmanian colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the Premier of Tasmania upon saving the gorges of the Franklin and Olga rivers for future generations of Australians. I hope that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) will join me in those congratulations because only recently, on 8 April, he said in reply to a question by the honourble member for Cunningham (Mr West):
The south-western wilderness area is land of great beauty. It is unique; it is irreplaceable. I hope that it can be listed in the World Heritage list.

Unlike the honourable member for Franklin, on this point I agree with the Prime Minister. After touring south-west Tasmania recently in a light plane, I believe that the flooding of rivers in the area for hydro-electric power would have been an ecological disaster. This magnificent, rugged wilderness is one of the few remaining untouched areas in Australia and, if left in its present state, will provide a unique heritage for generations of Australians to come. The south-west has the reputation of being one of the finest bush walking areas of the world. Its topography is varied. It has magnificent examples of glacial landforms, forested valleys and rivers that have formed enormous gorges and its coastline is extremely rugged. It presents enormous scope for geological and archaeological research by scientists. Only recently, in January and February, it was discovered that Aboriginals had inhabited the region during the last Ice Age. These archaeological discoveries were directly threatened by the plans of the Hydro-Electric Commission of Tasmania to flood the area. The invaluable heritage of the relics found there, and those yet to be found, would have been lost forever. There would be no going back, or second chances, if the decision to flood these areas had gone ahead.

Let us examine why the Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission would commit such environmental vandalism. The destruction of the area was designed to yield 180 megawatts of power. I invite honourable members to compare this with the output of Loy Yang, which is 4,000 megawatts, or even the Newport power station, which is 500 megawatts. This alone is indicative of what a thoughtless plan the flooding of the Franklin was. In this plan the Hydro-Eelectric Commission was abetted and supported by the Upper House of Tasmania. I understand that that House is not exactly a democratically elected body; that it perpetuates itself by a gerrymander. Lest honourable members should think that I am alone in my opinion on this matter, I propose to quote from an editorial in the Melbourne Age of 5 May. The editorial states:

The question is no longer simply the fate of south-west Tasmania. The Council-and to some extent the HEC-have made it a fight about who is running the State. A small group of conservative independents, elected on one of Australia's worst gerrymanders--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, that's terrible.
—I am not quoting from a socialist newspaper but from the Melbourne Age. The editorial continues:

SPEECH.PARA: is endeavouring to block the will of a democratically elected government on a major issue-and promising to do so indefinitely. . . . last Thursday's decision by the Government to declare the gorges of the Franklin and Olga a national park is a welcome sign of resolve.
If the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) wants to hear some more I will quote the editorial further:

Mr Lowe should now keep up the pressure by legislation to abolish the Council gerrymander. The Fraser Government should help by persuading its Tasmanian supporters to respect both constitutional convention and the landscape of the south-west.
May I hope that for once the Federal Government will stop playing politics, and will come to the assistance of the Tasmanian Government and help to preserve the south-west wilderness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it must be of great comfort to all the Tasmanian members to know that the best interests of their State are now safely in the hands of the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent). Last week some members of this House attended the keynote address at the Australian Mining Industry Council Minerals Outlook Seminar given by its Senior Vice-President, Mr H. M. Morgan. As not many Labor members actually attended that address so that they would really find out something about the mining industry-apart from the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), who has a degree of responsibility in this area which is not shared by many of his colleagues-I believe that I should point out to the House some of the realities about the mining industry. The Australian Labor Party appears to think the industry is some sort of bottomless honey pot from which it can get goodies non-stop to pay for its welfare programs, which in fact, are not generally aimed at people in need but at people from whom it hopes to buy a vote.

SPEECH.PARA: The points made by Mr Morgan are worth stating to the House. He said:

The current Federal/State rivalry over who gets the biggest slice of the government share of mineral related revenue threatens to become the single most important, and divisive, issue in Australian politics during the next five years. And the mining industry faces the chilling prospect of being caught in the crossfire. At the present time both sides in this Federal/ State row argue that they have the right to impose taxes on the industry because the resources are owned by the people they represent. I doubt that the members of the pre-Federation Constitutional Conventions who reserved Crown ownership of minerals to the States ever thought that position would be challenged.
I think it is worth pointing out too that Mr Morgan said:

While the current Federal Government has repeatedly rejected the proposition that it impose a resources tax on the industry, continual urgings for it to do so have resulted in a number of States engaging in reviews of their own royalty charges. Quite naturally, they are not prepared to run the risk of allowing another authority to benefit from the development of their resources. Equally, the mining industry looks askance as the prospect of it being subjected to increasingly heavier charges designed to satisfy the phony political objective of ensuring that the Australian community receives an equitable share of mineral development proceeds. The community's share in the industry is already higher than that of any other industry. Last year, for example, the government share in the mining and exploration sector of the industry was 55.8 per cent of the pre-tax operating profit of the industry. How much more does this industry have to pay to satisfy the political objectives of those who cannot understand that the total government share in the industry of $1,013 million last year, compared with a total net profit of $874 million, is already an equitable share of our business?

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the fee for this speech?

—That is the sort of interjection that I would expect from the honourable member. It reflects the level of his thinking and the level, I believe, of his contribution to this House. The next point I make relates to the bureaucratic control of this industry which honourable members opposite seem so determined to pursue. Mr Morgan said:

SPEECH.PARA: There seems to be a belief in the community that a remote bureaucracy which makes decisions and rules about practical matters will have greater wisdom and virtue than those who have a vested interest in the economic activity it is regulating. I have found little evidence to support this belief. My experience is that the best decisions and the best management come only from those who have a position of real accountability in a direct personal way for performance.

In Australia any new minerals development project may well have to run the gauntlet of submissions to, and approvals from, up to 20 government instrumentalities, at the same time governments have stretched their constitutional competence to embrace matters which to the industry appear to be remote from the intention of earlier legislators.

It is difficult for the community at large to comprehend the impact of the multiple interventions by government on resource projects, but there is no doubt that the result is increased cost, further delay and longer response times. None of these things can possibly benefit the man in the street, nor, in my opinion, can they do much to improve or protect his quality of life.

I believe that it is a shame that more members of the Labor Party did not go along to hear Mr Morgan's address. I hope that it had some sort of impact on the honourable member for Blaxland who attended the address. It seems a shame to me that so many members of the Labor Opposition are convinced that this mining honeypot is bottomless. The reality is that it is very risky business and I believe the Australian mining industry is doing a magnificent job, particularly under the present Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise in this House tonight a matter which is beginning to cause deep concern in my electorate; that is, a decision by the Department of Transport to locate a new international air terminal in the northern corner of Perth Airport. The matters involved are complex and I intend to raise them frequently in this place. At this preliminary stage, however, I want to place on record the grave exception taken by the Belmont Council, a local authority in my area, its members and officers, to the Department's decision and to the accompanying propaganda campaign being conducted among residents living near the airport. They are not complaining because they want the airport removed-let me make that quite clear. They are complaining because they do not believe they are being properly consulted and honestly dealt with and because they take the view that the propaganda campaign of the Department does not accurately portray the recommendations made by a joint State-Commonwealth committee on which the Council was represented.

SPEECH.PARA: That committee met for a number of years and contained representatives of a number of government departments, both State and Federal, and of a number of local authorities. The committee produced a series of recommendations and the Council believed that those recommendations would be acted upon. In the present process it believes that the environmental problems of its citizens have not been properly considered. It takes particular exception to an article which appears on page 2 of the Department's leaflet, which has been widely distributed in my electorate in association with the Department's efforts at explaining the proposed new terminal. That leaflet purports to represent the joint State-Commonwealth committee's recommendations. In it the Department implies that the committee firstly, recommended without qualification that Perth Airport be developed as the sole primary airport in the Perth region and, secondly, determined that a new north-south parallel runway was not justified on cost effective grounds and was not necessary on environmental grounds.

Both implications are misleading. In the first place, whilst the committee suggested that Perth Airport should be the sole primary airport for the Perth region until the year 2004, it further said that development should follow the production of a master plan based on a detailed analysis of airport development options and their impact on the environment and land use. On the Department's own admission, no such master plan has been produced. In the second place, the committee's opting for abandonment of a parallel runway was only a preliminary finding, not a final recommendation. It was accompanied by a request for more detailed research than the committee found it impossible to do. It was also stated by the committee that any decision to abandon a parallel runway should be accompanied by departmental consideration of compensation for homes and buildings affected by noise. The committee acknowledged that taking up this option would increase the number of buildings affected. Again there was no reference to this matter in the Department's propaganda leaflet. These are very important points and they affect the capacity of the community in the area to achieve a consensus on the expansion of the airport.

As all honourable members would be aware, when a major Commonwealth installation is to be located in an inner city location, as is the case in Swan, it is very desirable, if possible, to achieve a degree of consensus in the community, particularly among the local authorities concerned. Having local government representation on this joint State-Commonwealth committee, I think, was a very reasonable and forward step. However, all the good that was done by having that representation has been undone by the nature of the campaign being conducted and by the decision that has been arrived at by the Department of Transport. I hope that when the Public Works Committee visits Perth later in the year there will be an opportunity for this matter to be raised by the local authority with that Committee. I hope the result of raising it will be to produce some changes in the Department's decision. I urge the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) to initiate those changes himself.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I require the debate to be extended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take only a few minutes of the time of the House to respond to some of the remarks made by the honuorbale member for Hotham (Mr Kent) because they related to my home State. Whilst I appreciate his motives in wishing to come in to this Parliament and congratulate the Premier and the Government of Tasmania on the declaration of a new national park in the south-west of Tasmania, he made some other comments which I feel ought to be responded to before the House adjourns.

SPEECH.PARA: I had the honour to serve for some eight years as the momber for Huon in the Legislative Council, and the Huon electorate includes a substantial part of the south-west. I know the south-west. I have walked in it, and I was sent in there in tragic circumstances some years ago when three man drowned in what was Lake Pedder before the hydro-electric scheme came into effect. I believe that I am the only member in this Parliament who went out into the streets and took part in marches and open air rallies opposing the flooding of Lake Pedder before conservation became fashionable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Opportunism.

—It was not opportunism. Sometimes people do things that they believe in. In 1967 I went out into the streets and campaigned on an issue because I believed in it. I do not believe that it is in the interests of Tasmania, nor is it in the interests of Australia, for members of the Opposition, including-
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I think the mouth from the south, the Minister--
—Order, the honourable member will not offend in that way.
—He is misusing the arrangements whereby an additional 10 minutes was available for Ministers to reply to criticisms or matters raised relating to their portfolios.

—Order! I uphold the point of order. The Chair was prepared to give the Minister an opportunity to address himself to that requirement, possibly with more latitude than was appropriate. I ask the Minister immediately to confine himself simply to responding to the matters raised in the honourable member's speech.

—I accept you ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker, and will respond as the honourable member for Port Adelaide leaves the chamber. The honourable member for Hotham, before congratulating the Premier of Tasmania on founding a new national park in the south-west, ought to realise that the Premier and his Government want to put a massive hydro-electric commission scheme in the south-west and to seek the funds for that scheme from the Government of which I have the honour to be a Minister. Before people in this Parliament congratulate what I suggest is hypocritical and cynical grandstanding by a State Premier who declares an area to be a national park and then wants to put in a multi-million dollar hydro-electric scheme in the middle of it, they ought to check their facts. Finally, let me say that if people are genuinely interested in Tasmania then they should listen to the voices of the five Tasmanian members who have represented that State in this House for the last five years with very great distinction.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is his Department evaluating the drug Benoxaprofen, marketed in the United Kingdom as Opren.
(2) If so, when are the results likely to (a) become known and (b) be published.
(3) If the results are successful, will the drug be placed on the National Health Scheme list.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) I am unable to state when the results will become known although it is likely that the evaluation reports will be considered by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee before the end of this year.
(b) Results of the evaluation of drugs are not published, but are communicated in detail to the sponsoring drug companies as soon as practicable after their consideration by the ADEC.

(3) Drugs are considered for listing as pharmaceutical benefits under the National Health Scheme following a specific request from the company concerned or other interested parties. This consideration is given by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, which is the independent statutory body established under the National Health Act to advise the Minister for Health on the listing of pharmaceutical benefits. The company has applied for listing of Benoxaprofen and this will be considered if and when marketing approval is granted.

(2) If so, did the New Zealand Department of Agriculture and Fisheries advise his Department of the find, and supply details of the source and nature of infestation.

(3) Do Australian quarantine officials give details of similar finds at Australian ports to the New Zealand Department of Agriculture and Fisheries; if not, will he take active steps to develop such co-operation in quarantine matters between Australia and New Zealand.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. However, for years wood carpenter ants have been regularly intercepted at Australian ports of entry and appropriate quarantine action has been taken.

(3) No. The specific arrangements proposed are not regarded as necessary. However, an arrangement does exist whereby New Zealand advises Australia and Australia advises New Zealand of any infestations detected in plants or goods moving across the Tasman.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many lepers are in Australia and what is their distribution by State and Territory.
(2) How many cases of leprosy have been reported in each State and Territory in each of the last 3 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In view of the stigma attached to the word 'leper' and the now curable nature of the disease, it is desirable that sufferers from leprosy be no longer referred to as lepers but as cases of leprosy.
