QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What procedures have been adopted to ensure that animal and bird diseases are not introduced to the indigenous wildlife of Antarctica by (a) Australian expeditioners and (b) other nations with bases in the Antarctic.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The 'Agreed Measures', developed and agreed to by the members of the Antarctic Treaty, detail provisions for the protection of all native Antarctic wildlife and for the prevention of the introduction of pests or disease into the Treaty area. Australia gave the 'Agreed Measures' force of law under the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act which was proclaimed in June 1980. The Antarctic Division is administratively responsible for the Act including a permit system which is used to monitor and control activities which may have an adverse effect on the native fauna and flora or their habitat.

In accordance with Section 19 (1) of this Act, unless specifically authorised by permit, it is unlawful to take to the Antarctic any animal, plant, virus, bacterium, yeast or fungus that is not indigenous to the Antarctic. This provision does not apply to the introduction of animals and plants into Antarctica for use as food provided that they are used for this purpose and are kept under stringent conditions. Live poultry cannot be introduced.

The Division has actively implemented operational procedures consistent with the Agreed Measures. The growth in the use of containers and the unitisation of cargo and supplies has lessened the risk of contamination to the Antarctic environment. The cleanliness of containers is checked prior to their shipment from Australia. Unitised cargo loading has reduced the need for timber packaging. Other features of the Division's operations which promote environmental protection are:
No live animals are introduced to Antarctica or sub-Antarctic Islands. Husky dogs are bred at Mawson station and there is infrequent exchange of husky dogs between Antarctic stations.
Annual provision of new clothing, footwear, cooking utensils and machinery reduces significantly the likelihood of germs surviving on inanimate objects.
With few exceptions, frozen meats, vegetables and poultry products taken to stations are produced in Australia, and hence are free from most of the major pests and diseases.
Immediately prior to departure to Antarctica, all heavy machinery (ie tractors, motorised tobaggans and sledges) is steamed clean and if appropriate painted.
Once identified any possible source of quarantine threat is communicated to Antarctic stations and resupply vessels for their information and appropriate action.
In the history of Australia's Antarctic operations, no infection has been detected by quarantine inspectors in Antarctic resupply vessels.

(b) Antarctic Treaty Consultative Parties are bound by the provisions and procedures of the Agreed Measures for the Conservation of Antarctic Fauna and Flora. However, it is considered that itinerant yachts and foreign fishing trawlers operating in the Southern Ocean constitute a quarantine risk and there is a need for greater surveillance in this area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How is garbage and effluent disposed of at Australian Antarctic bases.
(2) Are the methods employed different from those adopted at the Antarctic bases of other nations; if so, in which way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: All sewage and sullage is piped untreated to the sea.
Burnable garbage is incinerated whilst remaining garbage is disposed to landfill.
Solid human waste is incinerated. The products are ash which is disposed to landfill.
Liquid human waste and sullage is piped untreated away from buildings whence it drains to the sea.
Burnable garbage is incinerated whilst remaining garbage is disposed to landfill.
In respect to future developments, current proposals as presented to the PWC provide that:
Liquid waste (human and sullage) will be biologically treated and effluent will be piped to the sea.
Sludge from the treatment process will be returned to Australia.
Other garbage will be compacted and returned to Australia.
Large metal objects will be cut up and returned to Australia.
(2) Twelve countries are operating stations in Antarctica. We have information concerning waste disposal practices of all these countries with the exception of Poland, Chile and Argentina.
The following summarises disposal methods used for human waste and sullage.

Piping untreated waste to sea 4 Waterborne system using recirculated effluent from which solids have been removed and incinerated 1 Landfill 2 Chemical toilets with sullage piped to sea or ice 2 Untreated waste piped to ice disposal 1 Wastes tankered to landfill area 1
Information concerning garbage disposal is not as clear as for human waste and sullage. The method commonly used is one or a combination of the following:
Disposal to sea by placing on pack ice.
From the information given in answer to Question 1, waste disposal methods used as Australian stations are approximately similar to those used, at the present time, by other countries.

In the future it is proposed that Australia should treat liquid waste and disposal of garbage by incineration and/or returning it to Australia. By comparison, no countries are known, at the present time, to be treating liquid waste as is proposed for Australian stations. Two countries at least are using chemical toilets.

If the proposals to treat liquid wastes are approved, Australia would be establishing a higher standard of waste disposal than is used at the present time by other countries. This higher standard would minimise the impact of waste disposal upon the Antarctic environment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The huts on Ross Island are the responsibility of New Zealand. The NZ Huts Restoration Committee, which was formed in 1959-60, undertakes care and maintenance of the huts. The Committee is accommodated within the NZ Department of Science and Industrial Research and draws on the following organisations; Royal NZ Navy; Historical Places Trust; Ministry of Works; NZ Antarctic Society; Dominion Museum and the NZ Antarctic Division.
Hut caretakers each summer are unpaid volunteers and are kitted by the NZ Antarctic Division and are transported to Antarctica by US aircraft. Up to one thousand visitors inspect the huts each year.
(2) Australia has made no contribution to the preservation of the huts.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has been taken by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs on the recommendation of the Commissioner for Community Relations in his 5th Annual Report for 1979-80 that Government agencies should grant equal recognition to Aborigines, Torres Strait Islanders and South Sea Islanders.

(2) Does the experience of Departmental officers support the Commissioner's assessment that distinctions made between the 3 groups in delivery of services and assessment of needs has created tensions and disharmony.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An Inter-departmental Committee established in 1975 to examine the situation of South Sea Islanders in Australia recommended that although there was evidence of some disadvantage, extension of the special assistance available to Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders was not warranted.

The Committee found that South Sea Islanders were not fully aware of existing general community assistance programs and benefits. As a result, when the then Minister for Social Security tabled a summary of the Committee's main findings on 13 September 1978 she announced that the needs of South Sea Islanders would be given specific attention by a social worker in her Department working in conjunction with other staff in regional offices.

(2) Officers of my Department have informed me that although distinctions in assistance programs available to South Sea Islanders, and Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders have been blamed for exacerbating tensions between the groups, the Department's experience has been that the causes of such tension, where it exists, are more deeply rooted.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: 5th Annual Report of the Commissioner for Community Relations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister support the following statement of the Commissioner for Community Relations at page 99 of his 5th Annual Report for 1979-80 that the solution to the white problems lies with the white governments and white bureaucracies; the answer to black problems lies with the powers that oppressed the Aborigines in the first place.
(2) If not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The quoted statement comes at the end of a section of the Commissioner's Annual Report in which he discusses complaints he received about 'Special Programs for Disadvantaged Groups' implemented by Commonwealth and State Governments. The Commissioner indicates his full support for Governments in implementing special measures and indicates that these do not constitute racial discrimination for the purposes of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination or the Racial Discrimination Act, but are required to ensure adequate development and protection of human rights for disadvantaged racial or ethnic groups. It remains the policy of the Commonwealth Government to maintain and develop special programs for the advancement of the Aboriginal people.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has been taken to enforce the 200 mile fishing zone in relation to Norfolk Island?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Primary Industry monitors reports of foreign fishing vessel activity in the Australian Fishing Zone (AFZ), including the AFZ around Norfolk Island and has arranged for the charter of aircraft on a number of occasions to investigate alleged infringements when timely information regarding such incidents has been received. In addition, the Australian Government has informed the relevant foreign governments of incidents involving foreign flag fishing vessels suspected of illegal activities in the AFZ around Norfolk Island.

Licences have been issued which permit a number of foreign fishing vessels to fish in the AFZ off Norfolk Island under prescribed terms and conditions. The operations of such vessels are monitored by means of a mandatory radio reporting system which requires each vessel to provide details of its movements and activities (including catches) to the Department of Primary Industry (via the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre) on a regular basis.

Surveillance and enforcement measures in the AFZ are under continuous review, including those relating to areas of the AFZ surrounding external territories, and will be further considered during the forthcoming review of the existing Australian civil coastal surveillance system, the report on which is due to be presented to the Australian Government in mid-1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he say in a recent statement concerning the lifting of the freeze on the southern bluefin tuna fishery, that new entrants, if any, will not be able to establish access rights under any future management regime on the same basis as fishermen who have operated in the fishery to date.
(2) If so, does his reference to a future management regime indicate that there will be a future management regime to replace the freeze on entry.

(3) Does the statement referred to in part (1) indicate that he intends establishing some form of second-class licence in the southern bluefin tuna fishery, in that certain licences will not carry with them the same rights as licences which existed prior to the lifting of the freeze.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) No. The statement indicates that if in future it proved necessary to control or even reduce the number of boats in the fishery, those who had been in the fishery for a period of time would be given priority over new entrants to the fishery.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he recently quote an economic study, or survey, undertaken by his Department as at least a substantial part of the basis on which he took the decision to lift the freeze on entry to the southern bluefin tuna fishery.

(2) If so, has the Australian Fishing Industry Council informed him that they regard the economic survey carried out by his Department as being inadequate, in that it contains old information which, in the view of the Council, is of very limited benefit, and also that it contains important gaps that throw the value of the entire document into doubt.

(3) Did the Australian Fishing Industry Council also request him to update and upgrade the economic survey which he used as the basis for his decision before any substantive decision is taken on the longterm future of the southern bluefin tuna fishery.
(4) If so, why did he choose to ignore the advice of the Council concerning the value of the economic survey.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The lifting of the freeze was based on the decision of the Australian Fisheries Council in 1979, confirmed in 1980 and supported by substantial sectors of the Australian fishing industry.
(3) Yes, although it is difficult to see how 1979-80 information could be regarded as seriously out of date.
(4) I did not ignore the advice of the Australian Fishing Industry Council.
